title: Psalms 1:1
content:
• Blessed: The Hebrew term (’ashrey) appears twenty-six times in Psalms. While some translations use “blessed,” a different term (barak) is used for blessings (Psalms 5:12; 45:2; 107:38).

  • The godly avoid living under the influence of sinners. Those who do not fear the Lord are wicked (Psalm 36:1). They oppose those who love God, do right, and the poor and oppressed (see 10:2–13; 37:14). The wicked might seem devoted to God (50:16). Sometimes they enjoy success, but it does not last long (37:35). They will face sadness and ruin when they must deal with the results of their bad actions (1:4–6; 9:16; 32:10).

  • People who turn away from God's path and rebel against him are sinners (Psalms 25:8; 78:17). They commit serious crimes like adultery (being unfaithful to their spouse) and murder (compare Psalm 51).

  • sit in the seat of: This expression describes a person who is controlled by sin (compare Psalm 1:2; 26:3–7; Deuteronomy 6:7).

  • Mockers are people who disrespect and reject God's wisdom. Mockers hate the Lord and insult anyone who tries to correct them (Proverbs 9:7–8). They seek only the “wisdom” that justifies their actions. These bold people have little respect for God, his plans, or his followers (see Psalms 86:14; 119:51, 69, 78, 85, 122). These three terms (wicked, sinners, mockers) describe all kinds of people who do not live in a way that pleases God.

title: Psalms 1:1–2
content: The Lord brings true happiness to those who turn away from evil and find joy in him.

title: Psalms 1:1–6
content: This wisdom psalm sets the tone for the whole Psalter. The psalmist strongly contrasts the happiness of the godly with the condemnation of the wicked; in the end, the way of wisdom will triumph. This idealization of the godly person (as in Ps 8) highlights the Lord’s expectations of his people and especially of the coming Messiah (Ps 2). The people of Israel did not live up to this ideal, and neither did the kings of David’s dynasty. Not even the best of them could bring in the triumph of righteousness described in Psalms 1, 2, and 72. In the New Testament, the apostles’ use of the Psalter to describe the life and ministry of Jesus the Messiah confirms that Jesus alone fulfills the ideal of the godly person presented in the psalms. Only Jesus could please God and secure redemption, happiness, and peace. Psalm 1 introduces the hopeful anticipation of the final hallelujah (Ps 150), when the Lord will remove all evil from his creation and prosper his children.

title: Psalms 1:1–2.12
content: The first two psalms serve as an introduction to the whole book of Psalms (called the Psalter). Psalm 1 presents the Lord's guidance in wisdom, while Psalm 2 shows God's rule over a rebellious and sinful world. Together, these psalms invite people to abandon foolishness, which leads to destruction. These psalms invite people to follow God's path instead, which leads to wisdom and salvation. The New Testament confirms that God will govern the nations through Jesus Christ, his chosen representative (Hebrews 1:5; Revelation 12:5; 19:15).

title: Psalms 1:1–8.9
content: Psalms 1 and 8 form an inclusio (set of literary bookends) that describes what God expects of the ideal person (cp. Pss 19; 33; 104; 145), contrasts the godly person with the wicked, and extols the godly person’s dignity. Jesus the Messiah (Ps 2)—the sovereign Lord (Heb 2:6–8; see 1 Cor 15:27) and perfection of humanity—embodies this ideal.

title: Psalms 1:2
content: The law (Hebrew torah) of the Lord is the full revelation of God’s instructions (see study note on Deut 4:44). • Meditating is a process of inner reflection that can be positive (Pss 1:2; 63:6; 77:12; 143:5) or negative (see 2:1; 38:12). The Lord’s word is the object of godly meditation (119:48). • Day and night includes all times, whether one is walking, standing, sitting, or sleeping (see Deut 6:7).

title: Psalms 1:3
content: Well-watered trees endure and bear abundant fruit (cp. Jer 17:8).

title: Psalms 1:3–5
content: The future belongs to the godly.

title: Psalms 1:4
content: The coming time of judgment (1:5) will carry off the wicked and their deeds (35:5; 83:13; Isa 17:13; see study note on Jer 13:24).

title: Psalms 1:5
content: The wicked cannot abide the scrutiny of the Lord’s judgment; they are already condemned (see 5:5; 7:6; 101:7).

title: Psalms 1:6
content:
• When God takes care of people who obey him and punishes people who do evil, it shows how God gives people what their actions deserve (see Galatians 6:7–10). This is called "retribution." The wicked might appear successful for a short while, but their lives are short and meaningless in the end. God and the people who remain faithful to him will have the final victory (see Psalms 9:5, 6, 18; 10:16; 37:20; 73:27; 92:9; compare 142:4; Isaiah 57:1).

  • People who live in a way that pleases God are happy (Psalms 1:1; 5:12; 14:5). They are happy because God protects and cares for them, listens when they ask for justice, and secures their future (see 121:3–4).

  • A person's path is their life and character.

title: Psalms 2:1
content: plot: The Hebrew verb translated as "meditates" in Psalm 1:2 suggests opposing the Lord through speech (Isaiah 59:13) or thought (Psalm 38:12; Proverbs 24:2).

title: Psalms 2:1–3
content: Their futile paths lead to death (1:4, 6), but fallen human beings unite in opposing the true God and his Messiah.

title: Psalms 2:1–12
content: This royal psalm pertains to the Lord’s appointment of a king descended from David. It celebrates the mission of all the kings in David’s line, and it introduces the hope of an ideal ruler who will accomplish the Lord’s goal of bringing all nations into submission (2:11) or to destruction (2:9). The New Testament identifies Jesus as this descendant (see Acts 13:33; 1 Cor 15:25–27; Heb 1:5; 5:5; Rev 19:15).

title: Psalms 2:2
content: The kings hate the Lord’s established order in the world, so they desire to be independent of him (see 36:4). They scheme about dominating the Lord’s people (31:13; see 83:1–4). Their goal is to subvert the Lord’s rule in the world by overthrowing his anointed one (or his messiah); the Lord chose the kings of David’s dynasty to establish his kingdom throughout the earth. The New Testament confirms that Jesus, the appointed and anointed Son of God (Acts 4:26; 13:33; Heb 1:5; 5:5), fulfills the role in which these earlier kings failed.

title: Psalms 2:3
content: break their chains: These kings believe that acknowledging the true God and his chosen ruler will result in their enslavement (Isa 28:22; 52:2; cp. Lam 3:7; Rom 1:1; 1 Cor 7:22; Titus 1:1).

title: Psalms 2:4
content: rules in heaven: The Lord’s place in the universe is so certain that he scoffs at humans who boast that they can rebel against his power and authority (see 37:13; 59:8).

title: Psalms 2:4–6
content: The Lord finds the human threat insignificant. He provided a solution long before their rebellion. He will end their agitation through the appointment of a human agent, a descendant of David’s line who will rule the nations.

title: Psalms 2:6
content: my chosen king: The Lord establishes his anointed ruler.

title: Psalms 2:7
content: Today I have become your Father: People in the ancient Near East commonly accepted a father-son relationship between gods and kings. In Israel, the Lord adopted kings as his sons. God set David apart as his most excellent and exalted son (89:27). All descendants of David were the Lord’s representatives or agents. As an eternal member of the Godhead (John 1:1) and a descendant of David (Acts 13:33; Heb 1:5; 5:5), Jesus is the true Son of God.

title: Psalms 2:7–9
content: The Lord adopted the king of David’s dynasty to conquer rebellious nations by force (see 89:26–27).

title: Psalms 2:8
content: In an example of the suzerain-vassal relationship between the Lord and Israel’s king (see Deuteronomy Book Introduction, “Literary Form”), the Lord invites the king to ask for favors (see Ps 21:2, 4). • All nations will be subject to David’s descendant, the Messiah.

title: Psalms 2:9
content: The Lord gives his anointed ruler the power to conquer the nations as his inheritance (Isa 11:4; Rev 2:27; 12:5; 19:15), breaking their rebellion, resistance, and independence.

title: Psalms 2:10
content: It pleases the Lord when his people submit to him and seek his protection. The wise accept the Lord’s rebuke and desire to repent.

title: Psalms 2:11–12
content: rejoice: Rulers must welcome the Son as their true and only King. • Submit to God’s royal son (or Submit to God’s royal Son, or kiss the son): Kissing was an expression of submission (Hos 13:2). • The Lord gives joy to all who fear him (Ps 1:1–2) and trust him (18:30; 34:22; 119:1–3).

title: Psalms 3:1
content:
title

This sad episode in David’s life (see 2 Sam 15–18) helps readers keep the promises of Ps 2 in perspective. The Lord granted victory to his anointed king (Ps 2), but the manner and timing of this victory remained in God’s hands.

title: Psalms 3:1–2
content: The psalmist’s many enemies speak brashly (4:6; 12:4; 40:15) and question the Lord’s ability to rescue (10:11; 22:7–8; 71:10). Their words haunt him because it seems that the Lord will not answer his prayer. • These enemies wield great power (cp. 2:1–3); unlike Ps 2, this psalm does not resolve the crisis.

title: Psalms 3:1–8
content: This psalm laments that the expectations raised by Pss 1–2 have not been met. But even when beset by enemies, godly people need not question the Lord’s just dealings. Rather, they can confidently trust his goodness and expect God to rescue them.

title: Psalms 3:1–7.17
content: This group of psalms moves readers from the orderly world of Pss 1–2 to a disoriented one. The Lord’s anointed cries out while facing enemies, ferocious opposition, evil schemes, and the Lord’s apparent distance.

title: Psalms 3:3
content: The psalmist contrasts the contention of his enemies (3:2) with the Lord’s provision. The Lord is a shield for his people; he turns their defeat and shame into victory and glory.

title: Psalms 3:3–4
content: The psalmist’s eyes turn from his enemies to the Lord.

title: Psalms 3:5
content: By refocusing on the Lord (3:3–4) in the midst of his crisis, the psalmist can rest, confident of his safety (see study note on 4:8). The Lord cares for his servant; he protects him and keeps his mind and heart from fear (37:17; 54:4; 119:116; 145:14).

title: Psalms 3:6
content: The psalmist’s peaceful confidence in the Lord’s protection and care shields him from evil and gives him a new sense of reality (23:4; 27:1, 3; 46:1; 56:4, 11; 91:5–6; 118:6).

title: Psalms 3:7–8
content: The psalmist does not seek revenge; instead, he waits for the Lord’s vengeance. • Arise: The psalmist calls upon the Lord to take action now.

title: Psalms 4:1
content: Waiting for the Lord’s answer allows for growth in patience and for the refinement of living faith (38:15).

title: Psalms 4:1–8
content:
This personal lament includes:

  • a prayer for rescue (Psalm 4:1)

  • a rebuke of the enemy (Psalm 4:2–3)

  • advice to the faithful (Psalm 4:4–5)

  • a statement of confidence (Psalm 4:6–8)

title: Psalms 4:2
content:
• The opponents of those who follow God rely on false beliefs, deceit, and idol worship.

  • my honor (or my glory): The psalmist's honor, or possibly the Lord's, is being challenged.

title: Psalms 4:4
content: Angry feelings are not sinful, but letting anger control you leads to sin (see 37:7–8; cp. Eph 4:26–27, 31–32). • Instead of acting on their emotions, the godly think about their circumstances overnight. They might be disturbed as they sleep, but silence opens their hearts to trust in the Lord (Ps 4:5).

title: Psalms 4:5
content: Offer sacrifices in the right spirit: Redirecting emotions toward the Lord prevents a godly individual from doing too much self-reflection (40:6–8; 51:17).

title: Psalms 4:6
content: your face (or the light of your face): The psalmist seeks God’s favor and peace (Num 6:25–26), which can transform darkness into light (see Ps 27:1). Confident trust in the Lord is an antidote to anger, resentment, jealousy, and materialism.

title: Psalms 4:8
content: Peace comes from God’s blessing and protection (4:6; see 37:11).

title: Psalms 5:1–2
content: The request hear me appears in several prayers as a call for God’s attention during a time of trouble (39:12; 84:8; 143:1), as does pay attention (17:1; 54:2; 130:2). The needy ask their God, “Are you listening?”

title: Psalms 5:1–12
content: This morning prayer (5:3) expresses unwavering confidence in the Lord’s help and protection. The psalmist asks for and awaits God’s response (5:1–3). He describes the schemes of the wicked in detail but does not get lost in his circumstances. The psalmist also knows that the wicked cannot coexist with God (5:4–6, 9; see 1:5). He keeps returning to the Lord (5:7–8, 10; see 5:1–3), and then he prays for the godly community (5:10–12; see 3:8).

title: Psalms 5:3
content: The psalmist begins and ends each day with prayer, awaiting new expressions of God’s fidelity and goodness (143:8). • wait expectantly: The psalmist does not demand God’s grace but places hope in it (see Mic 7:7; Hab 2:1).

title: Psalms 5:5
content: the proud: Mockers (see study note on 1:1), the wicked (73:3; 75:4), and the arrogant (10:2) use their mouths to twist truth and challenge the faith of the godly. • The Lord allows only the godly into his presence (see 1:5). His holiness and justice do not tolerate oppression or those who do evil. • you hate: The Lord rejects proud sinners (see also 11:5).

title: Psalms 5:7
content: God promises his unfailing love—his covenant goodness and faithfulness—to his people (see 25:6; 69:16; Lam 3:32). • your house: The godly long to come into God’s presence with reverence and awe (see Heb 12:28).

title: Psalms 5:8
content: God guides those who are obedient, submissive, and patient in waiting for him to lead, provide, and protect them (27:11; 43:3; 143:10), not those who expect God simply to endorse their own decisions. • Following the right path of wisdom leads to the Lord (27:11; 61:2; 139:24).

title: Psalms 5:9–10
content: The psalmist again describes the vile acts of the wicked, who cannot stand in God’s presence.

title: Psalms 5:10
content: The psalmist prays for the justice and retribution that God promised against the wicked (1:6)—those who have rebelled against the Lord. • The wicked lay traps to kill (38:12) or deceive (140:4–5).

title: Psalms 5:11
content: A blessing rests on all who take refuge in God (see 18:30). • Joy and praise make good companions. The godly rejoice when they see evidence of God’s rescue. They sing joyful praises as a new song (see 33:3). When the Lord restores peace to this world, puts down evil, and rewards the righteous, they will have lasting joy (9:2–4; 53:6; 90:14–15; 118:24). • The children of God, who find refuge in him, love his name. To love his name is to love his very character.

title: Psalms 5:12
content: The psalmist extends his concern beyond himself to all the godly. • A shield, here an image of God’s protection, deflects spears and arrows from its bearer.

title: Psalms 6:1
content: don’t rebuke me . . . or discipline me: The psalmist does not explicitly connect God’s discipline with sin here (cp. 39:8–11), but it might be implied.

title: Psalms 6:1–3
content: The psalmist asks for God’s favor and restoration at a difficult time.

title: Psalms 6:1–10
content: The occasion for this lament might have been sickness or a mental or spiritual depression from which the psalmist sought healing.

title: Psalms 6:2–3
content: In his longing for God’s response to his prayer, the psalmist grew physically weak (6:6; see 77:3; 119:81; 142:1–3; see also Ps 101). Fasting might have played a part in his agony, but this is not mentioned.

title: Psalms 6:4–5
content: The experience was so painful that the psalmist might as well have been dead, or perhaps he feared for his life.

title: Psalms 6:5
content: from the grave? Hebrew from Sheol? In the Old Testament, Sheol is the abode of the dead. It is not necessarily associated with punishment.

title: Psalms 6:6–7
content: The psalmist is exhausted to the depths of his being from the anguish of his spiritual distance from the Lord (22:1; 31:9–10; 102:5). • When eyes dim, the body is failing (see 13:3; 31:9; 38:10; Matt 6:22).

title: Psalms 6:8–10
content: In a closing note of triumph, the psalmist reasserts his confidence in the Lord.

title: Psalms 7:1
content: Persecutors (a common term for “enemies”) intentionally seek out people in order to destroy them (31:15; 56:1–2; 71:11; 143:3).

title: Psalms 7:1–17
content: This psalm consists of a lament (7:1–2), an oath of innocence (7:3–5), an appeal to God’s justice (7:6–9), an affirmation of God’s just kingship (7:10–16), and a concluding hymn of praise (7:17).

title: Psalms 7:title
content: an unknown person of the tribe of Benjamin, remained hostile to David.

title: Psalms 7:2
content: Like a lion, a wicked enemy relentlessly and violently pursues its prey (10:9; 17:12; 22:13, 21; 35:17; 57:4), but God promises victory (91:13).

title: Psalms 7:3
content: The psalmist does not claim to be without sin, but he knows that he does not deserve the brutal attacks of his opponents (see 35:7).

title: Psalms 7:3–5
content: The psalmist swears to his innocence, making himself vulnerable to scrutiny (7:9.

title: Psalms 7:5
content: trample: Cp. 44:5; 60:12; 91:13; 108:13. • into the ground . . . in the dust: Disgrace and shame can lead to death and the grave (143:3; see 13:3–4).

title: Psalms 7:6
content: God’s judgment brings justice, despite the chaos created by adversaries (see 7:11).

title: Psalms 7:6–9
content: With this appeal to God for justice in the world, the psalmist also submits to God’s examination.

title: Psalms 7:8
content: The judgment is against the defendants (the nations) and in favor of the righteous plaintiff (the psalmist; see 43:1). • Although not innocent of all sin, the psalmist is a person of authentic integrity (see 15:2; 25:21; 41:12; 78:72; cp. Job 1:1, 8; 9:20, 22).

title: Psalms 7:9
content: God examines the mind and heart of each person (see 11:3–4; 26:2; 139:1, 23).

title: Psalms 7:10–13
content: The psalmist moves from his own situation (7:1–9) to speak for all the godly who long for redemption (7:10–16). He depicts God as the righteous King who vindicates his subjects when they cry out for rescue.

title: Psalms 7:11
content: The honest Lord cannot be bought or bribed, nor does he abuse his power (9:4; cp. 82:1–8).

title: Psalms 7:12–13
content: sword . . . bow . . . deadly weapons . . . flaming arrows: As the Divine Warrior, God goes on the offensive on behalf of himself and his people.

title: Psalms 7:14
content: Evil begins with small words or steps, and gives birth to increasingly worse deeds as time goes on (see Isa 59:4–5).

title: Psalms 7:17
content: I will thank . . . sing praise: The laments in Pss 3–7 usually move from lament to praise, as does the Psalter as a whole. • Most High: This is an ancient designation for God (see Gen 14:19). • God is just and reliable, so his order prevails in this world.

title: Psalms 8:1
content: The Lord (Hebrew Yahweh), the covenant God of Israel (Exod 3:15), also holds the title of Lord (Hebrew ’adonay), the king of the earth. • The word translated majestic (sometimes translated “mighty”) can describe kings (Ps 136:18), heroes (16:3), mountains (76:4), or waves breaking on the seashore (93:4). While all are awe-inspiring and mighty, the created order pales in comparison with the Lord. • A person’s name embodies their reputation. • The earth and the heavens reveal the Lord’s splendor. All creation worships and praises the Lord (66:4; 113:3; 145:21).

title: Psalms 8:1–9
content: Psalm 8 begins the second part of Book One of the Psalms (Psalms 8–14). The psalmist praises God’s creation and the dignity of the ideal human (see Psalm 1). Instead of the world of enemies, wicked people, and unfair justice shown in Psalms 3–7, this psalm presents the world as God first made it. Someone who is tired (both physically and emotionally) can imagine a place of dignity in God’s world.

title: Psalms 8:2
content: silencing: The loud noise of the oppressors contrasts with the praise of God. In the end, the praise of God will overwhelm the sound of evil (31:18; 63:11; 101:5; 143:12). • Those who oppose God seethe with vindictive anger (2:1–3; 44:16; cp. 149:6–7).

title: Psalms 8:3
content: The nations around Israel worshiped heavenly objects as deities. The sun, moon, and stars are indeed immense and glorious, but they are merely the work of your fingers, a reason to praise the Almighty.

title: Psalms 8:3–5
content: In light of God’s awesome glory, it might seem that people would be insignificant to him. However, he has crowned them with glory and honor and placed them over all creation.

title: Psalms 8:4
content: human beings (literally son of Adam): The Hebrew idiom son of man (or son of Adam) means a human being. Through the influence of Dan 7:13–14, it became a title with divine overtones in the New Testament. See Heb 2:6–8, where this passage is quoted.

title: Psalms 8:5
content: Yet you made them only a little lower than God: Humans bear God’s image; the Lord has endowed humans with dignity and charged them to rule (Gen 1:26–27). Hebrews 2:6–8 applies these words to Jesus Christ, the ideal human who fully realized God’s purposes.

title: Psalms 8:6
content: gave them charge of everything: The psalmist is still referring to humans in general. Paul applies these words to Jesus as the perfect man who has made the created order—even death (1 Cor 15:25–27)—subject to God and his glory. The New Testament connects these themes of creation and salvation with Jesus Christ (John 1:1–2, 14; Col 1:16).

title: Psalms 8:7–8
content: Wild animals, including birds and fish, remind readers of God’s creation of the animal world in Gen 1. Contrary to beliefs among Israel’s neighbors in the ancient Near East, animals are not sacred.

title: Psalms 9:1
content: The verb translated praise is translated “thank” in 7:17, suggesting a close connection between Pss 7 and 9 (see 7:17; 8:1–2). With all my heart expresses the psalmist’s deep devotion and commitment (86:12; 111:1; 119:10; 138:1). • I will tell: These stories educate the next generation (78:4; 145:4); when they are not remembered, a generation might easily depart from the Lord (78:11, 32). • The marvelous things include the Lord’s judgments on the enemies of his people (9:4) and his care for the oppressed (9:9). The wonders in creation, in redemption, and in revelation reveal his character and show his power (89:5; 111:4; 119:18, 27). His powerful manifestations evoke public praise (9:1; 26:7; 75:1).

title: Psalms 9:title
content: but that tune is no longer known. So also with the tunes mentioned in Pss 22, 45, 56–60, 69, 75, and 80.

title: Psalms 9:1–10.18
content: This hymn celebrates the Lord’s kingship and victory over evil. It might also serve as a response to the laments of Pss 3–7. Some believe that Pss 9 and 10 should be read together as one psalm in two parts because Ps 9 includes a title and Ps 10 does not, and although several letters are missing or inverted, the two psalms connect as an acrostic of the Hebrew alphabet (other such alphabetic acrostics are Pss 25, 34, 37, 111–112, 119, 145). The ancient Greek and Latin translations treat 9 and 10 as one.

title: Psalms 9:2
content: filled with joy . . . sing praises: The psalmist often connects joy with praises, as one leads to the other (5:11–12; 32:11; 67:4; 90:14; 92:4).

title: Psalms 9:3
content: retreated . . . staggered: The Lord overpowers even powerful enemies (see 27:2). Israel also experienced judgment when it resisted the Lord (107:12).

title: Psalms 9:3–6
content: The psalmist celebrates God’s judgment of the wicked, which is a testimony to the Lord’s reliable promise to establish his kingdom on earth (1:6; Ps 2).

title: Psalms 9:4
content: The throne represents the Lord’s royal authority.

title: Psalms 9:5
content: God created the heavens and the earth with a word (Gen 1), and he can bring nations to an end with a word (see Ps 2:5). Evil and those who do evil will come to an absolute end (69:28; 109:13; Rev 21:4).

title: Psalms 9:7–10
content: The godly do not put their hope in corruptible human government but in God’s everlasting rule of justice and fairness (see Pss 96–100).

title: Psalms 9:9
content: The Lord provides shelter in dangerous circumstances and refuge from powerful and oppressive people. The Psalter includes many similar images of the Lord, such as fortress (18:2; 31:2), rock (18:2; 42:9), strength (18:1), and strong tower (144:2). These images occur frequently in the royal prayers (see 9:9; 18:30). • Even oppressed, afflicted, and marginalized people (10:17; 74:21) can enjoy divine protection. • The times of trouble (10:1; 20:1) stand in contrast with appointed times when the Lord openly bestows his favor upon the afflicted (69:13; 102:13; see Ps 107:6).

title: Psalms 9:10
content: Alienation from the Lord might be part of an individual’s experience (22:1; 42:9; 119:8), yet the psalms affirm that the Lord will not abandon his people (16:10; 37:25, 28).

title: Psalms 9:11
content: The psalm writers often connect the idea that God reigns (or sits, or is enthroned) with a place, such as heaven (2:4; see 47:9), Jerusalem, “between the cherubim” (80:1; 99:1), “on high” (113:5), or “at my right hand” (110:1). Since the Lord rules the world, all people must know of his unforgettable deeds of salvation (see 9:1; 64:9; 66:16; 105:1).

title: Psalms 9:11–12
content: Recognition that the Lord’s judgment falls on some of the wicked (9:3–6) and that God promises to judge all evil (9:7–10) motivates praise. The psalmist calls on the godly community to join him.

title: Psalms 9:12
content: The Lord saves his servants and punishes those who have harmed them (Psalm 18:46). He defends his servants by fairly judging his enemies on earth (Psalm 58:11). Those who follow God do not seek revenge. Instead, they wait for the Lord to defend them (Psalm 94:1–2; Deuteronomy 32:35; Romans 12:19).

title: Psalms 9:13–14
content: The psalmist returns from a vision of the glorious future to the reality of facing his enemies (9:3). • The jaws (literally gates) are a vivid image of the powerful grip of death (see 13:3–4). • Jerusalem’s gates provide an intentional contrast to the “gates” of death.

title: Psalms 9:18
content: Hope requires waiting for the Lord’s rescue or justice (25:3, 5, 21). The godly find hope, rest, and quietness as they await the Lord (see 1:6; 27:14).

title: Psalms 9:19–20
content: The psalmist ends his lament with a prayer for the Lord’s intervention and divine vengeance. • mere mortals . . . merely human: Humans who have received authority and glory sometimes become oppressive and assume glory for themselves (see 8:4; 10:18).

title: Psalms 10:1
content: The opening questions set the mood. The Lord does not seem to hear the prayers of his people (22:1, 19; see 2 Kgs 4:27; Isa 1:15).

title: Psalms 10:1–18
content: The lament of 9:13–20 continues in Ps 10 (see study note on Pss 9–10), but the mood changes from confident assertion to anguished questioning. The psalmist prays for rescue, believing that the Lord, as a just king, takes care of the needy.

title: Psalms 10:2
content: The wicked brazenly defy God with their acts and speech (17:10; 31:18; 59:12; 73:8; 123:4). Although the Lord will deal with them (31:23), they disturb the righteous (see 5:4–6) prior to their condemnation and judgment.

title: Psalms 10:2–11
content: Wicked and oppressive people might prosper, leaving ugly consequences. Evil can be as dramatic as the psalmist portrays it here, or it could be more subtle.

title: Psalms 10:3
content: Unlike those who have evil desires, the godly wait for justice (10:17).

title: Psalms 10:4
content: God is dead: See 10:11; 14:1.

title: Psalms 10:6–7
content: Despite their evil ways (5:9; 28:3; Rom 3:14), the wicked expect a future free of trouble such as the righteous will enjoy.

title: Psalms 10:8
content: The wicked rely on outright violence (11:5; 37:32) and deception (Prov 12:6; 23:27–28).

title: Psalms 10:12–15
content: With confidence that the wicked will be held responsible for their deeds and that the Lord will care for the helpless, the psalmist prays intensely for rescue from evil.

title: Psalms 10:14
content: Because the Lord cares for the afflicted, he will take note and punish evildoers (see 72:14; 116:15).

title: Psalms 10:15
content: The psalmist strongly invokes a curse as he prays (see “Prayers for Vengeance” Theme Note). • Arms represent an ability to wage war (18:34; 44:3).

title: Psalms 10:16
content: As the true and just king, God will bring the wicked to an end, as he promises (1:6).

title: Psalms 10:17–18
content: The psalmist expresses his confidence in the Lord.

title: Psalms 10:18
content: Mere people misuse their power and enslave the very people God wants them to serve (see 9:19–20; Luke 22:25–26).

title: Psalms 11:1
content: God provides protection (or refuge; see 5:11; 9:9; 25:20) when the foundations of justice collapse. • The mountains provide another place of refuge (see 121:1).

title: Psalms 11:1–7
content: The psalmist affirms his faith in the righteous God. Even though the world appears hopelessly chaotic, both the godly and the wicked can count on God’s justice. The godly can depend on him as a refuge and shelter.

title: Psalms 11:2
content: The wicked live in the shadows and create gloom for the godly (82:5; 139:11; 143:3; Prov 4:19).

title: Psalms 11:2–3
content: In the inevitable battle between the evil and the godly, the wicked cannot tolerate the righteous, so they victimize them. This seems to leave the godly with nothing but questions.

title: Psalms 11:3
content: The wicked create a world of darkness (see 82:5).

title: Psalms 11:4
content: The righteous King rules from heaven, where his throne is untouched by human corruption (see 2:4). He examines everyone and sees everything that happens on earth (see 14:2–3).

title: Psalms 11:5
content: hates: See 5:4–6; Prov 6:16–18. • Wicked deeds result in destruction and violence (Pss 58:2; 73:6; 74:20).

title: Psalms 11:6
content: God rained blazing coals and burning sulfur on Sodom and Gomorrah (Gen 19) as symbols of judgment (Pss 18:8; 120:4; 140:10).

title: Psalms 11:7
content: The godly are assured of the Lord’s favorable presence when they see his face (see 23:6).

title: Psalms 12:1–4
content: Evil becomes so pervasive that the godly pray for rescue (Isa 57:1; Mic 7:2; cp. Pss 1:6; 37:20; 58:7; 104:35).

title: Psalms 12:1–8
content: This community lament seeks the Lord’s help against the prevalence of evil. Because of the Lord’s answer, the godly can face the future knowing that God protects them.

title: Psalms 12:4
content: The words they say reveal the character of the wicked. They deceive and overpower the godly and arrogantly question the Lord’s purposes.

title: Psalms 12:6
content: The godly can rely on the Lord’s promises, but not on the lies of the wicked (12:2–4). • Seven times means totally or completely.

title: Psalms 12:7–8
content: The godly know that the Lord cares, even though the wicked continue to oppress them. The Lord sees the corrupt and foolish people who praise evildoers (see 9:19–20; 14:2–6).

title: Psalms 13:1–2
content: How long? The fourfold repetition expresses agitation and deep anguish (79:5).

title: Psalms 13:1–6
content: The psalmist’s piercing cry for help becomes a confident song of hope.

title: Psalms 13:2
content: A sense of anguish and sorrow closes off any perspective of hope (6:3). Unless the Lord answers the psalmist’s prayers (22:1), death seems inescapable, torturous, and slow (6:6; 32:3; 55:4; 61:2; 102:5; 116:3). The psalmist hardly knows how to pray; he longs for God’s redemption (25:17–18; 31:10; 38:8; 39:2).

title: Psalms 13:3
content: The psalmist’s affliction feels like death (22:15; 55:4; 88:15; 94:17; 116:3).

title: Psalms 13:3–4
content: Only the Lord can bring enlightenment and relief. The psalmist longs for the Lord’s vindication so that his foes will not rejoice.

title: Psalms 13:5–6
content: The psalmist no longer hears the ridicule of his foes. Instead, because of his trust in the Lord, he is full of joy.

title: Psalms 14:1
content: Also known as fools, the wicked speak to themselves, think, scheme (10:4, 6, 11), and make claims; however, because they do not heed God’s revelation, they possess no understanding (14:1; 39:8; 53:1; 74:18, 22).

title: Psalms 14:1–3
content: Paul uses phrases from the Greek translation of this passage in his description of the depravity of all people (Rom 3:10–12).

title: Psalms 14:1–7
content: This wisdom psalm contains some characteristics of lament and prophetic speech. The ideals of Ps 8 have run aground on the reality of foolish human attitudes and sinful actions. With the exception of vv 5–6, this psalm parallels Ps 53.

title: Psalms 14:2–3
content: From heaven (33:13; 80:14; 102:19), the Lord sees the wicked, who stand out as vile sinners (11:3–5). The entire human race lacks wisdom and fails to live up to the glory originally given to them (10:4–11; see Rom 1–3).

title: Psalms 14:4
content: The evil live at the expense of others (27:2; 44:11; 53:4; see Isa 5:8) and have no reverence or knowledge of God (Ps 79:6).

title: Psalms 14:5
content: Though the wicked perish (1:5–6), God is with the godly.

title: Psalms 14:7
content: The psalmist prays for the renewal of God’s relationship with his people. • Jacob is a synonym for Israel (see Gen 35:9–10).

title: Psalms 15:1
content: Only the godly may reside in the Lord’s presence (5:4). As his guests, they experience his hospitality and protection. • sanctuary (or tent): In David’s time, God’s sanctuary was a tent (the Tabernacle; see 1 Sam 21:6; 2 Sam 6:17; 7:6; 12:20; 1 Chr 6:32).

title: Psalms 15:1–5
content: In this wisdom poem, the psalmist contrasts the lifestyle of the godly with the actions of fools (Ps 14). The questions in this psalm invite readers to examine themselves and to look away from problems with the wicked. The question of who dwells in God’s presence leads into a description of godly character qualities (cp. 24:3–6; Isa 33:14–16).

title: Psalms 15:1–19.14
content: The psalms in this section affirm integrity and purity (17:15; 18:20–26; 19:13–14). They refer to people as dwelling in God’s presence (16:9–11; 17:15) and as not being shaken (15:5; 16:8).

title: Psalms 15:2
content: The godly speak truthfully and act faithfully in their relationships. Unlike the wicked, they are open and transparent (12:2–4).

title: Psalms 15:5
content: The Lord prohibited Israel from charging interest to people in need (Exod 22:25–27). • The assurance of God’s presence keeps the godly from destruction (Pss 16:8; 46:5; 125:1). Their circumstances might shake them temporarily, but they ultimately stand firm (30:6; 94:18; 112:6).

title: Psalms 16:1
content: The psalmist feels safe because the Lord alone offers security (16:5–6), guidance (16:7–8), and the joy of his presence (16:9–11).

title: Psalms 16:1–11
content: In this psalm of confidence, the poet moves quickly from a short petition (16:1), to expressions of passionate commitment to God and his people (16:2–6), to a conclusion of confident praise (16:7–11).

title: Psalms 16:2
content: I said to the Lord: The various writers of the psalms pray, lament, and praise the Lord throughout the Psalter, and the Lord answers them (see 12:5–6).

title: Psalms 16:4
content: The psalmist dissociates himself from ungodly worship, rituals, and words (see 15:3–5).

title: Psalms 16:5
content: The cup of blessing represents God’s provision for all the psalmist’s needs (23:5; see 116:13; cp. 75:8; Isa 51:17).

title: Psalms 16:6
content: The land is God’s gift for his people (Deut 18:8).

title: Psalms 16:7–8
content: God’s instruction brings life (16:11; see 5:8; 23:1–3; 32:8; 73:24). • The psalmist so deeply depends on the Lord for strength and joy that he senses that God is right beside him (16:11; see 73:23; 109:31; 110:1, 5; 121:5). • Peter quoted 16:8–11 in his sermon on the day of Pentecost (Acts 2:25–28).

title: Psalms 16:9–11
content: Knowing that not even death can separate him from the Lord strengthens the psalmist’s confidence. He fears a separation (see 13:3–4), but he remains confident of seeing the Lord (see 11:7).

title: Psalms 16:10
content: The psalmist expresses his confidence that life continues beyond death. The apostles applied this text to the resurrection of Jesus (Acts 2:25–33; 13:35).

title: Psalms 16:11
content: with you: See 16:7–8; 110:1.

title: Psalms 17:1
content: comes from honest lips: Deception characterizes the wicked. The godly reject such deceit as a failure of character and pray for rescue from such people (5:6; 43:1; 120:2). They love honesty, truth, and integrity (15:2–3; 24:4; 101:7).

title: Psalms 17:1–15
content: The psalmist pleads for God’s protection and vindication, affirms his own integrity, and prays that the Lord will prevail against his fierce enemies.

title: Psalms 17:3
content: Though he is not perfect, the psalmist commits himself to the Lord. He does not want to sin through deception, flattery, or gossip (see 10:7; 15:2–3; 17:1).

title: Psalms 17:3–5
content: The psalmist declares his innocence (17:1) and commits himself to integrity by being open to God’s examination.

title: Psalms 17:6–9
content: This prayer for God’s care returns to the petition begun in 17:1–2 for redemption from evil.

title: Psalms 17:8
content: as you would guard your own eyes (literally as the pupil of your eye): This metaphor expresses God’s care and affection for the psalmist (see Deut 32:10). • The shadow of God’s wings is a place of his protection from enemies and adversity (Pss 36:7; 57:1; 61:4; 63:7; 91:4).

title: Psalms 17:13–14
content: The psalmist confidently prays for the Lord’s victory, knowing that God possesses more power than the evildoers. The psalmist finds his joy in the Lord’s inheritance (16:5), whereas the wicked search for joy in this world.

title: Psalms 17:15
content: see you face to face: The psalmist does not allow temporary concerns raised by adversaries to stand in the way of his experiencing a real and lasting relationship with the Lord.

title: Psalms 18:1
content: Lord, charged with the responsibility of establishing God’s kingdom on earth (see 78:70; 132:10; 144:10). • The Lord rescued David from all his enemies when he enabled David to conquer them (see 2 Sam 8:1–14).

title: Psalms 18:1–50
content: This royal drama of divine rescue (also found with minor variations in 2 Sam 22:1–51) encourages readers who are following the laments and requests for rescue in Pss 16 and 17. The psalmist describes the dramatic nature of God’s rescue in three different ways (18:7–15, 16–19, 30–36). The psalm also extends hope that a future Son of David will be totally victorious over evil (18:43–50; cp. Ps 2).

title: Psalms 18:2
content: A shield is an image of protection, salvation, and victory (7:10; 18:2, 30, 35; 84:11; 91:4; 115:9, 10, 11; 119:114; 144:2). It evokes a response of trust, waiting, and godly confidence.

title: Psalms 18:3
content: God deserves praise for his greatness and faithfulness (48:1; 96:4; 145:3).

title: Psalms 18:6
content: God dwells in his sanctuary, the heavenly temple (102:19; see 14:2–3). He knows everything, sees everyone, and will vindicate the godly (see 11:3–7).

title: Psalms 18:7
content: The destabilization of the whole earth will be a means of God’s judgment (77:17–18; 96:9; 97:4; 99:1; 104:32; Isa 29:6; Mic 1:3–4; Nah 1:2–6; Hag 2:7, 21).

title: Psalms 18:7–15
content: The psalmist depicts the Lord’s descent from heaven to earth with phenomena such as earthquakes, flames, smoke, darkness, and rain. Creation shudders at God’s marvelous coming as the Divine Warrior (see 97:2–5) and Judge (see 50:1–6).

title: Psalms 18:8
content: his nostrils . . . his mouth: The psalmist likens God to an angry person or a fierce creature (see Job 41:12–22). • The terrifying images of smoke, flames, and glowing coals express God’s wrath against sin.

title: Psalms 18:9–11
content: The Lord’s sovereignty extends over all of nature (see 104:2–4; 148:5–6).

title: Psalms 18:10
content: a mighty angelic being (Hebrew a cherub): See study notes on 1 Chr 28:18; 2 Chr 3:10–13.

title: Psalms 18:19
content: Because God loves and delights in the psalmist (see 18:1), he will save him (37:23; 41:11; 91:14–16).

title: Psalms 18:20–24
content: The psalmist affirms that loyalty is rewarded. He puts his trust in the Lord (see 16:1) and commits himself to living with integrity (see Pss 1, 15, 24; see also 19:12–14).

title: Psalms 18:21
content: kept the ways of the Lord: The psalmist faithfully obeys God’s instructions (see 25:8–10). • not turned . . . to follow evil: The psalmist rejects the way of folly (see Pss 1 and 14) and chooses the way of wisdom (see Pss 1 and 15).

title: Psalms 18:25–29
content: The faithful God remains true to his character. He loves faithfulness, blamelessness, and purity, and he hates the perverse (see 1:6).

title: Psalms 18:26
content: The pure have clean hands (see 18:20–24). • to the crooked you show yourself shrewd: The Lord knows each person’s character, and he justly responds to them in kind.

title: Psalms 18:27
content: proud: The Lord hates pride (101:5; 131:1; see Prov 6:16–17; 21:4; 30:13).

title: Psalms 18:28
content: light a lamp: The Lord renews the psalmist’s life, helping him overcome the darkness of adversity (see Pss 112:4; 119:105).

title: Psalms 18:29
content: scale any wall: God helps his servants fight their battles.

title: Psalms 18:30
content: perfect: God’s character has integrity (see 18:26). • God promises to protect his people, and he does so. • Seeking God’s protection entails trust and faith. Regardless of his feelings or external circumstances, the psalmist makes a deep commitment to the Lord. He experiences joy (5:11; 64:10) as he awaits the Lord’s rescue (57:1).

title: Psalms 18:30–36
content: The psalmist experiences God’s rescue and provision of victory.

title: Psalms 18:32–34
content: The psalmist’s victories come from the Lord. He completely depends on God.

title: Psalms 18:36
content: A wide path represents freedom and safety (see 4:8; 119:35).

title: Psalms 18:37–42
content: With help from the Divine Warrior, the psalmist experienced victory over his enemies.

title: Psalms 18:40
content: Placing a foot on the necks of the enemy represents total victory (see Josh 10:23–26).

title: Psalms 18:43–45
content: With God’s victorious help, the psalmist achieved military and political success, thus fulfilling the history of David’s dynasty (Ps 2). The previous laments find some resolution in this psalm.

title: Psalms 18:46–50
content: The psalmist again reflects on the Lord’s victories. God’s marvelous rescue and the king’s victory are cause for celebration.

title: Psalms 18:47
content: God vindicates his servant and so fulfills his mission (Ps 2; see 47:3; 144:2).

title: Psalms 18:49
content: The psalmist’s vision of praise . . . among the nations motivated Paul in his mission to the Gentiles (Rom 15:9).

title: Psalms 18:50
content: God appointed David, his anointed ruler, to bring order into God’s world (see Ps 2). Both David and his descendants received this responsibility.

title: Psalms 19:1
content: The glory of God refers to the splendor or manifest presence of the Creator (113:4). • God (Hebrew ’el): El is an ancient designation for God that signifies his creative power.

title: Psalms 19:1–4
content: The created order is an arena of God’s wisdom, and the heavens are the place of God’s dwelling (2:4; see 8:1; 57:5; 89:6; 115:3). From heaven, God observes humanity (11:4; 14:2; 33:13; 53:2; 80:14; 102:19) and comes to the rescue of his servants (18:6–8, 13; 20:6; 57:3; 76:8; 144:5). The heavens remain unaffected by human failures and rebellions (see 2:1–4). They display God’s qualities of fidelity, righteousness (36:5; 50:6; 57:10; 85:11; 89:2, 5; 97:6; 108:4), and wisdom (136:5; see 119:89–90). The heavens reveal the Lord’s glory (see 19:1) and give evidence of his presence and handiwork.

title: Psalms 19:1–14
content: God’s wisdom is manifest in heaven (19:1–4), in nature (19:4–6), in his instruction (19:7–11), and in the life of the psalmist (19:12–14). Like Ps 8, this hymn uses creation to motivate reflection—it is a peaceful oasis after the drama of the lament and victory psalms. The psalm begins with creation as a source of wisdom, then moves to God’s word as the perfect source of wisdom, and ends with the human need for redemption.

title: Psalms 19:3–4
content: God’s wisdom does not need to be spoken. Through creation, it is seen, felt, and experienced. Paul applied this text to condemn Israel for its lack of receptivity to Jesus Christ (Rom 10:18). • The sun is part of God’s creation, but it is not a deity, as people of other nations in the ancient Near East commonly believed.

title: Psalms 19:7–11
content: God’s instructions to humans reveal his character and wisdom. God’s instruction is precious and pleasant (119:103). It nourishes the person (Prov 16:24; 24:14) and is of more value than objects of human worth (Ps 81:13–16).

title: Psalms 19:12–14
content: The psalmist knows his faults, so he prays to remain faithful and commits himself to the Lord.

title: Psalms 19:13
content: An individual who commits deliberate sins does so with an insolent (86:14) or arrogant (119:21, 69) attitude. • The great sin is rebellion (see 32:1).

title: Psalms 19:14
content: words of my mouth . . . meditation of my heart: The psalmist desires to please God in everything he says and thinks (see Luke 6:45; Rom 12:1–2).

title: Psalms 20:1
content: The title God of Jacob affectionately expresses God’s ancient relationship with his people (see 46:7, 11; 75:9; 76:6; 81:1, 4; 84:8; 94:7; 114:7; 146:5). • keep you safe from all harm: See 59:1–2.

title: Psalms 20:1–5
content: The community prays for the king’s protection and victory.

title: Psalms 20:1–9
content: This royal prayer for God’s victory (20:1–5) leads to confidence in God’s rescue (20:6–8) and a communal request for God’s response (20:9).

title: Psalms 20:1–24.10
content: This sequence of psalms expresses the experience of moving from confidence and commitment (Pss 20–21), through anguish and abandonment (Ps 22), and finally to comfort, insight, and hope (Pss 23–24).

title: Psalms 20:3
content: Gifts and burnt offerings express submission to the Lord (cp. 40:6).

title: Psalms 20:4–5
content: make all your plans succeed . . . answer all your prayers: These requests could be those stated in 21:3–6 (cp. 27:4).

title: Psalms 20:5
content: Troops carried a victory banner to battle, under which they gathered and roused one another to action (see Isa 11:10, 12).

title: Psalms 20:6
content: God chose his anointed king to be ruler (see 2:7).

title: Psalms 20:6–8
content: An individual member of the community (20:1–5) responds with a word of assurance and confidence in God’s help.

title: Psalms 20:7
content: chariots and horses: These were instruments of war (see 33:16–17; 76:6; 147:10; Isa 30:16; 31:1–3).

title: Psalms 21:1–13
content: God’s people thank him for giving victory to the king.

title: Psalms 21:2
content: The king has experienced his heart’s desire—God’s protection and blessing (see 20:5; see also 2:8).

title: Psalms 21:3
content: success and prosperity: See Prov 10:6.

title: Psalms 21:3–6
content: The king returned victorious from battle and received honor from the people. His greatest honor came from God, who gave him blessings, life, and his presence.

title: Psalms 21:4
content: God offers a rich quality of life (61:6–7; 91:14–16; 128:4–6) characterized by his presence (16:11; 23:6; 27:4; 36:9), joy (16:11), goodness (23:6; 34:14–15), and protection (41:2; 61:7).

title: Psalms 21:6
content: God’s eternal blessings also bring fullness of life in the present (see Ps 133).

title: Psalms 21:7
content: The king enjoyed victory not because of his strength or intrinsic goodness but because God honored his faith.

title: Psalms 21:8–12
content: As long as even a single enemy opposed the king’s authority, God’s kingdom was not fully present. This prayer requests victory over all evil in the world.

title: Psalms 21:9
content: The flaming furnace and fire portray the severity of God’s judgment on the wicked. In the Old Testament, this image often refers to hell (11:6; 18:8; 50:3; 68:2; 78:21; 79:5; 80:16; 89:46; 97:3; 104:4; 140:10; see Isa 66:24).

title: Psalms 21:10
content: children . . . descendants: Evil will end when God destroys all opposition to himself (109:13; cp. 18:50; 22:30–31; 25:13; 102:28).

title: Psalms 21:13
content: Rise up (or be exalted, as in 57:5, 11; 108:5) expresses communal praise and joy in God’s greatness and power.

title: Psalms 22:1–2
content: A deep sense of alienation from God overwhelms the psalmist (see 10:1).

title: Psalms 22:1–21
content: The psalmist alternates between reflections on his present dire circumstances and memories of the Lord’s past faithfulness; he ends with a prayer for rescue.

title: Psalms 22:1–31
content: All previous laments pale in comparison with this outcry against the enemy and God’s abandonment. The psalm contains two main sections: the lament (22:1–21) and praise for redemption (22:22–31), which leads naturally to Ps 23. The apostles saw in this psalm an expression of the sufferings of Jesus Christ, who ultimately fulfilled the purpose of David’s humiliation, rejection by people, and divine abandonment (Matt 27:35, 39, 43, 46; Mark 15:34; John 19:23–24, 28; Heb 2:12).

title: Psalms 22:3
content: God, the holy King, is set apart from all his creation, but he chooses to reveal himself to Israel. • God greatly desires that his people offer praises to him.

title: Psalms 22:6–8
content: Both the Lord and people reject the psalmist. He vividly describes his anguish (22:1–2); he lives like a lowly animal.

title: Psalms 22:7
content: Everyone mocks the psalmist’s confidence in the Lord (see 3:2; Matt 27:43), which shames him (Pss 44:13–14; 74:10; 89:50; 109:25).

title: Psalms 22:9
content: The Lord took care of the psalmist before he could do anything for himself (see 71:6; 139:13).

title: Psalms 22:9–11
content: The psalmist reflects on his past relationship with God (see 22:3–5). The Lord has been his very life.

title: Psalms 22:12
content: Bashan, a region known for its herds and vegetation, produced strong bulls (68:30).

title: Psalms 22:12–18
content: The psalmist returns to expressing his anguish and suffering (see 22:1–2, 6–8). His trouble comes from human beings who act like beasts.

title: Psalms 22:14
content: The psalmist’s sense of being poured out like water expresses a meaningless, transitory existence that leaves him depleted.

title: Psalms 22:15
content: Facing adversity is as horrible as dying of thirst (see 137:6). • Jesus may have had this verse in mind when he said, “I am thirsty” (John 19:28).

title: Psalms 22:16
content: The wild pack of dogs represents fierce and unscrupulous people.

title: Psalms 22:17–18
content: I can count all my bones: The psalmist’s enemies have utterly shamed him by taking his garments. Jesus also suffered this disgrace (see Matt 27:35). • stare at me and gloat: Enemies make the psalmist the object of their scorn (see Pss 35:24, 26; 38:16; 55:3; cp. 59:10). • throw dice: Literally cast lots. The casting of lots was sometimes a way for godly people to find God’s direction (Lev 16:8; Num 27:21; Acts 1:24–26). Here, the lots are thrown simply as a game of chance. The soldiers threw dice for Jesus’ clothing after the crucifixion (Matt 27:35; Mark 15:24; Luke 23:34; John 19:24).

title: Psalms 22:19–21
content: The psalmist faces his troubles by praying for God’s rescue. Only the Lord has the strength to ward off dogs, lions, and oxen.

title: Psalms 22:20
content: The sword makes evident the lethal intent of the enemy.

title: Psalms 22:22
content: I will proclaim your name: The writer to the Hebrews ascribes these words to Jesus (Heb 2:12). • my brothers and sisters: Literally my brothers. In the New Testament quotation, the Greek translation picks up the broader meaning as “my brothers and sisters.”

title: Psalms 22:22–24
content: The psalmist praises the Lord and calls for the godly to join him. He tells of God’s goodness to the needy, including himself.

title: Psalms 22:23
content: The godly respond with awe (see 22:25).

title: Psalms 22:24
content: Unlike his response to the wicked (see 21:8–12), God cares about the needy and hears their prayers (51:17; 69:33; 102:17).

title: Psalms 22:25
content: The great assembly might include all nations (22:27; 26:12; 35:18).

title: Psalms 22:25–31
content: The psalmist vows to praise the Lord, the great King of the earth (22:27–28) who cares for the needy. God alone deserves praise.

title: Psalms 22:26
content: God knows his people’s needs and addresses them (63:5; 81:16; 103:5; 107:9; 132:15; 145:16; 147:14).

title: Psalms 22:27
content: families of the nations: All clans and tribes of humanity (see Gen 12:3; Rev 5:9–10) will live in submission to the Lord (Ps 96:1–3; see Pss 2, 72; Isa 2:2–4; 1 Cor 15:25–27).

title: Psalms 22:28
content: The universal kingdom belongs to God alone (Obad 1:21).

title: Psalms 22:29
content: The Lord invites all people, rich and poor (22:26), to the banquet as long as they worship him.

title: Psalms 22:30
content: Future generations will join those from the past who praised the Lord (22:3–5). The descendants of the godly will receive blessings (22:30–31), unlike the offspring of the wicked (21:10).

title: Psalms 22:31
content: The Lord’s acts of redemption (40:9; 50:6; 71:15, 16, 24; 97:6) demonstrate that he is righteous (see 4:1). His righteousness provides the character required for rule, judicial decisions, and relationships. This virtue leads to harmony and order (see 50:6).

title: Psalms 23:1
content: The Lord promises to take care of his children (34:9–10; Isa 51:14). He demonstrated this ability to Israel in the wilderness (Deut 2:7) and in the Promised Land (Deut 8:9).

title: Psalms 23:1–3
content: People in the ancient Near East commonly viewed their rulers as shepherds.

title: Psalms 23:1–6
content: This psalm of trust and confidence in the Lord has been a favorite of God’s people for generations. It expresses assurance of God’s presence in the midst of adversity. It evokes images of the Good Shepherd (23:1–3; see Ezek 34:12; John 10:11) and of the messianic banquet (Ps 23:5–6; see Isa 25:6; Rev 19:9).

title: Psalms 23:1–28.9
content: These psalms develop the importance of integrity (25:4–7, 12–14, 21; 26:6, 11; 27:7–12), God’s shepherding care (23:1; 28:9), God’s guidance (23:2–3; 25:5; 27:11), God’s goodness (23:6; 25:7–8; 27:13), and living in his house (23:6; 26:8; 27:4, 8).

title: Psalms 23:2
content: Sheep rest after they have eaten their fill (Zeph 3:13; see Isa 11:7; cp. Isa 13:20; 27:10). • The Lord leads the sheep for their own benefit (see Ps 5:8). • Sheep only drink from still water, so the shepherd seeks out peaceful streams for his flock.

title: Psalms 23:3
content: Cp. 19:7; the Lord’s word renews my strength. • The Lord guides by rescuing his people from evil (23:4–5; see 31:3), bringing them back to himself (5:8; 61:2), caring (48:14; 139:10), ruling (67:4), counseling (73:24), protecting (78:53; 107:30; 143:11), and instructing them in wisdom (27:11; see Prov 4:11). • The Lord’s name guarantees the relationship; he guards his reputation against any accusation of his abandoning his people or allowing them to sin (see Pss 25:11; 31:3; 106:8; 143:11).

title: Psalms 23:4
content: The shepherd used his rod and staff to fend off danger.

title: Psalms 23:5
content: A feast demonstrates the Lord’s care and mercy toward his people (see 22:26, 29). Although enemies can watch, they cannot trouble the guests. • The ritual of anointing the head with oil showed guests honor (92:9–11), hospitality, and refreshment (104:15; 133:2).

title: Psalms 23:6
content: The Lord expresses his unfailing love through the goodness of his presence and other benefits that he alone provides (69:16; 86:17; 109:21; see 18:6; 61:4). He actively bestows care that is greater than the temporary trials imposed by enemies (7:1).

title: Psalms 24:1
content: The Lord created and now rules the earth and everything in it (see 1 Cor 10:25–26). He sees all its people (Ps 33:14), regardless of their status (49:1–2).

title: Psalms 24:1–2
content: The kingdom belongs to the Creator, the Great King (cp. 22:27).

title: Psalms 24:1–10
content: The shepherd of Ps 23, who is also the King of the whole world, takes possession of Zion.

title: Psalms 24:2
content: God created everything in an orderly and stable manner (see 89:11; 102:25; 104:5).

title: Psalms 24:3
content: These questions invite readers to look away from their problems with the wicked and to examine themselves (see 15:1). • God’s holy place is the holy mountain, a reference both to Jerusalem and to heaven.

title: Psalms 24:3–6
content: The citizens of the King’s realm include all who seek him. The Lord invites them to enter his presence.

title: Psalms 24:4
content: Those with pure hands have not shed blood or injured relationships between people (see 9:12; 15:2–5). • Those with pure hearts commit themselves fully to the Lord, as evidenced in strength of character, transparency, and selflessness (51:10; 73:1; see Matt 5:8).

title: Psalms 24:10
content: The Lord of Heaven’s Armies reigns from his home, the Temple in Jerusalem (84:3–5). He excludes sin and sinners (24:3–6) but protects all who dwell in Zion.

title: Psalms 25:1
content: The psalmist commits himself to the Lord instead of to idols (see 24:3–4).

title: Psalms 25:1–3
content: The psalmist expresses confidence that the godly will be vindicated and his enemies will not succeed (see 25:15–22).

title: Psalms 25:1–22
content: This individual lament includes instruction in wisdom and a community lament; it begins and ends with an affirmation of trust in the Lord (25:1–3, 15–22). The psalmist prays for guidance (25:4–7) and encourages the godly to practice a lifestyle of wisdom (25:12–14). In addition to the enemies who trouble him, the psalmist confesses his sins (25:7, 11, 18) as part of his anguish. Trust develops with understanding God’s character: He is compassionate, faithful, and good (25:8–10).

title: Psalms 25:2
content: Enemies would rejoice by singing a victory song.

title: Psalms 25:4–6
content: The right path, the path of wisdom (see 5:8), means being open to instruction that leads to life (27:11; 43:3; 73:24; 119:12).

title: Psalms 25:4–7
content: In this prayer for guidance, compassion, and forgiveness, the psalmist turns to the Lord for instruction in wisdom. He confesses his past failures and acknowledges that his hope lies with his merciful Savior.

title: Psalms 25:5
content: Biblical hope does not mean wishing for an event to turn out favorably. Hope trusts the Lord’s will and gives the courage to face disappointments (33:22; 130:5).

title: Psalms 25:6
content: compassion: See also 51:1; 57:1; 103:8.

title: Psalms 25:8–10
content: The Lord keeps his people close to himself.

title: Psalms 25:11
content: The psalmist again asks forgiveness for his many sins (25:7; 32:1–5). The sins of Israel’s kings demonstrated the weaknesses inherent in David’s dynasty and the reasons for its failure in Old Testament Israel (see Ps 89).

title: Psalms 25:12–15
content: Those who fear the Lord will receive further instruction and experience God’s presence (25:14) and blessing (25:13).

title: Psalms 25:13
content: prosperity: See 23:6. • inherit the land: Unlike the wicked, who will perish (1:6), the godly have a secure future. In the end, God will bless them, and their blessings will endure (see 37:9, 11, 22, 29, 34; Isa 57:13; Matt 5:5).

title: Psalms 25:15
content: the traps of my enemies: See 5:9–10; 31:4; 140:5; Prov 3:26.

title: Psalms 25:15–22
content: The psalmist expresses confidence in the Lord, commits to a life of integrity, and prays for rescue.

title: Psalms 25:17–18
content: The psalmist can find no relief (see 4:1; 13:1–2) as his problems go from bad to worse. He associates his anguish with sin, but he does not elaborate on the nature of his sin (see 25:7, 11).

title: Psalms 25:19–20
content: Knowing that the Lord hates violent people (see 11:5), the psalmist pleads with God to deal with these enemies.

title: Psalms 25:21
content: Just as it opened, the psalm closes with a commitment of trust and hope (see 9:18; 25:5).

title: Psalms 26:1–3
content: The psalmist opens himself to divine examination of his life, especially in the areas of his character and devotion.

title: Psalms 26:1–12
content: In this individual lament, the psalmist prays for redemption on the basis of his own innocence and the Lord’s justice.

title: Psalms 26:3
content: For God’s truth to become part of one’s character requires a habitual commitment.

title: Psalms 26:4–5
content: Because of his devotion to the Lord (26:1–3), the psalmist dissociates himself from evil people (see 1:1).

title: Psalms 26:6
content: Ritual purity required the worshiper to wash their hands, symbolic of separation from evil and evildoers (see 73:13). • The altar symbolizes God’s presence (43:4).

title: Psalms 26:6–8
content: The psalmist demonstrates his loyalty to the Lord through pious rituals, praise, and acknowledgment of the Lord’s presence in the Temple.

title: Psalms 26:8
content: The sanctuary symbolized the manifest presence of the Lord (see 18:6).

title: Psalms 26:9
content: Don’t let me suffer: The end of the godly cannot be the same as that of the wicked.

title: Psalms 26:12
content: The psalmist’s footing on solid ground represents salvation (cp. 143:10). • publicly: Or in the great assembly at the Temple (26:6–8; 22:25).

title: Psalms 27:1
content: Light expresses the Lord’s goodness (27:13; see 4:6; 23:6; 31:19; 38:10; 43:3; 56:13).

title: Psalms 27:1–3
content: The psalmist acknowledges the Lord at the center of his life (27:1). Because of God’s presence, he engages his adversaries with confidence. They cannot intimidate him or penetrate his inner security.

title: Psalms 27:1–14
content: This psalm mixes two genres—a psalm of confidence (27:1–6) and an individual lament (27:7–14)—held together by the theme of longing for the Lord’s presence. The psalmist focuses on the Lord; his circumstances are secondary. The strength of the psalmist’s faith is expressed in his openness to the Lord’s instruction, timing, and priorities.

title: Psalms 27:2
content: The psalmist’s enemies seek to devour him by living at his expense (see study note on 14:4).

title: Psalms 27:3
content: remain confident: See 25:2; 26:1.

title: Psalms 27:4–6
content: Searching for and enjoying the Lord’s presence provides the psalmist’s foundation for confidence and security. He lives in the assurance of God’s protection and looks forward to offering sacrifices of thanksgiving and praise (see 18:6).

title: Psalms 27:5
content: sanctuary (or tabernacle): This early shrine was the Israelites’ place of worship before the Temple was constructed.

title: Psalms 27:6
content: hold my head high: A sign of victory. • The granting of the request of 27:4 prompts sacrifices with shouts of joy.

title: Psalms 27:7–8
content: Unlike the wicked (10:4), who only want a temporary advantage (78:34–36), the godly search for the Lord as a thirsty person searches for water in the desert (63:1; 105:4; 119:2, 10; Matt 6:33). They act wisely (Ps 34:10, 14) while waiting for the Lord to resolve their crisis (34:4; 69:6; 77:2; 119:58).

title: Psalms 27:7–12
content: The psalmist requests the Lord’s mercy, presence, and instruction. God is the psalmist’s greatest good; enemies and other circumstances are peripheral.

title: Psalms 27:13–14
content: The psalmist expresses confidence and hope in the Lord’s presence. To live in faith means to wait patiently in recognition of the Lord’s goodness. Such a life is not always pleasant for the godly (42:2–3; 43:5), but their future is secure (37:9; 130:7; see 9:18).

title: Psalms 28:1
content: if you are silent: The psalmist appeals to the Lord to take action (35:22; 50:3; 83:1; 109:1).

title: Psalms 28:1–2
content: The psalmist urges the Lord to listen; his urgency flows out of the tension between his deep relationship with the Lord and the adversity he faces.

title: Psalms 28:1–9
content: In this individual lament, the psalmist pleads for justice and mercy. He expresses confidence in the Lord’s strength and faithfulness, and he intercedes for the Lord’s people.

title: Psalms 28:2
content: It was common to lift up one’s hands in a gesture of devoted prayer (63:4; 134:2).

title: Psalms 28:3–5
content: The psalmist curses his enemies, asking God for retribution and vindication.

title: Psalms 28:5
content: The wicked do not acknowledge the difference between the sacred and the common, so they have no respect for the Lord’s creation, redemption, or revelation.

title: Psalms 28:6–8
content: The psalmist anticipates rescue because of his confidence in the Lord’s justice.

title: Psalms 28:7
content: my strength and shield: The Lord protects the psalmist (see 59:9, 17).

title: Psalms 28:9
content: The poem closes with intercession for the Lord’s people. • Bless Israel, your special possession: See 29:11; 133:3.

title: Psalms 29:1–2
content: The psalmist issues a call to honor the Lord for his power (cp. 96:7–8). • you heavenly beings: Angels or deities who, some believed, held special powers. The psalmist did not believe in other deities but called on people who thought they were real to look to the Lord as the only God.

title: Psalms 29:1–11
content: This nature hymn in praise of the Creator declares that the Lord holds all power over nature. God uses the same unsurpassed strength to care for his people.

title: Psalms 29:3–9
content: The word translated voice (Hebrew qol) can also mean “noise” (1 Kgs 1:45) or “thunder” (Joel 3:16). The Lord’s voice is awe-inspiring, and it dominates whatever rumblings people might attribute to other deities.

title: Psalms 29:5
content: The cedars of Lebanon were known for their size and quality (see Isa 2:13).

title: Psalms 29:6
content: Lebanon’s mountains and Hermon are high mountains to the north of Israel. • The Lord can cause even immense mountains to shake at his command (see 114:4).

title: Psalms 29:8
content: The wilderness of Kadesh was located south of Judah. God’s voice can be heard throughout the land, from the north (29:6) to the south.

title: Psalms 29:10
content: The image of powerful floodwaters connects with the Genesis flood (Gen 6:17). The Lord reigns as king over the whole created order; no one contests his kingdom.

title: Psalms 29:11
content: The ruler of nature blesses his people with peace (see 28:8–9; 37:11; 133:3).

title: Psalms 30:1
content: I will exalt you is a call to lift up the Lord’s name in praise and thanksgiving (34:3; 81:1; 99:5, 9; 107:32; 118:28; 145:1; see Exod 15:1; Isa 25:1). • you rescued me: God pulled the psalmist from death (Ps 30:3). • In his justice and care, God refused to let the psalmist’s enemies triumph (see 26:9; 27:12; 28:3; 31:8).

title: Psalms 30:1–3
content: The psalmist praises God for his triumph over adversity, which he likens to salvation from the grave.

title: Psalms 30:1–12
content: This individual thanksgiving psalm opens in praise to the Lord for his salvation (30:1–3), then contrasts God’s favor with his anger (30:4–7), and ends with a transformation from mourning to dancing (30:8–12).

title: Psalms 30:title
content: wrote this psalm in advance for the dedication of the Temple, making his own experience representative of the nation’s.

title: Psalms 30:4
content: The godly should celebrate the Lord’s acts of rescue with song and praise (33:21; 97:12; 103:1; 105:3; 145:21).

title: Psalms 30:6–7
content: Nothing can stop me now! The psalmist confesses his presumptuous attitude (cp. 32:3–4). • secure as a mountain: In the psalms, this phrase creates a powerful image of stability and of God’s control (see 11:1; 18:7; 36:6; 46:2; 72:3; 76:4; 83:14; 97:5; 114:4, 6; 125:2). • I was shattered: The absence of God’s favor destroys the security of the proud (cp. 104:27–30).

title: Psalms 30:8–12
content: The psalmist faced death (also in 30:1–3)—perhaps literally, perhaps figuratively. But when he turned to the Lord, the Lord rescued him and turned his mourning into joyful dancing. Only God’s favor can permanently and powerfully overcome human failure and the depths of despair.

title: Psalms 31:1–5
content: The Lord offers refuge to anyone who comes to him for protection. The psalmist trusts in and submits to the Lord. See also 71:1–3.

title: Psalms 31:1–24
content: The psalmist encourages the godly to find refuge in the Lord and wait for his salvation. Despite having had a death-like experience, he testifies to the Lord’s faithfulness. This psalm foreshadows the suffering of Jesus (Luke 23:46).

title: Psalms 31:2
content: The psalmist issues an urgent call for the Lord to pay attention to his desperate situation (71:2; 88:2; 102:2).

title: Psalms 31:5
content: I entrust my spirit into your hand: Whether he lives or dies, the psalmist will trust his Lord. Jesus uttered these words on the cross just before he died (Luke 23:46).

title: Psalms 31:6–8
content: Trust in the Lord requires confidence that he has our best interests at heart.

title: Psalms 31:8
content: A safe place literally means a broad place, in contrast to a “narrow” or constricted place of distress (see 18:19).

title: Psalms 31:9–13
content: In this prayer for mercy, the psalmist wedges a description of the intensity of suffering and the pain of rejection between two affirmations of trust (31:6, 14).

title: Psalms 31:10
content: wasting away from within: This is a powerful description of how despair takes a toll on our physical well-being.

title: Psalms 31:14–18
content: Hope does not confide in frail and changeable human beings but only in the Lord. The sufferer entrusts himself to God while waiting for the Lord’s justice.

title: Psalms 31:15
content: My future is in your hands: To relinquish control of timing is one way to express submission.

title: Psalms 31:17
content: The psalmist, who did not deserve to be disgraced, invokes the principle of retribution (see study note on 1:6; see also “Prayers for Vengeance” Theme Note).

title: Psalms 31:19–20
content: Since the godly are under the Lord’s protection and shelter, evil has no power over them.

title: Psalms 31:19–24
content: The psalmist thanks the Lord for answering his prayer (31:1–18) and rescuing him.

title: Psalms 31:21–22
content: Praise the Lord: The psalmist expresses his joy at the experience of God’s goodness and love. Throughout his ordeal, the Lord has cared for him.

title: Psalms 31:23–24
content: Out of his own pain and renewed awareness of the Lord’s goodness, the psalmist turns to others who suffer. He holds out the promise of God’s loving care for those who persevere in hoping for the Lord.

title: Psalms 32:1–2
content: The Lord’s forgiveness restores people to fellowship with him, clears them of guilt, and gives them great joy. Paul quoted this text when explaining justification by faith alone (Rom 4:4–8).

title: Psalms 32:1–11
content: This wisdom psalm of confession and thanksgiving encourages and exhorts the godly to learn from the psalmist’s experience of sin, denial, confession, and forgiveness. This psalm was one of the seven psalms of penitence used in the early church (also Pss 6, 38, 51, 102, 130, 143).

title: Psalms 32:3–5
content: The psalmist acknowledges his own sin (see 19:12–13; 25:7, 11, 15–22) and his resistance to confessing sin. The Lord pressed him hard until he confessed his guilt.

title: Psalms 32:4
content: The psalmist attributes his suffering directly to the Lord’s hand of discipline (cp. 38:2; 39:10).

title: Psalms 32:5
content: God has forgiven the guilt and rebellion of 32:1. The Lord’s nature is to reconcile and forgive (78:38; 85:2; 130:4), but he requires confession and repentance.

title: Psalms 32:6
content: The godly will learn from the psalmist’s experience to pray for forgiveness before it is too late.

title: Psalms 32:7
content: The Lord promises to be his people’s hiding place (31:20). Instead of being overwhelmed by terror (31:13), the psalmist is surrounded by songs of victory.

title: Psalms 32:8
content: God interrupts the psalmist’s teaching with a message that invites the godly to receive the Lord’s wisdom (see 5:8; 23:3; 25:4–6).

title: Psalms 32:9
content: The senseless person is not wise. Rejecting the Lord’s counsel ruins life and makes one like an animal (see Isa 1:3; Jas 3:3).

title: Psalms 32:10
content: Difficulties common to all of life will ensnare the wicked, whereas the Lord promises to protect the godly with his care.

title: Psalms 33:1–3
content: The psalmist exhorts the godly to praise the Lord with melodies, with a new song, and with skillfully-played music.

title: Psalms 33:1–22
content: This hymn of creation (see also Pss 8, 19, 104, 145) might be a continuation of Ps 32. It exhorts readers to praise God (33:1–3), to recognize the power of his word in creation (33:4–7), and to fear the Creator (33:8–11). It offers hope to forgiven sinners (Ps 32) that they can live a new life in the fear of the Lord and under divine protection.

title: Psalms 33:4–7
content: God’s word displays his character and his power.

title: Psalms 33:7
content: The nations surrounding Israel thought that the sea had divine power, but it is under God’s control, within boundaries that he set (see 104:8–10).

title: Psalms 33:8
content: The power of the Lord extends to all the nations (see 2; 96:1–3).

title: Psalms 33:8–11
content: Fear of the Lord begins with awe for God and for his powerful word. His word created everything and continues to order and sustain creation. He frustrates the plans of people who oppose his will.

title: Psalms 33:10
content: The plans and schemes of the mighty will not prevail, except by God’s will (see Isa 8:9–10).

title: Psalms 33:11
content: God’s word still orders creation and will do so forever. • God’s intentions are marvelous (40:5; 92:5).

title: Psalms 33:12
content: People who fear God are chosen as his inheritance (see 33:13–19); this excludes rebellious people (78:62).

title: Psalms 33:13–19
content: From the heavens, the Lord searches out and cares for anyone who fears him (see 14:2–3).

title: Psalms 33:16–17
content: army . . . great strength . . . warhorse: Even military might is under God’s control (see 33:10–11; Eccl 9:11).

title: Psalms 33:18
content: God watches over all who live by his counsel (32:8). He protects, rescues, and remains close to them (34:15–22).

title: Psalms 33:20–22
content: The godly respond to this magnificent vision of God’s power in creation and in the affairs of the world with an affirmation of trust, commitment, joy, and hope as they pray and wait for God’s rescue.

title: Psalms 33:22
content: Using a play on words, the psalmist contrasts his people’s sure hope (Hebrew yakhal) in the Lord with the supposed strength (33:17; Hebrew khayil) of the horses of the wicked.

title: Psalms 34:1
content: is another name for Achish (see 1 Sam 21:10–15). The body of the psalm makes no explicit connection to this event.

title: Psalms 34:1–3
content: The psalmist exhorts the helpless to join him in praise.

title: Psalms 34:1–22
content: This wisdom psalm includes a thanksgiving hymn (34:1–7) that celebrates the Lord’s care for and protection of godly sufferers. It also includes an invitation to wisdom (34:8–14) and an exposition of wisdom concerning the Lord’s care for the needy and the suffering of the wicked (34:15–22).

title: Psalms 34:5–6
content: The psalmist narrates his experiences of answered prayer.

title: Psalms 34:7
content: The angel of the Lord represented the Lord’s presence during the wilderness journey. He protected Israel from the forces of Egypt (Exod 14:19–20), and he will guard all the godly (Ps 91:11).

title: Psalms 34:8–14
content: The godly encourage everyone to seek wisdom, to fear the Lord, and to place themselves under the protection of the Lord’s angel.

title: Psalms 34:9–10
content: Fear of the Lord includes reverence and respect, and it motivates a life of wisdom (see Prov 1:7; 9:10).

title: Psalms 34:11
content: Anyone who listens, even children, can become wise followers of God.

title: Psalms 34:11–13
content: Wisdom contains three components: fearing the Lord (34:11), doing good (34:14), and rejecting evil (34:13).

title: Psalms 34:12–16
content: Peter quotes this passage in his instructions for peaceful living (1 Pet 3:10–12).

title: Psalms 34:13
content: Godly people control their words; speaking evil and telling lies are foolish (see 10:7; cp. 17:1).

title: Psalms 34:14
content: The way of peace leads to harmony and order, whereas evil destroys them (see 37:11).

title: Psalms 34:15–16
content: The Lord distinguishes between wise and foolish people; he shows his concern for the wise by rescuing them from trouble (34:15, 17–20), but he destroys the foolish (34:16, 21).

title: Psalms 34:18
content: Those who are brokenhearted possess a spirit of deep contrition and dependence on the Lord. God accepts this spirit as a proper sacrifice (51:17). The wicked hate the brokenhearted (109:16), but the Lord heals them (147:3; see Isa 57:15; 61:1).

title: Psalms 34:19–22
content: The godly might suffer, but the Lord will reward them in the end. Similarly, the wicked might prosper for a time, but ultimately they will perish (1:6; 34:15–16).

title: Psalms 34:20
content: Bones represent a person’s entire being (see 6:2). • not one of them is broken: John applied this statement to Jesus at the crucifixion (John 19:36).

title: Psalms 35:1–28
content: In this lament, the Lord’s troubled servant calls for God to see his circumstances and vindicate him.

title: Psalms 35:4–10
content: The psalmist longs for the Lord’s salvation. The language seems vindictive, but it arises from a desire for justice and for the Lord to care for the needy and oppressed.

title: Psalms 35:6
content: A path that is dark and slippery suggests instability and untimely doom under the Lord’s judgment (see 69:23; 73:18; 82:5; 107:10; 143:3). • The angel of the Lord is an agent of judgment as well as salvation.

title: Psalms 35:10
content: Nothing in the universe can compare with the Lord (see 86:8; 89:6, 8; Isa 40:18, 25).

title: Psalms 35:11
content: Malicious witnesses want nothing but violence (see 11:4–6; 54:3).

title: Psalms 35:11–18
content: The psalmist presents the Lord with the reasons for his suffering. Evil has many faces. He is tired and worn out, and he knows that only the Lord can help him.

title: Psalms 35:16
content: The psalmist’s attackers snarl to express their bitter envy.

title: Psalms 35:19
content: John applied this claim of innocence (see also 69:4) to Jesus (John 15:25).

title: Psalms 35:19–25
content: In this prayer for vindication, the psalmist’s crisis looms so large that a resolution must be found in the Lord.
