The psalmist has taken the high road, believing that vengeance belongs to the Lord. God’s patience hardens the hearts of the wicked and gives them reasons to justify their evil lifestyle.

title: Psalms 35:21
content: Aha! . . . Look: Both words translate the same expression of glee (Hebrew he’akh).

title: Psalms 35:26–28
content: The psalmist calls on the Lord to judge the wicked and to rescue the godly and bring them joy.

title: Psalms 36:1
content: no fear of God: Paul includes this phrase in his description of the depravity of all people (Rom 3:18).

title: Psalms 36:1–4
content: Fools despise what is wise and good as they pursue evil.

title: Psalms 36:1–12
content: This lament contrasts the world of folly devised by the wicked with the world of wisdom created and sustained by the Lord. The wicked care only about themselves, whereas the Lord cares for all of creation. He will intervene to bring about justice in his world. The righteous will enjoy his protection, but the wicked will perish.

title: Psalms 36:5–6
content: God’s all-encompassing goodness surpasses that of the created order. God graciously meets his people’s practical needs.

title: Psalms 36:5–9
content: As the source of wisdom, the Lord is reliable and incomparable. His faithful care extends to all parts of the created order.

title: Psalms 36:6–9
content: All creatures live by God’s grace (1 Tim 4:10).

title: Psalms 36:7–8
content: God invites all humanity to the banquet in his house (cp. Prov 9:1–6).

title: Psalms 36:9
content: Light represents salvation and celebration (18:25–29; 27:1; cp. 35:6).

title: Psalms 36:10–11
content: Since God’s wisdom extends to all of creation, it protects the godly.

title: Psalms 36:12
content: The psalmist remains confident that the disorder caused by the wicked (36:1–4) will end when they meet their demise.

title: Psalms 37:1
content: envy: The jealous desire to have what others enjoy leads to further sin (73:3; Prov 3:31; Jas 1:14–15; 4:1–2).

title: Psalms 37:1–9
content: The wise respond to evil by trusting in the Lord. Trust includes five dimensions: (1) renouncing irritability and envy (37:1–2); (2) delighting in the Lord (37:3–4); (3) submitting to the Lord (37:5–6); (4) practicing patience in hope (37:7); and (5) avoiding anger (37:8–9).

title: Psalms 37:1–40
content: This psalm elaborates on the problems posed in Ps 36: How should the godly respond to the reality of evil? When will the Lord bring justice? Why does he permit the wicked to destroy his created order? Psalm 37 offers clear responses that reduce the tensions of life (37:1–9, 34) and promise that the meek will have a future (37:10–11, 39–40). The alternating contrast between the godly and the wicked emphasizes the futility of folly (37:12–24, 27–33). The personal observations of the psalmist add a human touch (37:25–26, 35–38). He encourages viewing the inheritance of the land from a long-range perspective: The earth belongs to the Lord, who will give it to those he blesses—the lowly and godly who trust in him, put their hope in him, and follow him (see 37:9, 11, 22, 29, 34; see also Isa 57:13; Matt 5:5).

title: Psalms 37:2
content: Finite existence is part of the human condition (see 90:5–6; 92:7; 102:4, 11; 103:15; 129:6; Isa 40:7–8).

title: Psalms 37:3
content: To do good means cultivating a devotion to wisdom (see 34:14; Prov 3:5–7).

title: Psalms 37:3–4
content: The antidote to irritability and envy (37:1) is trust in the Lord.

title: Psalms 37:4
content: To take delight in the Lord means aligning with the Lord’s way in order to enjoy him.

title: Psalms 37:6
content: Justice occurs when the Lord’s will triumphs and the godly experience his rescue (Isa 45:8; 51:5–6; 58:8, 10–11).

title: Psalms 37:7
content: Be still: We should let the Lord be God rather than taking matters into our own hands.

title: Psalms 37:8
content: Irritability and anger quickly corrode character.

title: Psalms 37:9–11
content: The wicked will not possess the land; those who trust in the Lord will. The Lord promises an inheritance because he is committed to caring for his people.

title: Psalms 37:11
content: The Lord is the author of peace (85:10)—he brings peace to a chaotic world (29:11; 37:11; 85:8; 147:14). His wisdom guides the lowly into the way of peace (119:165; Matt 5:5).

title: Psalms 37:12–13
content: The wicked snarl to express their bitter envy. They plot to bring an end to the godly, but the Lord derides them because they cannot succeed (2:4).

title: Psalms 37:12–17
content: The wicked seek to destroy the Lord’s order, but he defeats them.

title: Psalms 37:14–15
content: The weapons of the wicked will turn against them (cp. 7:12–13).

title: Psalms 37:16
content: Being wise with modest means is better than having prosperity and power and being wicked (Prov 15:16; 16:8, 19; 17:1; 28:6).

title: Psalms 37:18–20
content: The Lord cares for the blameless in this life and for eternity, but the wicked will perish.

title: Psalms 37:20
content: Smoke depicts the temporary nature of life (68:2; 102:3).

title: Psalms 37:21
content: To borrow and never repay is a behavior of a crooked lifestyle. • Generous givers freely share what they freely receive from the Lord (see 111:5; 112:5).

title: Psalms 37:23–24
content: The rectitude and strength of a godly person’s life comes from the Lord (see Prov 4:12; 14:15; 16:9; 20:24).

title: Psalms 37:25–26
content: The Lord does not abandon his children or their descendants.

title: Psalms 37:27–33
content: The godly are wise; they do good and reject evil. The Lord cares for them, protecting them and ensuring that they receive their rightful portion of the land as their inheritance. The wicked might try to ambush the godly, but they will not succeed.

title: Psalms 37:30
content: The godly base their counsel on the Lord’s wisdom.

title: Psalms 37:31
content: They have made God’s law their own: The godly internalize God’s wisdom and instructions (see 119:11; Jer 24:7; 31:31–34).

title: Psalms 37:35–36
content: The wicked might appear to be flourishing like a tree (cp. 52:8; 92:12–13), but they eventually die and are forgotten (37:2).

title: Psalms 37:39–40
content: The Lord provides strength for his people.

title: Psalms 38:1
content: The meaning of this phrase is uncertain (also in 70:title).

title: Psalms 38:1–4
content: The psalmist’s sins had triggered the Lord’s anger and rage, resulting in the arrows and blows of discipline and rebuke; as a result, his whole body is sick.

title: Psalms 38:1–17
content: These verses form a prelude to the psalmist’s confession (38:18) and describe his woeful condition.

title: Psalms 38:1–22
content: This psalm is a lament and prayer for healing. The psalmist’s suffering is associated with his unconfessed sin. He confesses his sin and entrusts his case to the Lord.

title: Psalms 38:3
content: Sin can lead to sickness and even death (1 Cor 11:30). Whether the psalmist actually felt physically ill or his sickness was a metaphor for emotional turmoil, he knew that it came from God and threatened his life (see Pss 32:3; 39:10).

title: Psalms 38:4
content: The psalmist’s burden results from sin (see 40:12; 41:4; cp. Gen 4:13).

title: Psalms 38:5–8
content: The severity of God’s punishment brings anguish that affects every part of the psalmist’s being.

title: Psalms 38:9–12
content: The psalmist longs for a restored relationship with God, but he feels alienated. He finds himself lost and alone as his friends disappear.

title: Psalms 38:13
content: The psalmist suffers quietly before his opponents (see Isa 53:7).

title: Psalms 38:15
content: The Lord alone will resolve the conflict (9:18; 27:14; 37:9, 34).

title: Psalms 38:17–20
content: No longer able to endure his suffering and teetering on the verge of collapse (cp. 15:5), the psalmist confesses his sin (see 32:5).

title: Psalms 38:19
content: That the psalmist’s enemies hate him without reason compounds his pain.

title: Psalms 38:22
content: Asking the Lord to act quickly in times of great need is common in the Psalter (22:19; 31:2; 40:13; 69:17; 70:1; 71:12; 79:8; 102:2; 141:1; 143:7). However, wisdom and experience teach that God’s people must often wait for him to act (27:14; 37:7; Isa 8:17; 40:31).

title: Psalms 39:1
content: was a levitical singer appointed by David along with Asaph (1 Chr 9:16; 16:38; 25:1).

title: Psalms 39:1–3
content: Suffering in silence only intensifies the psalmist’s anguish, pain, and inner turmoil.

title: Psalms 39:1–13
content: This prayer for rescue reflects the psalmist’s discouragement, which comes from having a limited perspective on his situation.

title: Psalms 39:4–5
content: how fleeting my life is: This perspective comes out of suffering (see 78:39; 89:47–48; 90:3–10). The human lifetime is but a moment to God (90:4), as temporary as a breath (see 39:11; 144:4).

title: Psalms 39:4–6
content: Because of his suffering and sin, the psalmist concludes that life is meaningless and fleeting (see Job 7:7–10; Isa 40:6–8). He had expected a wicked life to have those qualities (see Pss 37:2, 20; 103:15–16), but now whether a person is godly or not seems to be irrelevant.

title: Psalms 39:8
content: The idea that rebellion brings on suffering is a common thread in Pss 32, 38–41.

title: Psalms 39:9–11
content: The psalmist links suffering with God’s discipline, assuming that it is punishment for his sin.

title: Psalms 39:11
content: The Lord uses discipline to correct his children (38:1, 3, 7; 40:12; see Prov 3:11–12; Heb 12:5–6).

title: Psalms 39:12
content: A guest (or foreigner) had no rights of land ownership (see Lev 25:23). The patriarchs had lived as guests in Canaan (Ps 105:23).

title: Psalms 39:13
content: Unlike the psalmist’s earlier request that God stay close to him (38:21–22), his present desire for God to leave him alone echoes Job’s disposition (Job 7:17–19).

title: Psalms 40:1–5
content: The psalmist thanks the Lord for his rescue and testifies that God can be trusted.

title: Psalms 40:1–17
content: This psalm includes a thanksgiving song (40:1–10) followed by a lament (40:11–17). The thanksgiving song includes the reason for the thanksgiving (40:1–5), an affirmation of commitment (40:6–8), and a public testimony of God’s character (40:7–10). The lament concerns the psalmist’s troubles because of his sins (40:11–12) and is followed by two prayers for vindication (40:13–15, 17).

title: Psalms 40:6
content: The Lord delights in the attitude and character of the person making an offering more than in the offering itself. • Now that you have made me listen, I finally understand: Greek text reads You have given me a body. In Heb 10:5–7, the writer quotes from the Greek version of Ps 40:6–8. He casts the words as something Jesus said as he left heaven and came into the world.

title: Psalms 40:7
content: As is written about me in the Scriptures: Moses had recorded God’s requirements for Israel’s kings in Deut 17:14–15.

title: Psalms 40:11
content: The psalmist prays that the Lord will be true to his character when answering this plea for mercy.

title: Psalms 40:12–17
content: The psalmist is troubled by both his adversities and his own sins and prays for rescue. • This passage is repeated almost verbatim as Ps 70.

title: Psalms 41:1
content: The poor who suffer hardship have special protection under God’s law (Lev 14:21; 19:10); they receive God’s justice and godly rule (Pss 72:13; 82:3–4). The word translated poor is often a synonym for the godly (113:7; see Zeph 3:12).

title: Psalms 41:1–13
content: In this wisdom psalm, the psalmist prays for healing (41:4, 10), laments his distress (41:5–9), and expresses confidence in the Lord’s blessing (41:1–3, 11–12).

title: Psalms 41:3
content: when they are sick: This illness might be physical or spiritual (see 6:2; Ps 38).

title: Psalms 41:4
content: The psalmist applies the blessing to himself (41:12). Apparently he has taken care of the poor (41:1), but he has sinned against the Lord in other ways. Out of his pain, he cries for healing while confessing his sin. The Lord alone can grant the restoration that brings true joy (30:2; 107:20–21).

title: Psalms 41:5
content: How soon will he die? The psalmist’s opponents regard his suffering as a divine judgment (cp. 1:6).

title: Psalms 41:5–9
content: The psalmist’s enemies disguise themselves as friends, while his friends openly become his enemies.

title: Psalms 41:9
content: the one who shared my food: Eating together was a sign of unity (Acts 2:42). Refusing to eat with someone indicated hostility (1 Cor 5:11). Jesus experienced the same kind of betrayal (John 13:1, 18).

title: Psalms 41:11–12
content: The psalmist knows that the Lord has forgiven him and will bless him.

title: Psalms 41:13
content: This doxology closes Book One (Pss 1–41). Cp. 106:48.

title: Psalms 42:1
content: were members of a Levitical choir appointed by David to serve as Temple singers (see 1 Chr 6:22–38; 9:19–34; 2 Chr 20:19). Their ancestor Korah was the apostate who had rebelled against Moses and whom the earth swallowed up (Exod 6:24; Num 16).

title: Psalms 42:1–4
content: The psalmist’s longing for God comes from being geographically distant from the Temple as he remembers the past. • The verb translated longs is found only here and in Joel 1:20 (“cry out”); in both cases it refers to extreme thirst in a waterless desert (see Pss 63:1; 143:6; see also 84:2).

title: Psalms 42:1–43.5
content: These psalms, like Pss 9 and 10, form a unit comprising a lament with a bittersweet refrain of hope (42:5, 11; 43:5). In many Hebrew manuscripts these two psalms are combined as one. The historical context is uncertain; these psalms might be the voice of God’s people in exile, confessing their loyalty to God as he punishes them for their prevailing apostasy. The psalmist longs for fellowship with God such as he enjoyed in Jerusalem (42:4); his memories only make him more discouraged. As the psalmist cries out to God, he recalls God’s love and faithfulness (42:8), which moves him to plead for vindication (43:1–4).

title: Psalms 42:3
content: Having tears for food speaks of great grief (80:5; 102:9; see 6:6; 56:8; 119:136; 126:5). • The wicked try to hold God to their timetable and deny his power to intervene.

title: Psalms 42:4
content: The psalmist recalls leading a great procession as a member of the Levitical choir, possibly during the high holy days.

title: Psalms 42:5
content: The psalmist feels depressed, but it does not incapacitate him. He remembers that the living God is his Savior. This verse is repeated in 42:11 and 43:5.

title: Psalms 42:5–6
content: The psalmist encourages himself with questions and answers.

title: Psalms 42:6
content: Mount Hermon is a high mountain range northeast of Israel. The source of the Jordan is by Dan at the foot of Mount Hermon. • Mount Mizar might be a peak in the Mount Hermon range.

title: Psalms 42:7
content: The raging seas, waves, and surging tides conjure images of God’s wrath (see 88:7).

title: Psalms 42:8
content: The psalmist sees rays of hope. A life oriented to God includes songs of joy and praying for justice and vindication (42:9–10; 43:1–4).

title: Psalms 42:9–10
content: The psalmist brings his many doubts, discouragements, and questions directly to God.

title: Psalms 43:1–4
content: The psalmist turns to the Lord for rescue from his troubles, for guidance, for restoration, and for vindication.

title: Psalms 43:2
content: tossed me aside: Other psalms similarly ask whether God has rejected his people (44:9, 23; 60:1, 10; 74:1; 77:7; 88:14; 89:38; 108:11).

title: Psalms 43:3
content: In this prayer for God’s redemption, light and truth are viewed as guides (see 18:25–29; 27:1; 85:10–13; 89:14–18; see also 119:105; John 3:19; Eph 5:8; 1 Thes 5:5–7). • The Temple on the mountain in Jerusalem symbolized God’s holy presence among his people (Pss 15:1; 43:3; 99:5, 9; 132:7).

title: Psalms 43:5
content: This verse is repeated in 42:5, 11.

title: Psalms 44:1
content: we have heard . . . of all you did: The story of redemption encompasses the story of God’s favor and power in his past acts of rescue (see 78:1–4; see also Pss 105–106).

title: Psalms 44:1–26
content: This national lament after defeat in battle continues the tone of the previous two psalms, including reflecting on an unspecified moment in Israel’s history and calling on God for salvation. The people recite God’s past acts of rescue (44:1–3), acknowledge God’s power to save (44:4–8), describe their humiliation in exile (44:9–16), claim their innocence and lament the injustice of their current situation (44:17–22), and cry for vindication (44:23–26).

title: Psalms 44:2
content: God drove out the pagan nations during the conquests recorded in Joshua.

title: Psalms 44:3
content: Though the Israelites used swords and other weapons (44:6), they would have lost their battles without the light of the Lord’s favor (see 18:25–29; 27:1; 89:15).

title: Psalms 44:4–8
content: God’s people feel confident about his mighty acts; he was with them in the past, and he is their king in the present.

title: Psalms 44:9–16
content: The people have experienced defeat (44:9–12), so they understand suffering and disgrace (44:13–16).

title: Psalms 44:11
content: scattered us among the nations: This probably refers to the Exile (see 51:18–19; 89:38–51; 106:40–47; 137).

title: Psalms 44:22
content: Paul quotes this verse as a parenthetical aside in his list of things that cannot separate us from Christ’s love (Rom 8:36).

title: Psalms 44:23
content: Wake up: Biblical authors often call for God’s attention in a crisis (35:23; 44:23; 73:20; 80:2; Mark 4:38).

title: Psalms 44:23–26
content: In the end, God’s people can turn to the Lord and trust him for rescue. Their petition for God to remedy their situation is as strong as their lament about God’s rejection.

title: Psalms 45:1
content: is no longer known (see also Ps 69).

title: Psalms 45:1–17
content: This psalm celebrates a royal wedding; it might have been sung on many occasions and not just at one wedding. As God’s representative, the king carried the responsibility of dispensing justice and maintaining order in God’s world (see Ps 2).

title: Psalms 45:2
content: This general description of the king’s symbolic status anticipates his permanent legacy (45:16). That the Lord has blessed him and charged him to bear God’s attributes is symbolized by his handsome appearance and gracious words.

title: Psalms 45:3
content: Glory and majesty belong to the Lord (96:6; 111:3).

title: Psalms 45:3–5
content: The psalmist expounds on the royal splendor the king showed when fighting his enemies.

title: Psalms 45:4
content: As God’s agent of truth, humility, and justice (see 72:1–2, 4, 7), the king can carry out awe-inspiring deeds (65:5; 96:4).

title: Psalms 45:6
content: Justice characterizes God’s rule, as it should characterize the king’s administration.

title: Psalms 45:6–9
content: The king is like a god among humans; he is anointed by God, he has received a mighty throne, and he dispenses justice as he rules forever. • The writer to the Hebrews applies 45:6–7 to Jesus as he argues that the Son is greater than the angels (Heb 1:8–9).

title: Psalms 45:8
content: Fine spices mixed with oil create distinctive perfumes. • The king’s palaces were wood paneled with ivory inlays (cp. 6:4; Amos 3:15).

title: Psalms 45:9
content: Marriages often sealed diplomatic connections between kings; the women became part of the harem (see 1 Kgs 11:1–3).

title: Psalms 45:10–12
content: The bride is a representative of the king. Powerful people and nations try to gain her favor in order to get close to the king. This is a great honor, and she is encouraged to give herself fully to her new position.

title: Psalms 45:12
content: The princess of Tyre: Israel traded with Tyre, a powerful city-state. The noblest woman of the city bears a wedding gift to her counterpart, the new queen, who represents an honored kingdom.

title: Psalms 46:1
content: Hebrew according to alamoth (“maidens”; see also study note on 1 Chr 15:20). In worship, a choir or a group of instrumentalists performed this hymn.

title: Psalms 46:1–3
content: Even when faced with natural disasters, the citizens of Zion express no fear.

title: Psalms 46:1–11
content: This psalm of Zion celebrates God’s special presence in Jerusalem (see also Pss 48, 76, 87, 122), inviting confidence in the Lord because the citizens of Zion enjoy his protection.

title: Psalms 46:4
content: Like the streams flowing through Eden, this river brings the water of life, restoration, and healing (36:8–9; see Gen 2:10; Ezek 47; Rev 22:2).

title: Psalms 46:4–6
content: The strong city where God dwells protects its inhabitants. They enjoy the river flowing inside the city. This river contrasts with the turbulent waters (the powers of the nations) outside the city.

title: Psalms 46:5
content: From the very break of day: In the ancient Near East, enemies attacked cities during the day; even during the most dangerous times, the Lord will protect the place where his name dwells.

title: Psalms 46:6
content: People and nations live in chaos, characterized by opportunism (83:2), busyness (39:6), and noise. These people shake, totter, and crumble, unlike the city of God (cp. 15:5). In contrast, when the godly feel disturbed, they cry out for God’s help (42:5, 11; 43:5; 55:17).

title: Psalms 46:7
content: This refrain reminds readers of the identity of the God of Zion. • among us: Hebrew ‘immanu, part of the name Immanuel, “God with us” (Isa 7:14; 8:8; Matt 1:23).

title: Psalms 46:8
content: Israel saw the Lord’s glorious works in the wilderness (107:24; 111:2), but the wicked, who have no concern for them (28:5), are left desolate (73:19).

title: Psalms 46:8–9
content: This invitation to trust in the Lord offers a perspective on God’s interactions with human powers.

title: Psalms 46:10
content: A message directly from the Lord confirms the authenticity of the psalmist’s vision (see also 12:5–6; 32:8). • know that I am God: The Lord will do what he promises (Isa 45:3; 49:23; 60:16). • God will be exalted (Ps 47; Isa 6:1); he will judge the nations and rescue his people (see Pss 57:11; 89:13; 108:5–6; 118:16).

title: Psalms 47:1
content: People clap their hands in praise and recognition of marvelous deeds (47:3–4; see 98:8; Isa 55:12; cp. Nah 3:19).

title: Psalms 47:1–2
content: As the sovereign king over the nations, God requires praise.

title: Psalms 47:1–9
content: This psalm celebrates God’s kingship over all the earth; it tells of God’s victory in dealing with Israel and the nations. Both Israel (47:3–4) and the nations (47:9) participate in God’s kingdom.

title: Psalms 47:3–4
content: The Lord made Israel victorious, especially under David (see 18:40–50). God’s mighty deeds of redemption manifest his love for Israel.

title: Psalms 47:4
content: Jacob’s descendants: Jacob was the father of all Israelites (Gen 32:28); the name Jacob often represents the nation of Israel. • God loves and commits himself to Jacob (see Pss 78:68; 127:2; see Rom 11:28).

title: Psalms 47:5
content: trumpets: Or rams’ horns (see 81:3). At times, rams’ horns were sounded in celebration (98:5–6; 2 Kgs 11:14; 1 Chr 15:28).

title: Psalms 47:5–6
content: The psalmist portrays the Lord as returning to heaven, having accomplished his victories. For a portrayal of his descent, see 18:9–16.

title: Psalms 47:7
content: People from all the earth (see 96:1–3) will worship God.

title: Psalms 48:1–14
content: This song of Zion (see also Pss 46, 76, 87, 122) explicitly views Jerusalem (Zion) as the city of the Great King where the godly find protection (48:1–3). God rules from Zion in faithfulness, righteousness, and justice, and he inspires his subjects with confidence and joy (48:9–11). They commit themselves to seeing the glory of Zion for themselves so that they can tell the next generation about it (48:8, 12–14).

title: Psalms 48:3
content: God dwells in Zion to protect it from all enemies (see 46:5).

title: Psalms 48:7
content: The ships of Tarshish, built for long voyages, represent human accomplishment (see also 2 Chr 9:21; Isa 2:16). Their destruction might be the event mentioned in 1 Kgs 22:48.

title: Psalms 48:9–11
content: The psalmist joyfully celebrates the Lord’s presence in the midst of the community, reflecting on the faithfulness, righteousness, and justice of God’s rule.

title: Psalms 48:12–13
content: towers . . . fortified walls . . . citadels: These structures provide a visual tour of Zion’s strength.

title: Psalms 48:14
content: No one is like God (35:10; 71:19; 86:8; 89:6, 8; 113:5; see Isa 40:18, 25). He is the shepherd King (Ps 95:7) who will guide (see 5:8; 23:2) the sheep of his flock (77:20).

title: Psalms 49:1–2
content: Anyone who will listen can gain wisdom (Prov 1:5, 8, 33).

title: Psalms 49:1–4
content: The wisdom teacher invites everyone to the hall of wisdom; he promises to instruct with a proverb and a riddle.

title: Psalms 49:1–20
content: In this wisdom psalm, a wise teacher warns against enemies, whom he portrays as living a rich lifestyle and caring only for themselves (49:5–9). They cannot keep anyone alive, least of all themselves, even in their memories (49:10–12). Like fattened animals, they are led to slaughter (49:14–20).

title: Psalms 49:4
content: The teacher used both proverbs and riddles for instruction in wisdom (see Prov 1:5–6).

title: Psalms 49:5–8
content: If enemies who live for material rewards cannot sustain themselves, how can they give life to others?

title: Psalms 49:11–12
content: The teacher brings wisdom through irony. Everyone dies, and even those with estates named after them will be forgotten.

title: Psalms 49:13–15
content: The teachers of false wisdom cannot rescue themselves from death. Only God has that power.

title: Psalms 49:16–20
content: The wicked might have rich, luxurious lives, but they forget that they cannot avoid death.

title: Psalms 50:1–3
content: The whole universe must pay attention when God approaches to bring justice into the world.

title: Psalms 50:1–23
content: God appears as judge to remind the godly and the ungodly in turn that outward performance of sacrificial rituals and recitation of the law are worthless without thankfulness, repentance, and justice.

title: Psalms 50:4–6
content: The Lord is coming to bring righteousness. This hope encourages his faithful people, but those who have been unfaithful will not experience blessing when the heavens above and earth below testify against them (cp. Deut 30:19; 31:28; 32:1; Isa 1:2). The Lord comes to restore order to the world (Pss 5:8; 22:31; 33:5; 40:9; 50:6; 71:16; 97:6).

title: Psalms 50:7–13
content: The psalmist delivers a message against those who regard the sacrificial rituals as more important than having a proper heart attitude.

title: Psalms 50:9
content: Unlike pagan gods, God does not need food; instead, he wants his people to serve him with a right heart (50:14–15).

title: Psalms 50:10
content: I own the cattle on a thousand hills: God has no needs; he possesses everything.

title: Psalms 50:14
content: Thankfulness means looking beyond self-interest to express gratitude for God’s blessings (see 51:15–17; 54:6). • True sacrifice requires offering one’s self to the glory of God (50:23; Rom 12:1–2).

title: Psalms 50:15
content: God’s response to his people’s cry is to rescue them.

title: Psalms 50:16–21
content: This message is against the wicked, who only pretend to listen to God.

title: Psalms 50:17
content: my discipline . . . my words: The wicked may observe rituals, but they reject more important matters such as justice, mercy, and faithfulness (cp. Matt 23:23–24).

title: Psalms 50:21
content: Because he is patient, God remained silent.

title: Psalms 50:22
content: God will tear the wicked apart like a lion tearing its prey (Isa 5:29; 31:4; Ezek 19:3; cp. Pss 7:2; 22:13).

title: Psalms 50:22–23
content: The wicked will experience God’s justice, while the godly will see God’s everlasting salvation.

title: Psalms 51:1
content: A prayer for God’s mercy and kindness is part of the genre of lament. Sometimes the plea comes from the psalmist’s acknowledgment of his weakness and sin, as here (see also 6:2; 9:13; 25:16; 31:9; 41:4, 10). At other times, it arises from the psalmist’s commitment to the Lord (see 26:11; 27:7; 119:29, 58, 132). In each case, God’s mercy brings an inner renewal.

title: Psalms 51:1–2
content: The repentant offender has nothing to offer God. He needs God’s favor, mercy, forgiveness, and blessing before he can experience renewal and restoration.

title: Psalms 51:1–19
content: This moving prayer for restoration asks for God’s favor, mercy, forgiveness, and cleansing. Out of a broken spirit, the psalmist confesses and accepts responsibility for his sin (51:3–6), then petitions God to remove his guilt and renew him inwardly (51:7–12). The psalmist then recommits himself to a lifestyle of wisdom and joy in the service of God and others (51:13–17).

title: Psalms 51:title
content: See 2 Sam 11:1–27. The text of the psalm contains no explicit reference to this event.

title: Psalms 51:1–65.13
content: These psalms of David share a common thread in their reflection on the experience of evil. In Ps 51, the psalmist confesses the evil he has done and asks God’s forgiveness. Psalms 52–64 lament specific evils that David experienced. A song of praise (Ps 65) brings David’s laments to an end.

title: Psalms 51:2
content: Wash me . . . Purify me: The psalmist prays for cleansing and release from the guilt of his sin (51:7; see 26:6; Isa 1:16, 18; 4:4).

title: Psalms 51:3–6
content: The psalmist accepts the consequences of his sin against God. He knows that there is nothing good in him unless God renews his life.

title: Psalms 51:4
content: Against . . . you alone: This is hyperbole—the psalmist knows he also sinned against human beings (2 Sam 11:2–4, 15–17), but his offense against God is more important. He expects God to rebuke him and will accept whatever verdict God renders (see Rom 3:4).

title: Psalms 51:5
content: I was born a sinner: The psalmist is not making excuses but is acknowledging the depth of his sinfulness. From the time we are conceived, we all share in the human condition of sinfulness.

title: Psalms 51:7
content: Purify me from my sins (literally Purify me with the hyssop branch; see Exod 12:22; Lev 14:4; John 19:29; Heb 9:19): The psalmist depends on God to purify and renew him (see Isa 1:18).

title: Psalms 51:8
content: Regaining joy is a gracious gift from God. • you have broken me: The psalmist’s whole being feels broken (6:2; cp. 34:20).

title: Psalms 51:10
content: A loyal spirit yields the inner qualities of constancy and perseverance.

title: Psalms 51:10–12
content: God’s Spirit renews and recreates the human spirit.

title: Psalms 51:11
content: your Holy Spirit: Only the power of the Holy Spirit can change the human will to make it “loyal” (51:10) and “willing to obey” (51:12).

title: Psalms 51:13
content: As he learns from his sin and its consequences, the psalmist wants to teach others.

title: Psalms 51:14
content: shedding blood: This idiom includes any injustice, not just homicide (9:12; 58:10; see 2 Sam 11:14–26; cp. Isa 1:15–17).

title: Psalms 51:18–19
content: rebuild the walls of Jerusalem: These verses were probably added as a prayer for national restoration after the Exile (see Pss 42–43); the entire community in exile identified with the spirit of the psalm.

title: Psalms 51:19
content: Sacrifices offered in the right spirit come from a heart that is right with God and with others (see 15:2–5; 24:3–6; 50:14; Matt 5:23–24).

title: Psalms 52:1
content: is a paradigm of evil.

title: Psalms 52:1–4
content: Liars foolishly deceive themselves by thinking that they can be heroes by their words. They believe themselves innocent of any charges of evildoing, though they love evil and cause destruction. Those who speak curses, sarcasm, bitterness, arrogant boasting, and deceptions (31:18; 34:13; 59:7, 12; 120:2–3; 140:3, 9) bring about chaos, alienation, and destruction (Jas 3:5). Their sharp words cut like swords and daggers (Pss 55:21; 57:4; 64:3), the fangs of a snake (140:3), or a razor.

title: Psalms 52:1–9
content: Wicked people use words to destroy relationships and communities. They foolishly think that they can be heroes by their words (52:1–4), but their fate suddenly overtakes them (52:5–7). In contrast, the godly renew their commitment to the Lord (52:8–9) and find their future secure in him.

title: Psalms 52:3
content: Deceptive speech changes one’s character.

title: Psalms 52:5
content: God will strike the wicked down like a pagan altar, idol, or unclean vessel (Exod 34:13; Lev 11:35; 2 Kgs 10:27).

title: Psalms 52:5–7
content: God’s judgment on the wicked will come suddenly and forcibly. The godly rejoice in God’s justice, not in the misfortunes of the wicked.

title: Psalms 52:6
content: In Hebrew, the verbs here translated see and be amazed sound almost alike.

title: Psalms 52:8–9
content: The psalmist commits himself to a life of trust in the Lord. • An olive tree lives a long time when cared for (1:3; 128:3). The psalmist desires to be close to the Lord, his Savior and the source of his blessing (18:6; 23:6).

title: Psalms 53:1–3
content: Paul uses the Greek translation of this passage in his description of the depravity of all people (Rom 3:10–12).

title: Psalms 53:1–6
content: This psalm parallels Ps 14, differing only in verse 5.

title: Psalms 53:5
content: scatter the bones: Israel’s enemies would suffer shameful defeat and lack the peaceful rest of a decent burial (cp. 141:7; 2 Kgs 9:10; Jer 8:1–2; Ezek 6:5).

title: Psalms 54:1
content: were bent on violence.

title: Psalms 54:1–7
content: In this individual lament, occasioned by violent and godless people (54:3), the psalmist turns to God in prayer and maintains his focus on God’s help (54:4). He prays for God to save him from evil and to judge his enemies (54:5, 7).

title: Psalms 54:3
content: The strangers were alienated from the covenant community (see 109:11; Prov 5:10). • Proud and violent people hold no regard for God or for other people (see Pss 35:11, 25; 86:14; Prov 11:16).

title: Psalms 54:6
content: A voluntary offering is a sacrifice of praise. Sacrifices of praise are the kind of offering God most desires (see Ps 50:14–15, 23).

title: Psalms 54:6–7
content: In anticipation of God’s response, the mood of the psalm changes from gloom to thanksgiving.

title: Psalms 55:1–3
content: The occasion for this prayer is an attack by an enemy.

title: Psalms 55:1–23
content: The psalmist is faced with adversaries whose leader is a former friend (55:12–14), and he is overwhelmed with anguish. He turns to the Lord in prayer and commits himself to the Lord for redress (55:22–23). Jesus experienced similar suffering when his friend (Judas) betrayed him. He also experienced the answer to the psalmist’s prayer: (1) by taking the place of the wicked and receiving their judgment (Isa 53:7–9), and (2) by committing himself to the Father, who rescued (Luke 23:46) and rewarded him (Isa 53:10–12).

title: Psalms 55:4–8
content: In the experience of deep anguish, the psalmist confesses that his adversity has become unbearable and he seeks an escape.

title: Psalms 55:12–20
content: The psalmist’s enemy was once a friend; memories of that close relationship bring him pain (see 31:11).

title: Psalms 55:19–21
content: God is good and faithful, but the psalmist’s enemies and so-called friend are deceitful and wicked.

title: Psalms 55:22–23
content: The psalmist commits all his cares to the Lord.

title: Psalms 55:23
content: To die young means that one fails to experience God’s full blessing (cp. Prov 3:2, 16).

title: Psalms 56:1
content: by Philistines concerned about his loyalties and brought before King Achish (1 Sam 21:10–15).

title: Psalms 56:1–13
content: This individual lament moves from petition to confidence two times (56:1–4, 5–13).

title: Psalms 56:4
content: mere mortals: Or mere flesh, in contrast to the immortal and infinitely more powerful God (see Isa 2:22).

title: Psalms 56:5–7
content: The psalmist specifies his charge against his attackers as he prays for their evil to cease.

title: Psalms 56:8
content: The psalmist makes a play on the Hebrew words translated sorrows (Hebrew nod) and bottle (Hebrew no’d).

title: Psalms 56:11
content: mere mortals (Hebrew ’adam): The psalm also uses two other words for man: ’enosh (“people,” 56:1) and basar (“mere mortals,” 56:4). All express the ideas of mortality and finitude.

title: Psalms 56:13
content: The light of God’s goodness and salvation will replace the darkness of death (see 18:25–29; 27:1).

title: Psalms 57:1
content: shadow of your wings: As a bird protects its young, God protects the one who trusts in him (see 17:8).

title: Psalms 57:1–11
content: The psalmist’s cry for mercy and protection quickly turns into an affirmation of trust and confidence in the Lord (57:1–4). When the wicked fall into their own traps (57:6), the psalmist will praise the Lord (57:7–10).

title: Psalms 57:title
content: See 1 Sam 22:1 or Ps 24:1–8.

title: Psalms 57:2
content: God Most High (Hebrew Elohim-Elyon) is a generic title for God, who is more powerful than all real or imagined supernatural beings (see 91:1; 97:9; Gen 14:18–22). • who will fulfill his purpose: Or who will end my [trouble], or who deals kindly with me.

title: Psalms 57:3–4
content: These verses are a prayer for rescue from powerful enemies. The metaphor of fierce lions describes human enemies; the psalmist feels unable to escape them without God’s intervention (see also 35:11–21; 124:6).

title: Psalms 57:5
content: This verse is repeated in 57:11 and 108:5. • God’s glory—his manifest presence that excludes all evil (8:1; 19:1–4; 24:7)—will fill the whole created order (Isa 6:3).

title: Psalms 57:7–8
content: The psalmist is confident that God will end the night of evil (cp. 56:13).

title: Psalms 57:7–11
content: This section is repeated with a few modifications in 108:1–5.

title: Psalms 57:10–11
content: God’s glory extends to the whole universe, as will praise for his unfailing love and faithfulness.

title: Psalms 58:1
content: rulers (or gods): This designation was used for high officials and administrators of justice (82:1, 6). Elsewhere, it might refer to angelic creatures (89:7) or to the gods of the nations (82:1; Dan 11:36).

title: Psalms 58:1–5
content: The administrators of justice were furthering their own interests rather than those of the needy. The absence of justice gradually resulted in a violent society.

title: Psalms 58:1–11
content: The administration of justice is a mark of good government. God expects nothing less from his people. The psalmist condemns Israel’s leaders for abusing their power, and he calls on the Lord to rain down his curses upon the wicked. The demonstration of divine justice will reassure the godly that God is just.

title: Psalms 58:3
content: All human beings are born sinners (see 51:5); however, whereas the wicked indulge their sinful nature, the godly fight against it (Rom 7:19–23; Jas 4:1–10).

title: Psalms 58:4
content: Venom here means poisonous speech (see 140:3).

title: Psalms 58:6
content: The psalmist calls on God to break the destructive power of the wicked.

title: Psalms 58:8
content: When moving over dry ground, snails dry up.

title: Psalms 58:9–10
content: God’s judgment will come suddenly. The certainty of vindication brings joy to the godly.

title: Psalms 58:11
content: Vindication is the reward of those who live for God.

title: Psalms 59:1
content: See 1 Sam 19:11–18.

title: Psalms 59:1–2
content: Protect me (or place me on high): When surrounded by evil, the godly pray for God to set them apart for himself and protect them.

title: Psalms 59:1–17
content: The psalmist laments the power of enemies who conspire with other nations.

title: Psalms 59:4–5
content: The psalmist asks God to show the treacherous, deceptive, and wicked traitors no mercy (see 25:2).

title: Psalms 59:6–8
content: The wicked threaten like vicious dogs, but the Lord responds with scorn.

title: Psalms 59:11–13
content: The psalmist prays that the wicked will be forced to endure the same agonizing pain they have caused.

title: Psalms 59:14–16
content: The wicked will go unsatisfied, but the psalmist will praise the Lord’s power and unfailing love.

title: Psalms 60:1
content: This psalm was taught to young people as part of their education. • regarding the time: See 2 Sam 8:13–14. • Aram-naharaim and Aram-zobah refer to the Arameans of northwest Mesopotamia and Syria (see study note on Gen 24:10). • The tune “Lily of the Testimony” is unknown today.

title: Psalms 60:1–4
content: When God’s people experience his discipline, they affirm their loyalty and await God’s answer.

title: Psalms 60:1–12
content: The psalmist laments a national defeat and cries out to God for rescue.

title: Psalms 60:3
content: wine (Hebrew yayin) that sent us reeling: Yayin, the generic Hebrew term meaning “wine,” is often associated with drunkenness (2 Sam 13:28; Isa 5:11; 28:7–8; cp. Ps 104:15; Deut 14:26; Isa 55:1); it symbolized God’s judgment of the wicked (Ps 75:8; Jer 51:7).

title: Psalms 60:4
content: God raised a banner over his people to serve as a rallying point and as a source of pride and confidence. • The fear of God that leads to wisdom (111:10) is not weakness; it provides the perspective and strength required to do what is right.

title: Psalms 60:5
content: The psalmist prays for rescue based on the special relationship between God and his people.

title: Psalms 60:5–12
content: This section is repeated verbatim in 108:6–13.

title: Psalms 60:6
content: Shechem and Succoth represent Israel’s heartland.

title: Psalms 60:6–8
content: The Lord responds with a message of promise. He shares his land with his people as spoils of war.

title: Psalms 60:9
content: Destroying a defeated invader’s capital (the fortified city) would help to ensure that they would not attack again. The capital of Edom was Bozrah, located to the southeast of Israel. Only God could grant victory.

title: Psalms 61:1–8
content: The lamenting psalmist petitions God to protect him and lead him into his presence (61:4–5). He prays for God to extend and protect the king’s rule and makes vows to praise God.

title: Psalms 61:1–63.11
content: In these royal prayers, the psalmist longs for God’s presence. All three psalms concern themselves with the king’s security.

title: Psalms 61:2
content: the ends of the earth: This expression has the connotation of a cry that comes from a place far away from God. • The psalmist’s heart is overwhelmed with deep anguish.

title: Psalms 61:4
content: The poet longs for God’s presence and seeks entrance into God’s home on earth for divine protection and care. To be received into God’s sanctuary (literally tent) is the greatest good (see 15:1; 23:6; 24:3–6). The Hebrew word translated sanctuary recalls the Tabernacle and the tent that David built for the Ark (1 Chr 15:1). See also study note on John 1:14. • The shelter of your wings symbolizes God’s protection and care (see Pss 9:9; 17:8).

title: Psalms 61:5
content: you have heard my vows: The psalmist’s vows might also be a part of ceremonial sacrifices (66:13–15; 76:11; 116:14, 18). He praises and thanks God for his rescue. • The inheritance refers to the promise of the land (see Ps 60), the sacredness of the Temple, the joy of God’s presence (119:111), or any similar reward (16:6; 37:9, 11, 18, 22, 29, 34; 127:3).

title: Psalms 62:1
content: See 1 Chr 25:1; also in Pss 39 and 77.

title: Psalms 62:1–12
content: This psalm expresses confidence in the king and offers prayer for him. The king rests in God despite his difficulties. Although his deceptive and powerful adversaries push hard against him, he remains undaunted. He encourages himself and his people to trust in God and to see their human adversaries from God’s perspective, where they appear frail, fleeting, and deceptive (62:9).

title: Psalms 62:3–4
content: The enemies desire to topple the king with lies and cunning.

title: Psalms 62:4
content: My high position refers to the royal throne.

title: Psalms 62:5–8
content: The psalmist encourages himself and others to place their hope in God.

title: Psalms 62:9
content: not what they appear to be: People often try to look stronger and better than they are.

title: Psalms 62:9–12
content: Unlike God, humans are transient beings. Even when they thrive, their prosperity is fleeting.

title: Psalms 62:10
content: The crime of extortion means using intimidation and threats to make others give up what is theirs, while stealing is taking what belongs to others.

title: Psalms 62:11–12
content: Strength and unfailing love remain in balance only in God. He cares for his people by ridding the world of evildoers (see 1:6).

title: Psalms 63:1
content: Together, soul and whole body refer to a person’s entire being. • parched and weary land: When David was living in the desert, he also found himself in a spiritual wasteland, separated from God’s people and the sanctuary.

title: Psalms 63:1–11
content: The king longs for God’s presence so vividly that he eats, drinks, and sees God’s goodness. Though worn out and harassed by the wicked, the king sees God, and this animates him with praise. God becomes his life (63:3), while the wicked perish (63:9).

title: Psalms 63:2
content: The psalmist remembers that he had found God to be present in his sanctuary (see 18:6; 61:4; 62:5, 11–12).

title: Psalms 63:3
content: better than life itself: The highest quality of life is found in relationship with God (see 4:7; 63:5; Prov 16:8).

title: Psalms 63:6
content: Meditating on God requires focused awareness, concentration, thought, and reflection (see 1:2).

title: Psalms 63:6–8
content: The psalmist reflects and meditates on God’s presence through the night. In the absence of light, God is the light. The quietness of the night and the longing for dawn provide time to focus on the true significance of life with the Lord.

title: Psalms 63:9
content: The wicked were plotting to destroy the psalmist’s life through deception and lies, but they would meet their end. • The depths of the earth refers to the place of the dead.

title: Psalms 63:10
content: Wild jackals are associated with desolation and abandonment (Isa 13:20–22; 34:10–15; Jer 9:11; 49:33; 51:37; Lam 5:18; Mal 1:3). The wicked will not receive honor in death; their bodies will be left to scavenging animals (Eccl 6:3; Jer 22:18–19; 36:29–30).

title: Psalms 64:1–6
content: These verses form a prayer for rescue from bold and powerful liars.

title: Psalms 64:1–10
content: This lament decries the destructive plots and arrogant attitude of the wicked (64:1–6). The psalmist turns to God in prayer and takes heart in God’s justice because whatever the wicked do will be undone by the righteous judge. The godly will rejoice and grow in wisdom as they reflect on God’s mighty acts.

title: Psalms 64:3
content: their tongues . . . bitter words: Liars use their speech to kill. This description might also refer to practicing magic.

title: Psalms 64:6
content: The enemies create a perfect plan to harm the innocent without getting caught. • Human beings will sink to unthinkable depths with evil words, acts, or plans (83:3; see Jer 17:9).

title: Psalms 64:7–10
content: What God does is righteous. God undoes what is wicked and pays the wicked back with what they planned for others.

title: Psalms 65:1
content: God alone deserves praise and is worthy to have vows made to him.

title: Psalms 65:1–3
content: Praise is the appropriate response to God’s majestic deeds in redemption (65:3–5) and in nature (65:5–13).

title: Psalms 65:1–13
content: This psalm recounts the reasons why all people should praise and revere God for his almighty power and merciful care for his universe.

title: Psalms 65:2
content: All of us means all humans.

title: Psalms 65:3
content: you forgive: God graciously removes the guilt of sin (see 32:5).

title: Psalms 65:4
content: those you choose to bring near: This includes people from Israel and from other nations. • Only those whom God sees as blameless live in his holy courts (Pss 15 and 24). • At the Temple, God’s earthly palace, all nations can gather to experience God’s holy presence. No structure can separate humans from God (see Rev 21:22).

title: Psalms 65:6–7
content: God brought order to the mountains, the raging oceans, and the pounding waves (see Pss 95:4–5; 104:6–9). • The psalmist compares the chaotic forces of nature with the rebellion of the nations (see 2:1–12; 33:6–11; 46:6).

title: Psalms 65:8
content: All over the world (Job 38:13; see Ps 50:1–3), people should stand in awe of the Lord.

title: Psalms 65:9
content: The river of God and all rivers demonstrate God’s victorious power and goodness through the order in nature and the regularity of the harvests (see 1:3; 36:8; 46:4; Ezek 47:6–12; Zech 14:8; Rev 22:1).

title: Psalms 65:9–13
content: The created order provides clear evidence of God’s power (65:6–8). He shows his love by maintaining nature. Everything praises the Lord as all the parts fit together harmoniously.

title: Psalms 65:13
content: Nature bursts out in praise of the Creator (see 79:13; 96:11–13; 148:3–5, 7–12; Isa 55:12–13).

title: Psalms 66:1–4
content: The psalmist exhorts nature to join in a mighty chorus to praise God’s glory, name, and power.

title: Psalms 66:1–20
content: This anonymous psalm includes two hymns (66:1–12, 13–20) that praise God for his redemption.

title: Psalms 66:2
content: The glory of his name represents the perfection of God’s character.

title: Psalms 66:3
content: God conquers his enemies (see 18:44; 59:11; 81:15).

title: Psalms 66:5–7
content: The story of the Exodus and God’s victory over the sea evokes responses of astonishment (66:5) and worship (66:6). God works miracles . . . for people in order to redeem them for himself.

title: Psalms 66:7
content: God’s power brings redemption. The same word occurs in 65:6 for God’s power in creation (see also 80:2).

title: Psalms 66:8–10
content: The orderly lives of the redeemed reflect the order of God’s world. The Lord protects them from evil and purifies them.

title: Psalms 66:9
content: God guides his people into wisdom and away from folly (17:5; 37:31; 121:3).

title: Psalms 66:10
content: You have tested us, O God: As the silversmith heats silver to remove the dross, God’s discipline removes sin from his people (see 12:6).

title: Psalms 66:11
content: God decrees and permits the many trying circumstances his people experience.

title: Psalms 66:12
content: Then you put a leader over us: Or You made people ride over our heads. This expression possibly refers to a foreign ruler who kept the Israelites in submission.

title: Psalms 66:15
content: Vows often included sacrifices of thanksgiving, including burnt offerings (see 20:3; 40:6; 50:8; 51:19).

title: Psalms 66:16–20
content: The private testimony in the conclusion of the psalm parallels the public praise of its opening (66:1–4).

title: Psalms 66:18
content: Confession leads to restoration (see 32:5).

title: Psalms 67:1–2
content: This prayer is based on the priestly blessing found in Num 6:24–26. God’s goodness to Israel affects his reputation among the nations (see Ps 96:1–3).

title: Psalms 67:1–7
content: In this anonymous prayer for God’s blessing, the psalmist addresses the knowledge and worship of God among the nations (cp. 64:9; 65:8). The prayer requests that God’s name be kept holy and that his kingdom come (cp. Matt 6:9–13).

title: Psalms 67:3
content: God’s international reputation leads to his praise among the nations (see 138:4), whose turmoil and rebelliousness will cease when they join Israel in praise of God. • One God rules over all, and the nations will give thanks for God’s just rule (see 67:4).

title: Psalms 67:4
content: God brings the ultimate justice that human beings desire (96:10; 98:9).

title: Psalms 67:6–7
content: Bountiful harvests are evidence of God’s blessing (Gen 26:12; Isa 30:23). • all over the world: See Pss 2:8; 96:1–3. • All will fear him, joining with Israel to acknowledge the God of Israel.

title: Psalms 68:1–3
content: These verses form a prayer for God to rise up and scatter his enemies, as he did when Israel entered the Promised Land (cp. Num 10:35–36; Josh 6–12).

title: Psalms 68:1–35
content: This prayer for God’s victorious rule traces God’s march from Sinai to Zion (68:7, 16–18, 24). He rescued the nation of Israel from Egypt, guided it through the wilderness, brought it into the Promised Land, and established his kingdom. He is a caring and victorious God, whose nature is unchanging. Therefore, the godly hope and rejoice in the prospect of God’s universal dominion.

title: Psalms 68:2
content: Both smoke and wax represent a transitory existence (22:12–18; 37:20; 102:3).

title: Psalms 68:3
content: The lot of the godly contrasts with that of the wicked (see 1:6).

title: Psalms 68:4
content: him who rides the clouds: This is an ancient description of Baal, a Canaanite deity. The psalmist applies it to the Lord as the true “Rider of the Clouds” (see 68:33; 104:3). God wields power over the clouds and the rain.

title: Psalms 68:4–6
content: The psalmist praises God’s powerful and compassionate reign.

title: Psalms 68:5
content: God, the Father of all marginalized and needy people, shows them compassion and protects their rights (see 10:14, 18; 69:33; 82:3). • Like his dwelling, the Lord is holy. The supreme example of the holy God coming down to rescue humanity is Jesus Christ.

title: Psalms 68:6
content: God released Israel from slavery in Egypt (Exod 20:2; see Ps 69:33), and he still sets the prisoners free. • The sun-scorched desert represents alienation from God and separation from blessing.

title: Psalms 68:8–10
content: The earth trembled as in an earthquake (see Exod 19:18). • the heavens poured down rain: Wells in the desert and rain showers in Canaan supplied an abundance of water.

title: Psalms 68:11
content: a great army (or a host of women) brings: The Hebrew suggests women singers caroling the good news of victory (see 68:25; Exod 15:20).

title: Psalms 68:13
content: The seminomadic pastoral people who lived among the sheepfolds were surprised to receive silver and gold carvings from the battle.

title: Psalms 68:14
content: The Almighty (Hebrew Shaddai) is an ancient designation for God (see 91:1; Gen 17:1). • The identification of Mount Zalmon is uncertain; it was possibly a mountain in Bashan (see Ps 68:15).

title: Psalms 68:15
content: Bashan is a plateau northeast of Jerusalem and east of the Sea of Galilee that was known for its woods and pastureland (see 22:12; Isa 2:13). The mountains might have included Mount Hermon to the north of the plateau or Mount Zalmon, which might be Jebel ed-Druze on the east.

title: Psalms 68:16
content: Why do you look with envy? Bashan is physically much more impressive than the mountains around Jerusalem, but it was not the home of the Lord. Only Mount Zion enjoyed the privilege of providing God’s dwelling place.

title: Psalms 68:17
content: Chariots, the ultimate weapon of the armed forces in the psalmist’s day, are an image of the Lord’s power to grant victory (20:7; 44:3).

title: Psalms 68:18
content: When you ascended to the heights: The Most High established his reign victoriously in Zion. • a crowd of captives . . . gifts: This is an image of a victorious ruler leading the victory march after battle. Paul applied this image to Jesus Christ (Eph 4:8–13).

title: Psalms 68:19
content: Like a caring father or a shepherd, God carries his people in his arms (see 55:22; 68:5–6).

title: Psalms 68:19–20
content: The Divine Warrior cares for his people like a shepherd; the people praise him.

title: Psalms 68:21
content: God will smash the heads of his enemies: Cp. Gen 3:15.

title: Psalms 68:22
content: God will deal with all enemies, whether from high places (represented by Bashan) or low (the depths of the sea).

title: Psalms 68:24–27
content: A great company joins together in the pilgrimage to Zion.

title: Psalms 68:28–31
content: The people pray for God’s success and for victory over the enemy nations (68:1–3).

title: Psalms 68:29
content: The conquered kings will bring gifts to the Lord.

title: Psalms 68:30
content: Hostile and rebellious people delight in warfare and insurrection (see 2:1–3).

title: Psalms 68:32
content: The term kingdoms of the earth includes all nations and power structures.

title: Psalms 68:32–35
content: The psalmist calls for the people to praise God, who is victorious over his enemies.

title: Psalms 68:34
content: When the Lord demonstrates his power, majesty, and strength against the nations, he strengthens his people (see 96:4–6).

title: Psalms 69:1
content: Psalm 45 also notes this tune, but Ps 45 celebrates the glory of kingship, whereas Ps 69 is the cry of a tired king who feels abandoned by the Lord.

title: Psalms 69:1–2
content: The psalmist sees himself as almost drowning but still surviving chaotic forces and alienation from God (see 42:7; 69:14, 15; Isa 8:8).

title: Psalms 69:1–36
content: In this individual lament, the poet expresses his vulnerability, humiliation, and overwhelming pain, asking God to vindicate him for the sake of the righteous.

title: Psalms 69:1–72.20
content: These last four psalms of Book Two contrast with the psalms describing God’s mighty acts in creation and in redemption, capped by God’s march to Zion (Pss 65–68). Psalms 69–71 portray the king’s anguish, and Ps 72 responds with a prayer for God to bless the king.

title: Psalms 69:4
content: John applied this lament to Jesus (John 15:25).

title: Psalms 69:5–6
content: The psalmist confesses his sins and prays that God’s response to him will encourage others in similar conditions to place their hope in the Lord.

title: Psalms 69:7–12
content: Mistreated and abandoned by family, friends, and community, the psalmist turns to the Lord for comfort, relief (69:13–18), and redress (69:22–28).

title: Psalms 69:9
content: Though the psalmist concerns himself with God and all that is holy, insults have been his earthly reward. This verse was later applied to Jesus’ anger at the Temple’s money changers (John 2:17) and to his undeserved suffering (Rom 15:3).

title: Psalms 69:10–12
content: When the psalmist denies himself normal comforts to seek God in prayer, the wicked ridicule him.

title: Psalms 69:13–18
content: The psalmist’s only recourse is to pray for rescue and relief from his enemies.

title: Psalms 69:19–21
content: Alone and misunderstood, the psalmist confesses that he cannot bear his doubts. His heart has been broken by his problems.

title: Psalms 69:21
content: sour wine for my thirst: This description applies to Jesus’ suffering (Matt 27:34, 48; Luke 23:36; John 19:28–29).

title: Psalms 69:22–23
content: The psalmist wants God to transfer his suffering (69:3) to his enemies. Paul applied these words to the unbelieving Jews of his day (Rom 11:9–10).

title: Psalms 69:25
content: Peter quoted this verse after the death of Judas Iscariot (Acts 1:20).

title: Psalms 69:28
content: Erase their names from the Book of Life: Cp. 1:5–6; 9:5; Rev 3:5; 20:15; 21:22–27.

title: Psalms 69:29–33
content: The psalmist prays that his pain will turn to praise.

title: Psalms 69:31
content: Making a vow often included a sacrifice (20:3; 51:19; cp. 50:13–14; 51:16).

title: Psalms 69:32–33
content: despise: See 22:24; cp. Matt 25:36; Heb 13:3.

title: Psalms 69:34–36
content: The psalmist prays for Zion, offering a new petition from a new circumstance. He applies the prayer (69:1–33) to the desperate condition of Judah (see 51:18–19).

title: Psalms 69:36
content: God’s people will inherit the land because the wicked will perish (see 37:8–9).

title: Psalms 70:1
content: The meaning of this phrase is unknown (also found in 38:title).

title: Psalms 70:1–5
content: This psalm, nearly identical to 40:13–17, contains an urgency (70:1, 5) that fits with the surrounding psalms (cp. 69:17; 71:12).

title: Psalms 71:1–4
content: The poet has learned to acknowledge God as the reliable rock who will do what is right toward him and his oppressors. See also 31:1–3.

title: Psalms 71:1–24
content: This untitled lament by an aging believer is more of a confession of confidence and hope than the cry of someone abandoned by God. The psalmist experienced God’s power and protection in his youth (71:5–8) and now prays for rescue from the adversaries who stalk him in his old age (71:9–13). Even in the midst of his peril, he continues to tell of God’s past faithfulness and looks forward with hope to a time when he can testify to the next generation that God is faithful and righteous.

title: Psalms 71:5–6
content: The psalmist has trusted God throughout his life (see 22:9).

title: Psalms 71:9
content: The poet prays for continued fellowship with God (see 9:10; 51:11). In his weakness, he needs the Lord’s strength even more (see 143:7).

title: Psalms 71:9–18
content: The aging believer turns to the Lord for hope. As questions from his adversaries get under his skin and his own strength fails, he asks God to answer his prayers. He does not seek answers to prayer for himself but so that he can tell the story to the next generation.

title: Psalms 71:10
content: In their plotting, the psalmist’s enemies take counsel and scheme together (2:2; 21:11; 31:13; 35:4; 63:9–10).

title: Psalms 71:14
content: The psalmist contrasts his own goodness with his enemies’ evil; he centers his life in the Lord, even during hard times (see 9:17–18; 27:13–14).

title: Psalms 71:19–21
content: God’s righteous character provides encouragement and strength in the midst of suffering. The wounded psalmist confesses faith in God’s ability to transform his misery and weakness into abundant life.

title: Psalms 71:20
content: lift me up from the depths: The psalmist hopes for the renewal of an abundant earthly life. This later became grounds for belief in the resurrection of the dead.

title: Psalms 71:21
content: Being assured of God’s comfort also assures the poet of God’s presence, care, and goodness (23:4, 6; 86:17). God’s comfort enhances the psalmist’s sense of being alive (see 119:50).

title: Psalms 71:22–24
content: As he awaits God’s rescue, the psalmist prepares himself to declare with instruments and voice that God is faithful and righteous.

title: Psalms 72:1
content: love of justice . . . righteousness: Kings in the ancient Near East were expected to represent justice; the standard for Israel’s kings was much higher because the Lord was their model.

title: Psalms 72:1–7
content: The blessings of justice create a balance in nature, resulting in harmony, prosperity, and fertility.

title: Psalms 72:1–20
content: This royal psalm closes Book Two, with 72:18–20 functioning as an epilogue to all of Book Two. The psalmist reflects on the prospects of David’s royal line and on Zion (see Pss 46, 48). He prays that Israel’s kings will be good and prosperous, extending the Lord’s blessing on his people throughout the whole earth. The surpassing righteousness and dominion sought in this prayer foreshadow the coming of Jesus, the Son of David.

title: Psalms 72:3
content: The administration of justice transforms the earth into fruitfulness, abundance, harmony, and goodness (see Isa 32:16–17).

title: Psalms 72:4
content: A just ruler will defend the poor against injustice, rescue them from violence, and bring their oppressors to account for their wrongdoing.

title: Psalms 72:5
content: May they fear you: In Hebrew, this clause seems to be a response to the enforcement of justice. The Greek version reads May they endure, which makes this a prayer for longevity (21:4; 72:15, 17).

title: Psalms 72:6–7
content: The administration of justice is refreshing like spring rain, enabling the godly to flourish (see Isa 45:8) like flowers. • until the moon is no more: This phrase means forever (see Ps 89:36–37).

title: Psalms 72:8–9
content: from sea to sea: This phrase represents the whole world. • Solomon’s kingdom extended from the Euphrates River in the east to the Philistine territory in the west (1 Kgs 4:21; see Pss 80:8–11; 89:19–25), where the Mediterranean Sea appeared to be at the ends of the earth (see 2:8). Everyone will bow before this king, including the desert nomads (72:9), his enemies, and all the kings of the world (see Mic 7:17).

title: Psalms 72:8–11
content: The anointed king will rule over the whole world. Even hostile nations will submit to him. In the ancient Near East, bearing gifts to the king acknowledged his success and his reputation (see 1 Kgs 10).

title: Psalms 72:10
content: The western kings of Tarshish came from a major colony in the western basin of the Mediterranean. The eastern kings of Sheba came from an area in southern Arabia, home of the queen of Sheba (1 Kgs 10). • Seba was probably located somewhere south of Egypt, perhaps on the western shore of the Red Sea across from Sheba. • The gifts offered to the king represented a tribute and a token of submission.

title: Psalms 72:11
content: All kings and all nations must submit to the messianic king. The hope expressed in 2:10–11 will be realized (see 96:1–3; 1 Cor 15:25) when other leaders and peoples bow before and serve this king.

title: Psalms 72:12
content: To rescue the poor means to bring an end to the rule of their oppressors.

title: Psalms 72:12–14
content: The anointed king will rescue the needy. He is not only the judge but also a father to the poor (10:14, 17; 68:5).

title: Psalms 72:13
content: Like a father, the king feels pity for those in need (see Mal 3:17).

title: Psalms 72:15
content: The people will bless him, fulfilling God’s promise to Abraham (Gen 12:3; see Ps 133:3).

title: Psalms 72:15–17
content: The just kingdom will be long-lasting and universal. The summary combines the themes of abundance of crops, longevity, tribute of the nations, and the prayer of the nations.

title: Psalms 72:16
content: the trees of Lebanon: Lebanon was renowned for its lumber (see study note on 2 Chr 2:8).

title: Psalms 72:18–19
content: This doxology concludes Book Two of the Psalter.

title: Psalms 72:20
content: This parenthetical note ends Book Two, which consists mostly of prayers of David. Books Three to Five were probably compiled after Book Two; they include additional psalms of David (Pss 86, 101, 103, 108–110, 122, 124, 131, 133, 138–145).

title: Psalms 73:1
content: People whose hearts are pure are renewed by God’s Spirit (51:10), commit themselves to lives of godliness, keep away from anything that is sinful, and enjoy God’s presence (see 24:3–4).

title: Psalms 73:1–28
content: This wisdom psalm examines the injustice of the prosperity of the wicked. The psalmist affirms that God is good to the godly but his own experience differs (73:2–12). Nearly overcome by his doubts (73:13–16), the psalmist meets the Lord in the sanctuary and gains a perspective that stretches beyond his life and renews his confidence in God (73:17–26). His disturbing doubts stir a greater passion for truth. He knows that he can trust God and that God will rescue him (73:27–28).

title: Psalms 73:title
content: was a Levitical singer appointed by David (1 Chr 6:39); his descendants were singers and instrumentalists (1 Chr 15:16–17). Many of the psalms of Asaph (Pss 50, 73–83) were probably written by Asaph’s descendants at a later time in Israel’s history (e.g., Ps 74).

title: Psalms 73:1–75.10
content: The apparent prosperity of the wicked (Ps 73) and God’s apparent rejection of his people (Ps 74) raise questions about his justice. God is sovereign over the whole world, and he determines the time for judgment (Ps 75).

title: Psalms 73:2–3
content: The poet sees the prosperity of the wicked as unfair (see 72:7) and resents it. • The psalmist’s feet were slipping from the way of wisdom and godliness (see 17:5; 37:31), but God kept him from falling off the trail entirely (38:16; 66:9; 94:18; 121:3). • when I saw them prosper: Cp. 72:3, 7.

title: Psalms 73:4–12
content: The psalmist presents a caricature of the bliss of the wicked (cp. Ps 1).

title: Psalms 73:6
content: The proud adorn themselves with pride and cruelty rather than wisdom (Prov 1:9).

title: Psalms 73:9
content: The proud boast, claiming that they own everything and are not subject to anyone (see 2:1–3).

title: Psalms 73:13–14
content: These rhetorical questions expect a discouraging “yes” for an answer. The psalmist wonders if godliness has become a meaningless ritual (see Mal 3:14–15). • My heart refers to his whole being. • The psalmist’s pain comes from discipline and rebuke (Ps 39:11; Prov 1:23, 25; 12:1).

title: Psalms 73:13–17
content: Recognizing the ramifications of his discouragement and doubt, the psalmist turns to the Lord and receives special insight.

title: Psalms 73:15–16
content: If the psalmist had verbalized his suspicions about the futility of godly living, he would have discouraged God’s people and given God’s enemies an opportunity to blaspheme (cp. John 13:20). Instead, the psalmist internalizes the problem and reflects on it.

title: Psalms 73:17–20
content: At this time, God’s sanctuary was the Temple in Jerusalem. There, in God’s presence, the psalmist receives special insight (cp. 18:6). • God deals with the wicked over the long term. He waits patiently and gives them time to repent (Ezek 33:11; 2 Pet 3:9); those who do not repent will get what they deserve.

title: Psalms 73:21–22
content: The psalmist’s feelings about the prosperity of the wicked had given him a bitter spirit.

title: Psalms 73:24
content: The Lord leads the godly through their troubles and changes their misery into splendor.

title: Psalms 73:25–26
content: Nothing in heaven or on earth is better than being near God.

title: Psalms 74:1
content: God rejected his people because their sin aroused his anger (106:34–46). • Like a tender shepherd, God cares for his people, the sheep of his pasture (Pss 23; 100:3).

title: Psalms 74:1–2
content: In the aftermath of Jerusalem’s fall, it seemed that God had forgotten his special covenant relationship with his people.

title: Psalms 74:1–23
content: The psalmist laments the destruction of the Temple in Jerusalem (586 BC) with vivid imagery, questions, fresh memories, and a direct appeal for the Lord to act (74:19–23).

title: Psalms 74:2
content: The Lord chose and redeemed Israel from Egypt in the Exodus (cp. Exod 15:13). • your own special possession: This is another expression for “your people” (Pss 28:9; 78:62; 94:14; 106:40).

title: Psalms 74:3–8
content: Like a guide, the psalmist points out to the Lord what took place during the destruction of Jerusalem in 586 BC.

title: Psalms 74:12
content: my king from ages past: The psalmist acknowledges God’s power and his historical bond with Israel (5:2; 44:4; 84:3).

title: Psalms 74:14
content: Leviathan: See 104:26; Job 3:8; 41:1, 12, 22, 31; Isa 27:1. Here, the creature’s multiple heads suggest a mythical monster.

title: Psalms 74:15
content: springs and streams to gush forth: God provided water in the desert for his people (see 68:8–9; Exod 17:6); he dried up the Red Sea (Exod 14:21) and the Jordan River (Josh 3:17).

title: Psalms 74:19–23
content: The poet urges God to act.

title: Psalms 75:1–10
content: This hymn of thanksgiving includes two direct messages from God that provide assurance of his justice (75:2–3, 10). The Lord rebukes arrogant people who defy him, promising to forcibly humble them (75:4–8). Together, the community and the psalmist respond with thanksgiving for God’s character (75:1, 9).

title: Psalms 75:2–8
content: The Lord will bring justice in his own time.

title: Psalms 75:4–5
content: The wicked arrogantly defy the heavens—the dwelling place of God. Through their boasting they insist that they are wiser than God.

title: Psalms 75:6
content: No creature has the right to rebel against its Creator.

title: Psalms 75:7–8
content: The Lord alone is the Judge, with the power to exalt and humble (see 1 Sam 2:7; Luke 1:52).

title: Psalms 76:1
content: The Greek version reads for the Assyrian.

title: Psalms 76:1–3
content: God’s victory over Zion’s enemies foreshadows his worldwide victory over all his enemies.

title: Psalms 76:1–12
content: This psalm appears to celebrate a victory. The victory might have been recent, such as over the Assyrians (see note on 76:title; see also Isa 37); or the psalm might be recalling God’s great acts of rescue in the past.

title: Psalms 76:3
content: God brings an end to the attacks of his enemies (see 46:9).

title: Psalms 76:4
content: The victorious king’s splendor, glory, and majesty are greater than anything in the created order (8:1; 29:4; 111:3).

title: Psalms 76:4–6
content: The psalmist praises God for his achievement and for his glorious majesty.

title: Psalms 76:7
content: The word translated feared (Hebrew nora’) is a wordplay on the word translated “glorious” in 76:4 (Hebrew na’or).

title: Psalms 76:7–9
content: The needy await their victorious God, while the wicked stand in fear of him.

title: Psalms 77:1–3
content: The night provides a special opportunity for prayer and meditation (77:6, 11; see 6:6; 16:7; 17:3; 30:5; 63:6; 119:55, 62, 148).

title: Psalms 77:1–20
content: The psalmist laments that God has turned away from him, even though he feels innocent. He reflects on his situation (77:3, 6, 12) and finds hope (see 25:5) in remembering God’s past deeds (77:11).

title: Psalms 77:3
content: I think of God: God’s people inevitably face difficult times, but recalling his mighty acts at the beginning of their relationship assures them of God’s commitment. • Feeling overwhelmed, the psalmist is unable to deal with the crisis (142:3; 143:4).

title: Psalms 77:4–6
content: As the psalmist meditates at night, he feels so disturbed that he cannot sleep or speak. He has pleasant memories of the past, but he cannot look beyond the present moment into the future.

title: Psalms 77:7
content: Feeling rejected (see 43:2), the psalmist asks if the situation is permanent.

title: Psalms 77:7–9
content: The psalmist questions his status before God.

title: Psalms 77:10
content: The psalmist fears that God’s hand of protection (44:3; 77:15; Exod 6:6) and favor (Pss 16:7–8; 110:1) is now against him for no apparent reason.

title: Psalms 77:10–12
content: The memories of God’s mighty works in the past fill the psalmist’s mind.

title: Psalms 77:13–15
content: This central section of the poem reflects on God as the holy and powerful redeemer.

title: Psalms 77:16
content: the Red Sea: The Canaanites attributed divine power to the sea, but God is the one who made the sea and uses it for his own purposes.

title: Psalms 78:1–8
content: The prologue is an invitation to learn wisdom.

title: Psalms 78:1–72
content: This wisdom psalm exhorts the people to learn wisdom and faithfully pass it on.

title: Psalms 78:2
content: The psalmist recites Israel’s story (78:5–72) in a parable in order to teach wisdom and insight. • Jesus quoted this verse to explain why he taught in parables (Matt 13:35).

title: Psalms 78:3–4
content: This story of what God has done should be told from generation to generation (see Deut 6:20–25; Prov 4:1–4).

title: Psalms 78:5–6
content: The telling of the story should motivate God’s people to obey what he commanded (Deut 6:4–9).

title: Psalms 78:7–8
content: God holds each generation responsible for its own response, which should be to maintain faith and hope (see 9:18; 27:14) and avoid being stubborn, rebellious, and unfaithful (see Deut 9:6–7; 10:16; 30:6; 31:27).

title: Psalms 78:9–11
content: Ephraim, the second son of Joseph, received a special blessing from Jacob (Gen 48:15–20; 49:22–26; Deut 33:13–17). The land that his descendants received included fertile valleys and strategic roads (Judg 8:2). However, the people of Ephraim did not live in obedience to God’s gracious covenant.

title: Psalms 78:12
content: The miracles are the ten plagues against Egypt that God performed during Israel’s captivity (Exod 7–12).

title: Psalms 78:12–16
content: The focus shifts from Ephraim (78:9–11) to Israel as a whole as the psalmist reflects on God’s power in Egypt (see 81:4–7) and in the wilderness.

title: Psalms 78:13
content: God divided the sea when Israel crossed through the Red Sea (see Exod 14–15).

title: Psalms 78:14
content: God used a cloud and a pillar of fire to guide and protect Israel in the wilderness (Exod 13:21–22).

title: Psalms 78:17–31
content: Israel rebelled in the wilderness despite God’s abundant provision.

title: Psalms 78:23–25
content: Abundance comes through the doors of heaven (Gen 8:2; 2 Kgs 7:2; Mal 3:10). • Israel ate manna for forty years in the wilderness (Exod 16:31–36; John 6:31).

title: Psalms 78:26–31
content: God powerfully satisfied the people’s desires, but they did not respond with gratitude or faith. Therefore, God exercised his justice.

title: Psalms 78:32–39
content: Israel’s rebellion resulted in God’s judgment, but even their short-lived and insincere repentance motivated God to exercise forbearance.

title: Psalms 78:33
content: An entire generation died in the wilderness (Num 14:22–23, 28–35).

title: Psalms 78:34
content: They repented: This demonstration of zeal was not sincere.

title: Psalms 78:34–39
content: Israel’s continued existence, in spite of the people’s rebellion and unbelief (78:7–8), was due to God’s compassion.

title: Psalms 78:35–39
content: The Israelites remembered the right doctrine (9:9; 91:1), but they did not allow God to change their hearts (Lev 26:41).

title: Psalms 78:40–55
content: The Israelites rebelled even though the Lord had rescued them from powerful plagues.

title: Psalms 78:56–64
content: Israel’s rebellion desecrated the Promised Land. The people built shrines to false gods and worshiped idols (78:58) during the period of the judges (e.g., Judg 2:11; 3:7, 17–18).

title: Psalms 78:60
content: God abandoned his dwelling at Shiloh because of the people’s idol worship (1 Sam 4:11; Jer 7:12).

title: Psalms 78:67
content: The tribe of Ephraim was not completely rejected, but God favored Judah (78:68).

title: Psalms 78:68–69
content: In the choice of Mount Zion instead of Shiloh as God’s sanctuary on earth, God moved from the north to the south (see Ps 69).

title: Psalms 78:70–72
content: The God who had turned against his own people (78:62) chose David, a shepherd (Gen 46:34; 1 Sam 16:10–11), to become their shepherd (Ps 78:52; cp. 23:1).

title: Psalms 79:1
content: your special possession: This phrase might refer to the land, the Temple (see 61:5), or the people (see 79:2; 78:71).

title: Psalms 79:1–4
content: The poet laments the desecration of the Temple and the success of the enemy.

title: Psalms 79:1–13
content: This lament describes the occasion of Jerusalem’s fall in 586 BC. The early history of Israel’s rebellions described in Ps 78 provoked God’s wrath, resulting in the desolation of Zion described here as the defilement of the Temple and the disgraced bodies that littered the landscape. The psalmist then prays for forgiveness and rescue (79:8–9), as well as for God to pay back the nation’s enemies (79:12–13). Other psalms lamenting the Exile include Pss 42–44, 102, 107, 126, 137.

title: Psalms 79:5–8
