content: The intensity of God’s judgment surprises the people; they cry out in despair for compassion, forgiveness, and relief. Verses 6–7 are repeated almost verbatim in Jer 10:25.

title: Psalms 79:6
content: The repentant among God’s people ask him to vent his anger not on them but on their wicked and unrepentant enemies.

title: Psalms 79:8
content: The people’s accumulation of past sins contributed to the Exile (2 Kgs 17:7–23; 24:3–4); however, the people perished because of their own sins (Jer 31:30; Ezek 18:20).

title: Psalms 79:9–11
content: The people ask God to rescue them. Although Israel’s sins caused the tragedy, the pagan nations must also be held responsible for the bloodshed.

title: Psalms 79:12
content: The Exile resulted in national suffering and in individual searching for the Lord. • pay back: See 1:6; 94:2; Jer 32:18. • The expression seven times signifies something complete. • Israel’s neighbors included Edom, Moab, and Ammon (see Ps 137:7; 2 Kgs 24:2; Obad 1).

title: Psalms 80:1
content: is unknown today.

title: Psalms 80:1–2
content: God is the Shepherd of Israel: See also 23:1; 28:9; 78:52–53. • radiant glory . . . power: These expressions (145:11) refer to God’s manifest presence.

title: Psalms 80:1–3
content: The psalmist urgently calls upon the Lord to act.

title: Psalms 80:1–19
content: This psalm of lament might originate with the remnant of the northern kingdom after its fall in 722 BC. The people call on God as their Shepherd and as the God of Heaven’s Armies in the hope that he will return to them and restore them. They remember the Exodus and their special relationship with the Lord and conclude with an expression of renewed commitment to him (80:18).

title: Psalms 80:3
content: This verse is repeated (with an increasing crescendo) in 80:7, 19.

title: Psalms 80:4–7
content: The people cry out for rescue from the shame of their recent defeat. The enemy’s victory is less devastating, however, than the knowledge that they themselves are objects of God’s wrath.

title: Psalms 80:8–9
content: Israel had been a prosperous grapevine (Gen 1:28; Gal 5:22–23) that God transplanted into the land of Canaan at the time of the conquest. However, the people forgot the source of their prosperity and chose to do evil (Isa 5:1–7; Hos 10:1).

title: Psalms 80:8–11
content: Israel has a glorious past, beginning with its redemption from Egypt.

title: Psalms 80:10–11
content: Solomon’s kingdom had extended west to the Mediterranean Sea and east to the Euphrates River (see 72:8–9; 89:25; 1 Kgs 4:21).

title: Psalms 80:12
content: broken down our walls: God no longer defended Israel (Isa 5:5).

title: Psalms 80:13
content: The surrounding nations were ceremonially unclean, like a wild boar or vicious wild animals.

title: Psalms 80:15
content: Israel was the son that God had brought out of Egypt (see Hos 11:1) and planted in the Holy Land.

title: Psalms 80:16–19
content: The community prays for God to change their desperate situation and restore them. They are still the Lord’s chosen people.

title: Psalms 80:17
content: The son of your choice was probably the northern kingdom of Israel, although it might allude to the king of David’s dynasty (110:1).

title: Psalms 81:1–3
content: As a prelude to the message of warning, the psalmist invites Israel to contemplate their God in song and dance.

title: Psalms 81:1–16
content: This warning message invites Israel to worship only the Lord and to enjoy the fullness of his blessing.

title: Psalms 81:2
content: An Israelite tambourine was a hand drum—a round frame covered with a skin, used as a percussion instrument during festivities, often to accompany dancing (68:25; 149:3; 150:4). • The sweet lyre and the harp, both stringed instruments, are the instruments most frequently mentioned in the psalms (e.g., 33:2; 57:8; 71:22; 150:3).

title: Psalms 81:3
content: The ram’s horn mustered armies and announced special holy days (47:5; 98:6). • new moon: The first day of the lunar month marked a festival.

title: Psalms 81:4–5
content: The festival, a time to celebrate and listen to the Lord, took place at God’s appointed time.

title: Psalms 81:5
content: for Israel: Literally for Joseph. The tribes of Ephraim and Manasseh (the sons of Joseph) are used here to refer to the entire nation of Israel.

title: Psalms 81:6–7
content: The Lord heard Israel’s cry in Egypt and rescued them from oppressive slavery.

title: Psalms 81:8–10
content: God pleads with his people to remember the covenant and the Ten Commandments.

title: Psalms 81:10
content: God emphasizes that he and no one else rescued Israel. • The nation should open its mouth wide to take in God’s word (cp. Deut 8:3; Ezek 3:1).

title: Psalms 81:11–16
content: The Lord helps Israel to understand that their failure was not because of his weakness.

title: Psalms 81:13–14
content: God wants to give his children his goodness, but only if they listen (Isa 1:18–19; 28:12; 48:18–19; see Deut 6:3). • God promises to subdue the enemies (Deut 9:3) of those who walk the paths of obedience and loyalty. He will also richly feed his people (Isa 1:19).

title: Psalms 82:1
content: God presides and stands ready to render judgment (see Isa 3:13). • heaven’s court: See Job 1:6.

title: Psalms 82:1–8
content: God condemns those who mistreat the helpless.

title: Psalms 82:2
content: Since justice marks God’s reign (89:4), he opposes favoring the wicked. So the psalmist is perplexed and cries out to God for justice (82:3–4, 8).

title: Psalms 82:5
content: The unjust oppressors cannot bring or restore order. They wander about in darkness, unmoved by circumstances even when the whole world order falls apart around them (cp. 11:3).

title: Psalms 82:6–7
content: The gods (see study notes on 29:1–2; 58:1), like mere mortals, cannot escape the judgment common to human rulers. Jesus quoted from this passage in John 10:34.

title: Psalms 82:8
content: The nations belong to God; he will take over the realms formerly ruled by local deities and give them to his people, just as he did with the Promised Land.

title: Psalms 83:1–4
content: The enemy has successfully intimidated God’s people, so the poet prays that the Lord will hear and act.

title: Psalms 83:1–18
content: This community lament asks God for rescue and victory. The terse poetry suggests difficult times. A powerful coalition desires to destroy Israel (83:1–4) and allies itself against God (83:5–8). Recalling the fate of others who came against Israel (83:9–12), the psalmist prays that the same will happen to these enemies (83:13–16) so that God will receive honor among them (83:17–18). It is unclear whether this psalm arose out of a specific historical instance of opposition by these nations, or if it is a poetic collage of nations representing Israel’s enemies.

title: Psalms 83:5–8
content: signed a treaty: The allies agreed to fight against God and his people. The nations that are named in the alliance were situated around Israel and Judah.

title: Psalms 83:6–7
content: The Edomites, descendants of Esau, were located to the southeast of Judah (see Gen 25:30; 32:3; 36:1–8). • Ishmaelites were desert-dwelling descendants of Hagar. • Moabites and Ammonites descended from Lot; both were located to the east of Israel and Judah. • The Hagrites were possibly located north of the Ammonites (1 Chr 5:10).

title: Psalms 83:7
content: The Gebalites probably came from Gebal/Byblos on the coast of Lebanon. • The Amalekites were located south of Israel in the Negev. • Philistia was southwest of Judah, by the Mediterranean Sea. • Tyre was a port city on the Mediterranean, northwest of Israel.

title: Psalms 83:8
content: Assyria was northeast of Israel and north of the Persian Gulf. • The descendants of Lot were the Moabites and the Ammonites (83:6–7).

title: Psalms 83:9–11
content: The Midianites, ruled by Zebah and Zalmunna and led by Oreb and Zeeb, were Israel’s enemy in the days of Gideon (Judg 7:1–8:5). Barak’s coalition defeated Sisera and Jabin (Judg 4).

title: Psalms 83:9–18
content: The psalmist prays that God will miraculously destroy the new coalition as he did three other enemies; doing so would bring him glory.

title: Psalms 83:12
content: The coalition’s motivation for wiping out Israel was to acquire the land (see Jer 3:19).

title: Psalms 83:13
content: tumbleweed . . . chaff: This dry plant material easily blows away (see Isa 17:13).

title: Psalms 83:14–15
content: fire . . . fierce storm . . . tempest: These are images of God’s manifestation in judgment (see Isa 29:6).

title: Psalms 84:1–4
content: The psalmist is far from the Temple. He turns toward it in hopeful reflection.

title: Psalms 84:1–12
content: The psalmist expresses his deep spiritual longing for God’s presence. He faints with longing as he reflects on the Temple and on pilgrims making the journey to Jerusalem (84:1–7). He prays for himself and for the community (84:8–9). The conclusion of the psalm (84:10–12) clarifies that the Temple represents God—the psalmist truly longs for God’s presence. He knows that God’s goodness is greater than life and that only God can give his people favor and honor (84:10–11).

title: Psalms 84:3
content: The poet envies the birds that have nesting places in and around the Temple.

title: Psalms 84:4
content: The priests and Temple personnel lived in the Temple.

title: Psalms 84:5
content: Travelers needed strength to meet the challenges of pilgrimage by foot along unpaved paths, in all kinds of weather and with the possibility of assaults.

title: Psalms 84:5–7
content: The pilgrimage to Jerusalem reenacted the Exodus, when God marvelously provided for his people (see 78:15–16; 105:41). The psalmist imagines the pains of travel turning to the joy of arrival.

title: Psalms 84:6
content: The Valley of Weeping probably refers to the anguish that lonely pilgrims endured (see 23:4), rather than to an actual location. • refreshing springs . . . autumn rains: Even when pilgrims feel totally exhausted, the prospect of drawing near to the Lord renews their spirits (cp. Isa 35:6–10; 41:18–20; 43:17–20; 49:10).

title: Psalms 84:9
content: Both kings and priests were anointed to dedicate them for service (see 132:17; Exod 28:41; 1 Sam 9:16; 16:1–13; cp. Isa 61:1; Acts 10:38).

title: Psalms 84:10
content: The psalmist viewed being in God’s presence as much better than being anywhere else.

title: Psalms 84:11
content: Some people worshiped the sun as a god, but the true God provides all that anyone needs.

title: Psalms 85:1
content: God restored the fortunes of Israel by bringing the nation back from exile (see 14:7; 126:1).

title: Psalms 85:1–5
content: Though the psalmist gratefully acknowledges God’s goodness, he also asks God whether his wrath will last forever.

title: Psalms 85:1–13
content: The psalmist leads the postexilic community in lament and prayer for full redemption. He ponders God’s past rescue of Israel from exile (85:1–3), longs for greater evidence of God’s goodness, and leads the community in prayer for full restoration (85:4–7). God responds with a message of peace (85:8–9), and the psalm concludes with a lyrical outburst at the grandeur of God’s salvation (85:10–13).

title: Psalms 85:2
content: When God forgave the guilt of their sins, he gave the people the possibility of fellowship with him (see 32:5).

title: Psalms 85:6–7
content: This prayer for renewal is based on God’s unfailing love for his people.

title: Psalms 85:8–9
content: When God the Lord speaks, his faithful people listen. He promises them peace, meaning wholeness and well-being (see 37:11). They fear the Lord and know that he and his salvation are near to them. • The Lord does not tolerate foolish ways, such as those that resulted in the Exile.

title: Psalms 85:10–13
content: In the glorious world of renewal and salvation, all the qualities of God’s care—love, truth, righteousness, and peace—come together and transform the created order into something new (see Isa 32:15–20).

title: Psalms 85:13
content: Righteousness is like a messenger preparing the world for God’s coming in response to the prayers of his people (85:4–7; 89:14).

title: Psalms 86:1
content: This is the only Psalm connected to David in the third book.

title: Psalms 86:1–4
content: God’s devoted servant prays for mercy. The psalmist sees himself as a member of the covenant community and as a citizen of the world.

title: Psalms 86:1–17
content: The psalmist invokes God’s help and praises his character in a lament prompted by the presence of evil (86:14, 17). All people will worship the gracious and almighty God (86:8–10). To this end, the poet commits himself to a lifestyle of ethical integrity (86:11) and praising the Lord (86:12–13). The last stanza contrasts the qualities of evil people with those of the Lord (86:14–17).

title: Psalms 86:5
content: The psalmist recounts the catalog of divine perfections (Exod 34:6–7), especially God’s willingness to forgive sin (see Pss 32:5; 85:2; 145:7–10).

title: Psalms 86:5–7
content: The psalmist appeals to God to remain true to his character, which is the basis for hope.

title: Psalms 86:8–10
content: All the nations must submit themselves to the Lord and worship him (45:17; 117:1; 148:7–11).

title: Psalms 86:11
content: The poet responds to the Lord by seeking faithful instruction in the truth. • An individual with purity of heart has integrity and wholeness (see 73:1).

title: Psalms 86:12–13
content: In anticipation of God’s rescue, the psalmist praises him and trusts in his goodness.

title: Psalms 86:14–17
content: The arrogant exist both inside and outside the community. The psalmist asks for a vision of God’s character; God is so great that just a glimpse of his goodness will shut the mouths of the wicked.

title: Psalms 86:15
content: God has mercy on his people (51:1); he is gracious (25:6), slow to get angry (103:8; 145:8), and filled with unfailing love and faithfulness (Hebrew khesed and ’emeth; 143:1). This verse repeats a theme first expressed in Exod 34:7; Num 14:18 (cp. Pss 103:8; 145:8; Neh 9:17; Joel 2:13; Jon 4:2).

title: Psalms 87:1
content: Jerusalem was Israel’s capital and the location of the Temple, God’s earthly palace (see Ps 84).

title: Psalms 87:1–7
content: This psalm envisions Jerusalem as the city of God where all the nations are citizens.

title: Psalms 87:4
content: As great as Zion is, it will be even greater when it becomes an international city where believers from all the nations have citizenship. • God keeps a record of all who confess him as their Lord (Dan 7:10; Rev 13:8).

title: Psalms 87:5–6
content: Jerusalem becomes the international city where all God’s children are citizens.

title: Psalms 88:1
content: might be a sage from Solomon’s time (1 Kgs 4:31), a descendant of Judah (1 Chr 2:6), or a member of the Levitical family charged with singing at the Temple (1 Chr 15:17; 2 Chr 5:12).

title: Psalms 88:1–5
content: The psalmist calls on the Lord for salvation.

title: Psalms 88:1–18
content: In this lament, the psalmist sees himself as cast out from God’s presence. At first, he calls on the Lord. When he finds no relief from his suffering, he presents three charges against God (88:6–7, 8–12, 13–17).

title: Psalms 88:6–7
content: In his first charge, the psalmist blames the Lord for his demise. God’s overpowering anger did not make sense. • The phrase the darkest depths implies the place of the dead (143:3; see Lam 3:6) or the depths of the sea (Pss 68:22; 69:1–2).

title: Psalms 88:8–12
content: In his second charge, the psalmist claims that God has isolated him and caused his loneliness (cp. 31:11; 38:11). Loneliness was a curse in a culture where relationships were more important than personal achievement.

title: Psalms 88:13–17
content: In his third charge, the psalmist accuses the Lord of rejecting him. The force and apparent cruelty of the psalmist’s suffering overwhelm him.

title: Psalms 88:18
content: The psalmist restates his second and first charges.

title: Psalms 89:1
content: God’s unfailing love gives reason to celebrate forever.

title: Psalms 89:1–52
content: Book Three (Pss 73–89) begins and ends with weighty questions. Though Ps 89 begins with a praise-filled account of how the Lord exalted the throne of David (89:1–37), the psalmist protests the Lord’s apparent rejection of his covenant with David (89:38–51; see 2 Sam 7:8–16).

title: Psalms 89:title
content: was a wise man (1 Kgs 4:31; cp. Ps 88:title).

title: Psalms 89:3
content: The Lord has sworn by his own holiness (89:35; see 110:4).

title: Psalms 89:3–4
content: The psalmist restates God’s covenant with David (see also 89:19–37).

title: Psalms 89:5
content: Praise for God’s greatness (see 8:1) comes from the inhabitants of heaven who witness his faithfulness.

title: Psalms 89:5–8
content: God is the absolute standard of faithfulness, commitment, and order. The angelic beings and the heavens testify to his constancy.

title: Psalms 89:6
content: mightiest angel: Literally son of God (see study note on 29:1–2).

title: Psalms 89:9–10
content: The Lord rules over all parts of the created order, including evil. • You scattered your enemies: The Lord will crush (Luke 1:51) evil powers that oppose him (Ps 2:1–3). • with your mighty arm: This phrase represents God’s strength (89:13).

title: Psalms 89:9–13
content: In this hymn, the psalmist celebrates God’s comprehensive and powerful sovereignty over nature.

title: Psalms 89:12
content: Mount Tabor was in northern Israel. Mount Hermon formed the extreme northern border of the nation.

title: Psalms 89:14–18
content: God rules wisely over creation. The qualities of righteousness, justice, and faithfulness fit the profile of a wise ruler. The happy people who live under his rule enjoy his protection.

title: Psalms 89:15–16
content: Those who are wise worship God, walk in his light, rejoice in their relationship with him, and exult in his character.

title: Psalms 89:17–18
content: The Lord protects his people with the same power by which he established the created order.

title: Psalms 89:19–37
content: The Lord chose David as his son and as king of Israel (see 2:4–6; 2 Sam 7:8–16) to provide protection for his people.

title: Psalms 89:20
content: I have anointed him: This is the verb from which anointed one (Hebrew mashiakh, “messiah”) is derived.

title: Psalms 89:26–29
content: The Lord adopted David as his son, appointed him as his commander over the nations, and promised to support him forever. Verse 26 recalls a verse from David’s song of praise (2 Sam 22:47).

title: Psalms 89:27
content: David would be the most eminent of earthly kings. The Hebrew word translated mightiest is the same as the designation for God as “Most High” (‘elyon).

title: Psalms 89:29
content: The Lord writes his faithfulness in heaven, on the canvas of his universe (see 89:2). He records his commitment to the dynasty of David in the same way.

title: Psalms 89:30–37
content: The Lord disciplines but does not reject his erring children. He foresees violation of trust and subsequent punishment, but he commits himself to uphold the covenant. His fidelity to David corresponds to his faithfulness to the created order.

title: Psalms 89:35
content: holiness: The Lord is wholly distinct from the created order (22:3); his character is totally pure. He does as he pleases (115:3), and he chooses to be faithful (89:1; 115:1); therefore, he cannot lie.

title: Psalms 89:38
content: You are angry: The harshness of God’s wrath perplexes the psalmist.

title: Psalms 89:40
content: broken down the walls: The Lord’s people are completely vulnerable.

title: Psalms 89:42
content: Although the Lord promised to strengthen David, he secretly strengthened David’s enemies.

title: Psalms 89:46–47
content: The psalmist wonders if he will live to see the end of the Lord’s anger. Our lifetimes are short, like a day in the Lord’s sight (90:4, 10).

title: Psalms 89:50
content: The phrase your servants refers to the community loyal to the Lord.

title: Psalms 89:52
content: This doxology concludes all of Book Three (Pss 73–89); it is not intended to be read as part of Ps 89. It stands in stark contrast to the anguish and questioning of Ps 89. Cp. 41:13; 106:48.

title: Psalms 90:1
content: led God’s people from slavery in Egypt to Mount Sinai, where he received the law and established God’s covenant with Israel. • the man of God: Moses enjoyed a special relationship with God (Deut 33:1).

title: Psalms 90:1–2
content: The Lord becomes the home of the godly; he has provided shelter for countless generations. The word translated home is not used frequently in the Psalter. It describes a place of safety where the Lord meets his needy people and cares for them (68:5; 71:3).

title: Psalms 90:1–17
content: Although the Lord’s people have made their home in him for generations, their sin widens the gap between them and their infinite Lord. The Lord’s wrath against a person’s sin might last a lifetime and yet be only a taste of his displeasure with sin. This lamentable situation calls the community to seek the Lord’s light. Taking the first step means seeking restoration with the Lord on the basis of his compassion and love (90:13–14). He alone makes his servants glad and blesses their future generations (90:16–17).

title: Psalms 90:2
content: The Lord is the eternal God. • The Lord gave birth to the earth by creating it.

title: Psalms 90:3–6
content: Unlike God, humans are mortal and transitory.

title: Psalms 90:7–10
content: Sinners cannot escape God’s wrath because the Lord sees their sins. Their fleeting lives are filled with afflictions.

title: Psalms 90:9–10
content: A groan of sorrow (Ezek 2:10) sums up a life spent in facing the consequences of sin. • Humans cause trouble (see Ps 10:6) and receive pain in return.

title: Psalms 90:11–12
content: In the search for wisdom, no one can comprehend the Lord (see Isa 40:13). The appropriate human response to the Lord is godly fear (see Ps 60:4). The Lord alone can teach humans to follow the path of wisdom (25:4–6).

title: Psalms 90:13
content: The phrase your servants refers to the community of those loyal to the Lord.

title: Psalms 90:13–17
content: The psalmist prays for the Lord’s favor and restoration.

title: Psalms 90:15
content: The psalmist calls upon the Lord to give the people gladness to replace their mourning (see 92:4–5).

title: Psalms 90:16
content: The children represent future generations in contrast to the generations past (90:1).

title: Psalms 90:17
content: Humans waste their efforts unless the Lord makes them successful (44:3).

title: Psalms 91:1
content: The Most High is an ancient title that expresses the Lord’s exalted status as the ruler and protector of the godly (see Gen 14:19).

title: Psalms 91:1–2
content: The Lord is an ancient shelter (see 90:1), open to those who seek refuge in him.

title: Psalms 91:1–16
content: This wisdom psalm expresses confidence in the Almighty God, who provides a shelter for those who take refuge in him. They receive redemption, life, and glory from the Lord, who loves and cares for those who seek him.

title: Psalms 91:3
content: God protects the godly from deadly disease and even a destructive word.

title: Psalms 91:3–4
content: The psalmist invites the godly to trust in the Lord and find protection in him.

title: Psalms 91:4
content: The armor might refer to a body shield, while protection refers to a small shield worn on the arm.

title: Psalms 91:5–8
content: The godly should not be afraid, because the Lord watches over them. These promises do not guarantee an escape from trouble, but they create an expectation of the Lord’s goodness.

title: Psalms 91:6
content: The reference to disease represents any kind of affliction.

title: Psalms 91:9–13
content: The poet again invites the godly to seek refuge in the Lord and enjoy the benefits of divine protection.

title: Psalms 91:11
content: he will order his angels: Satan cited these words when he tempted Jesus (Matt 4:6; Luke 4:10–11), but God makes this promise for those who obey him (Ps 91:14), not for those who arrogantly test him (Matt 4:4, 7).

title: Psalms 91:14
content: Those who love the Lord will obey him (Deut 30:20; 1 Jn 5:3) and seek his protection (Pss 91:1; 145:18).

title: Psalms 91:14–16
content: The godly can trust the Lord’s protection and provision.

title: Psalms 91:15
content: The Lord promises to answer the prayers of his people. • The Psalter often speaks of people honoring the Lord (50:15); here, God promises to honor the godly who risk everything for his sake (62:7; 71:21; 84:11).

title: Psalms 91:16
content: A long life on earth represents just a small part of the Lord’s goodness and eternal friendship (23:6).

title: Psalms 92:1
content: Jewish tradition assigned one psalm to each day of the week: Sunday (Ps 24), Monday (Ps 48), Tuesday (Ps 82), Wednesday (Ps 94), Thursday (Ps 81), Friday (Ps 93), and the Sabbath (Ps 92). This is the only psalm that indicates this use in its title.

title: Psalms 92:1–3
content: The psalmist offers praise and thanksgiving for God’s unfailing love and faithfulness.

title: Psalms 92:1–15
content: Thanksgiving and praise open this psalm. The Lord—the Most High—is faithful and just in discerning between the godly and the wicked. The godly will enjoy a glorious, vigorous future, while the wicked will perish. The wise see and understand the Lord’s works as they reveal his justice (92:6–7, 11, 15). The wicked, like grass, are quickly destroyed (92:7–10).

title: Psalms 92:4–5
content: The Lord acts and the psalmist responds in praise (92:4). God’s actions spring from his thoughts (92:5).

title: Psalms 92:4–7
content: Fools perish because they do not understand the Lord’s marvelous works and eternal plans.

title: Psalms 92:5–6
content: The Lord’s thoughts do not make sense to the simpleton or the fool, the immoral person who desires no wisdom (Prov 1:22; 10:23).

title: Psalms 92:7
content: Even when the ungodly seem to grow luxuriantly (73:3–5), they have no future (92:9; see 1:6; 90:5–6; Isa 40:6–8).

title: Psalms 92:8
content: The transcendent Lord stays above the world of human experience. From this exalted place, he rules and judges (7:7), celebrates his victories (68:18; see Ps 47), comes to rescue the needy (102:19), brings an end to the wicked (92:7–8), and receives praise (148:1).

title: Psalms 92:8–10
content: The glory of the Lord provides the reason for the poet’s renewed strength and glory, and for the imminent defeat of the enemy.

title: Psalms 92:10
content: as strong as a wild ox: The Lord allows the psalmist to share his exaltation (92:8), thus ensuring victory.

title: Psalms 92:11–15
content: The psalmist understands the Lord’s mighty acts. He shares in the glory of the wise of heart.

title: Psalms 92:12
content: Carvings of palm trees (1 Kgs 6:29, 32, 35; 7:36) adorned the Temple, and builders made rich use of cedars (1 Kgs 5:6). The trees represent the godly, who are planted in the very courts of the Temple.

title: Psalms 92:13
content: The Temple area consisted of the Lord’s own house and the courts that surrounded it.

title: Psalms 92:15
content: There is no evil in him! The Lord is consistently just; he rightly judges everyone (see Zeph 3:5).

title: Psalms 93:1
content: robed in majesty: The Lord stands victorious both before and after battle (see 45:3).

title: Psalms 93:1–5
content: The everlasting Lord gloriously establishes his kingship (cp. Pss 47, 99–100).

title: Psalms 93:1–100.5
content: These psalms challenge the doubts created by the Exile (see Ps 89) and answer the questions asked in 90:11, 13. The Lord has established a kingdom (Ps 93) that is characterized by the punishment of the wicked (Ps 94), reverent obedience among his people (Ps 95), justice for the poor (Ps 96), celebration in Zion (Ps 97), salvation for Israel (Ps 98), holiness (Ps 99), and praise (Ps 100).

title: Psalms 93:3–4
content: God’s victory over natural chaos gives the psalmist confidence that the Lord will also defeat his present enemies (cp. Jer 46:8; 47:2).

title: Psalms 93:5
content: Through his stable rule and royal laws, the Lord orders the world. • Your reign (literally your house): The house from which God reigns might be the Lord’s heavenly palace or the earthly Temple.

title: Psalms 94:1–7
content: After the community falls victim to the wicked (94:5–7), they pray that the Lord will render justice (see 7:11; 9:12).

title: Psalms 94:1–23
content: This plea for the Lord’s justice includes both communal and individual expressions of lament (94:1–7, 16–23). The psalmist gives voice to the pain and suffering caused by the wicked, but he also depicts the comfort and stability of the Lord’s protection. He calls on the Lord to avenge the needy against the arrogant and foolish, he rebukes such people for their folly (94:8–11), and he pronounces a blessing on the wise (94:12–15).

title: Psalms 94:2
content: Just as the Lord’s enemies rise up against him and his people (3:7; 93:3), he must arise and make retribution against the enemy (see 79:12; Isa 65:6).

title: Psalms 94:6
content: widows . . . foreigners . . . orphans: The Lord’s law protects needy people (Deut 24:17; 27:19), but they remain vulnerable in society.

title: Psalms 94:7
content: The wicked think that they can get away with their vile acts and speech, foolishly assuming that God isn’t looking or doesn’t care.

title: Psalms 94:8–11
content: The psalmist rebukes human folly.

title: Psalms 94:9
content: It is preposterous that those with ears and eyes would imagine their Creator to be deaf and blind.

title: Psalms 94:10
content: punishes: This word also carries the idea of “warns” (2:10), “disciplines” (6:1; 94:12), or “instructs” (16:7). The Lord disciplines his people to purify their character (Prov 3:11–12; Heb 12:6–11). He punishes his enemies by giving them what they deserve (Ps 1:6; Rom 6:23).

title: Psalms 94:11
content: While the Lord’s thoughts are deep, people’s thoughts are worthless (cp. 92:5; 1 Cor 3:20).

title: Psalms 94:12–15
content: True to his nature, the Lord rewards those who live by his wise instruction and makes them happy according to his promises.

title: Psalms 94:13
content: God’s relief includes his comfort and rescue.

title: Psalms 94:14
content: Even when it seems that he has, the Lord will not reject his people.

title: Psalms 94:16
content: Only God has the power to stand up to the wicked (see 2:2).

title: Psalms 94:16–23
content: The psalmist’s prayer resumes (see 94:1–7) with a desperate cry for the Lord’s justice; it concludes with the hopeful expectation that evil will end.

title: Psalms 94:18–19
content: The psalmist’s experience of slipping contrasts with God’s promise to stand with him (94:12–13; see 15:5; 93:1).

title: Psalms 95:1–11
content: This call to worship urges the people to respond to the Lord, the Shepherd, and to follow him faithfully. The previous generation, who refused to obey, did not receive the blessings of the Promised Land.

title: Psalms 95:3
content: above all gods: The psalmist refutes idolatry and paganism (96:4–6; 135:15–18; see also Isa 46:5–7).

title: Psalms 95:3–5
content: The Lord is the great King over the whole universe.

title: Psalms 95:4–5
content: The whole created order owes its existence to the sovereign Lord alone—not to various gods.

title: Psalms 95:6–7
content: The great King cares for his people as a shepherd cares for his flock (Isa 40:11). • The Lord our maker, the Creator of heaven and earth, also made a people for himself (Isa 45:9–12; 51:12–16).

title: Psalms 95:8
content: To harden your hearts means to be stubborn and resist the Lord’s grace (see Num 20:2–13; see also Matt 13:3–23; John 12:37–43; Eph 4:17–32; Heb 3:6–19; 4:6–11).

title: Psalms 95:8–11
content: If people want to enter into the Lord’s rest, they need to respond immediately (see Heb 3:7–4:11).

title: Psalms 95:9
content: Israel’s ancestors . . . saw the wonders of the Lord, but they foolishly did not try to grasp their significance (see 92:5–6).

title: Psalms 95:11
content: The generation of Israel that wandered in the wilderness for forty years failed to enter the place of rest that Israel enjoyed after the conquest of the land (1 Kgs 8:56; see Deut 12:9). The Lord promised them the land and gave it to them (Isa 28:12), but they did not obey him (Isa 28:1). The warning reminds every generation of the need to obey in faith. • The rest that God provides includes peace, provision, and protection (Ps 132:14–18). The author of Hebrews challenged a new generation to enter the rest provided by Jesus Christ (Heb 3:7–4:13).

title: Psalms 96:1
content: Three psalms open with the exhortation to sing a new song (Pss 96, 98, 149); the song celebrates the Lord’s universal kingship (see 33:3).

title: Psalms 96:1–13
content: This psalm establishes the Lord’s universal kingship (see Ps 93) and prepares for the coming of the Lord to bring justice and righteousness into the world. The psalmist invites everyone to worship the Lord (96:1–3), the glorious Creator of all the earth (96:4–6), because worship is due to him alone (96:7–9). The universe joins in praise as the righteous Judge establishes a new order (96:10–13). • This psalm (along with 105:1–15; 106:1, 47–48) is included in David’s song of praise recorded in 1 Chr 16:1–43.

title: Psalms 96:4
content: Great is the Lord! . . . most worthy of praise: With this refrain, the poet exalts the Lord over all the gods (95:3) and nations (99:2). He inspires awe more than anyone or anything else (76:7, 12; 89:7; 99:3; 111:9). He is beyond human possession or comprehension. The story of what he does to redeem his people causes them to praise him.

title: Psalms 96:4–6
content: The gods of the nations are as nothing before the glorious and majestic Creator of the earth.

title: Psalms 96:5
content: The Lord made the heavens, an even greater task than creating the earth. The idols, made by human hands (115:4), created nothing.

title: Psalms 96:6
content: Honor and majesty: The Lord is glorious (96:6; 104:1; 148:13), and so are his works in nature (8:1) and in redemption (111:3; 145:5).

title: Psalms 96:7
content: nations of the world (literally families of the nations): Families and clans represent subdivisions of the nations (see Gen 12:3). • The nations must respond to the Lord’s glory (Pss 8:1; 19:1–4; 24:7).

title: Psalms 96:8
content: The courts of God’s sanctuary were usually off-limits to non-Jewish people. In this psalm the nations of the world—the non-Jews—are invited in (65:4; 84:2, 10; 100:4; 116:19; 135:2; Isa 1:12).

title: Psalms 96:9
content: Worshipers should tremble in awe (96:4; see 18:7–15; 97:4) at the splendor of the Lord’s majesty and holiness (Heb 12:25).

title: Psalms 96:10
content: The Lord’s coming means the end of injustice. He rules fairly (9:8; 96:13; 98:9) and inaugurates an era of harmony and order not experienced since Eden. • The Lord’s reign over the world is founded on the strong pillars of “righteousness and justice” (89:14), so it cannot be shaken (cp. 11:3).

title: Psalms 96:11–13
content: The psalmist exhorts the created order to respond with joy to the news of the Lord’s coming. Cp. a similar theme in 98:7–9.

title: Psalms 96:12
content: All of nature will experience renewal in God’s presence (65:13; 72:6, 16; Isa 44:23; 55:12; Rom 8:21–22).

title: Psalms 97:1
content: The farthest coastlands represent the most remote parts of the world.

title: Psalms 97:1–12
content: God is greatly exalted over the gods and over all the earth. Awe-inspiring phenomena accompany his coming. Even the created order is visibly affected and the wicked perish, but the people of Zion love his coming and rejoice.

title: Psalms 97:2–4
content: Dark clouds . . . Fire . . . lightning: This language shows that the Lord is coming in judgment.

title: Psalms 97:5–7
content: The created order stirs at the coming of its King. He alone deserves worship.

title: Psalms 97:6
content: As the Lord enters the world, the testimony of his righteousness resounds from above (50:6). • Every nation will view the open display of the Lord’s glory (see 8:1; 19:1–4a; 24:7; Isa 40:5).

title: Psalms 97:7
content: At the Lord’s coming, when every god must bow to him, those who worship other gods will face their own folly (see 95:3–5).

title: Psalms 97:8–12
content: Jerusalem rejoices at the news of the Lord’s coming, for he brings justice and rescues the upright of heart.

title: Psalms 97:11
content: The godly people of integrity (see Prov 2:7, 21; 3:32; 11:6, 11; 14:2), whose hearts are right, maintain a relationship with the Lord and with others (Pss 94:15; 125:4). The wicked plan the downfall of the godly (11:2), but the Lord rescues them (11:1; 36:10). Then the sorrows of the godly turn to joy and praise (32:11; 64:10; 111:1; 119:7).

title: Psalms 98:1–9
content: This psalm celebrates the Lord’s kingship. The Lord is Israel’s true King, its champion and savior. His people sing a new song celebrating his victorious power and faithfulness to them. The Lord displays his righteous rule to all the nations throughout the earth, which will culminate in a worldwide kingdom of justice (98:2, 9). Consequently, all the earth must worship and rejoice together because the Lord is coming (98:4–6).

title: Psalms 98:2–3
content: The Lord makes known his righteousness and faithfulness (see also Isa 52:10).

title: Psalms 98:4–6
content: The psalmist invites the whole earth to worship the King (see 96:1).

title: Psalms 98:6
content: The Temple musicians used trumpets to call people together for meetings (cp. 81:3).

title: Psalms 98:7–9
content: The created order is personified as rejoicing at the coming of the righteous Judge (see 93:3–4; 96:11–13).

title: Psalms 99:1
content: It is fitting to tremble and quake in response to the Lord’s holiness (see 96:9). • The throne between the cherubim refers to the cover of the Ark of the Covenant (Exod 25:17–22).

title: Psalms 99:1–5
content: The Lord is the holy and righteous King (Isa 6:1–5). Mount Zion, the location of the Lord’s Temple, metaphorically stands as the highest point on earth (Ps 113:4; Isa 2:2; 6:1). From this summit, the Great King (Ps 47:2) can see, rule over, and receive praise from all nations and peoples.

title: Psalms 99:1–9
content: The psalmist calls the nations to worship the Lord, the king of the earth who rules from Zion.

title: Psalms 99:4
content: The qualities of the Lord’s rule include strength, justice, love, fairness, and righteousness (see 93:4; 97:2, 6–7, 12; 98:2–3, 9; 138:6).

title: Psalms 99:6
content: Moses and Samuel were great models and leaders who had prayed on behalf of the Lord’s people (Exod 32:31–32; 1 Sam 12:23).

title: Psalms 99:6–8
content: God showed favor by responding to his people in the past, while holding sinners accountable.

title: Psalms 99:7
content: The Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron from the pillar of cloud (Exod 33:9; Num 12:5–6), and for a time, the people responded to the revelation.

title: Psalms 100:1–5
content: This psalm calls all nations to come to Jerusalem to worship the Lord and acknowledge his goodness to Israel.

title: Psalms 100:3
content: The Lord is the one who determines who his people are. • the sheep of his pasture: God will guide and protect his people (23:1, 4).

title: Psalms 100:4
content: Gates and courts were part of the Temple in Jerusalem.

title: Psalms 101:1–8
content: This hymn expresses a commitment to live with integrity and to avoid evil. Jesus meets this ideal.

title: Psalms 101:2
content: in my own home (literally in my house): This commitment to integrity might refer to private life at home. Some interpreters view my house as referring to the king’s palace; the commitment would then refer to the policies of his administration. • Leading a life of integrity means choosing a wise lifestyle.

title: Psalms 101:4–5
content: The psalmist hates what the Lord hates (Prov 6:16–19; see Pss 5:5; 11:4–5). • Perverse ideas come from corrupt human hearts (cp. 18:26).

title: Psalms 101:6
content: The psalmist surrounds himself with people who are also committed to integrity (101:2).

title: Psalms 101:7–8
content: The psalmist commits himself to ridding his house and the city of the Lord—representing the entire kingdom—of all evil.

title: Psalms 102:1–2
content: The psalmist appeals to the Lord not to turn away (or hide your face). Israel experienced his turning his face away during their exile.

title: Psalms 102:1–28
content: A frail and afflicted human being prays for the Lord’s compassion on Jerusalem and for his presence with its inhabitants.

title: Psalms 102:3
content: Smoke is an image of transitory life (37:20; 68:2). • The psalmist’s bones represent his whole being (see 6:2; 34:19–22).

title: Psalms 102:4
content: Like dried grass, the psalmist senses his life ebbing away.

title: Psalms 102:5
content: skin and bones: The psalmist has wasted away because of his anguish (see 102:9; 109:24).

title: Psalms 102:6
content: The owl was associated with ruin and desolation (Isa 34:11, 15).

title: Psalms 102:7–8
content: The psalmist cannot sleep (see 63:6–8). Like a bird on the roof, he feels isolated from both friends (see 88:8) and enemies.

title: Psalms 102:10
content: The psalmist blames the Lord for his troubles.

title: Psalms 102:11
content: The psalmist’s existence seems empty and transitory (102:4; 109:23; 144:4).

title: Psalms 102:12
content: forever . . . to every generation: The frailty of humans (102:3–11) contrasts with the permanence of the Lord.

title: Psalms 102:12–17
content: The topic changes from the psalmist’s miseries to the Lord’s glory. A vision of the Lord’s compassionate kingship gives him confidence in Zion’s future.

title: Psalms 102:13
content: Now is the time for the Lord to restore Jerusalem from exile (see 75:2; Jer 29:10; Dan 9:1–19).

title: Psalms 102:15–16
content: When the Lord arises (102:13), the nations will tremble with fear because they will see his glory (see 8:1; 19:1–4a; 24:7). The rebuilding of Zion and the Temple portray God’s glory and fulfill this promise. An even greater fulfillment will come with the New Jerusalem (Rev 21).

title: Psalms 102:17
content: The people of Israel were destitute (or naked) during the Exile.

title: Psalms 102:18
content: Let this be recorded: The written record stands as a memorial to the Lord’s goodness.

title: Psalms 102:18–22
content: The Lord will have mercy; Jews and Gentiles alike will worship him.

title: Psalms 102:19
content: The heavenly sanctuary refers to God’s holy place on high (see 92:8–10).

title: Psalms 102:22
content: The multitudes—both Jews and Gentiles—will join in the worship of the Lord (see 96:7, 9; 106:48; Isa 2:2–4; 43:10–13; 57:15; 60:3–7).

title: Psalms 102:23–28
content: Although the psalmist suffers in the present, he bases his hope for the future on the Lord’s past faithfulness.

title: Psalms 102:24
content: The psalmist draws a contrast between his days (102:23) and God’s years (cp. 90:4).

title: Psalms 102:25–27
content: In contrast with the permanence of the Creator, the created order will wear out like a piece of clothing (see Isa 40:28). • The writer to the Hebrews describes this passage as having been addressed to Jesus, the Son (Heb 1:10–12).

title: Psalms 102:28
content: The Lord’s presence provides the basis for the security and happiness of his people (23:6).

title: Psalms 103:1–2
content: Let all that I am praise the Lord: Pss 103 and 104 each open and close with this commitment (103:1–2, 22; 104:1, 35; see also 146:1).

title: Psalms 103:1–6
content: The psalmist offers praise for the Lord’s goodness.

title: Psalms 103:1–22
content: This psalm celebrates the Lord’s perfection, compassion, forgiveness, and goodness.

title: Psalms 103:7–8
content: The Lord revealed himself to Moses in distinctive ways that ensured his relationship with his people (see Exod 34:6–7; Num 14:18).

title: Psalms 103:9
content: If the Lord were to constantly accuse or remain angry forever, no one would be left (see Isa 54:7–8; 57:16).

title: Psalms 103:11–12
content: The Lord’s love and forgiveness are infinite and complete.

title: Psalms 103:13
content: The Lord is like a father to his children: This analogy forms the basis for Jesus’ teaching about God’s fatherhood (see Matt 5:43–48; 6:1; 10:19–20; 12:50; Luke 6:36; 12:29–32; John 8:31–59; 15:1–8; see also 2 Sam 7:14; Jer 3:19; 31:9; Mal 1:6; 2 Cor 6:16–18).

title: Psalms 103:14–16
content: The Lord compassionately cares for frail humans (see 37:2; 90:5; 92:7; 102:4; Isa 40:6–8).

title: Psalms 103:17–19
content: the love of the Lord remains forever: The Lord’s kingdom is everlasting, so he commits himself to his people across many generations.

title: Psalms 103:18
content: To obey God means to be faithful and loyal to him.

title: Psalms 103:20–21
content: The psalmist exhorts the Lord’s angels, his servants and messengers, to praise the Lord.

title: Psalms 103:22
content: God’s kingdom extends over all things, so all things are called to praise the Lord. • The concluding phrase takes us back to 103:1–2.

title: Psalms 104:1
content: Let all that I am praise the Lord: Pss 103 and 104 each open and close with this commitment to praise (103:1–2, 22; 104:1, 35). • how great you are! This acclamation expresses praise for rescue (see also 35:27; 40:16; 70:4).

title: Psalms 104:1–35
content: This creation hymn (see also Pss 8, 33, 145) exalts God’s goodness and majesty. The psalmist reflects on the present world, the original creation, and a future new creation. He sees both creations as marvelously and wisely made (cp. 139:14), as the work of the Lord’s Spirit (104:30; Gen 1:2; 2 Cor 3:6).

title: Psalms 104:2–4
content: The psalmist interacts with two of the days of creation (see Gen 1:1–8), when God created the heavens and light.

title: Psalms 104:3
content: This poetic portrayal envisions the clouds as beams that support heaven.

title: Psalms 104:4
content: Wind and lightning are seen as divine messengers. The Lord uses weather phenomena as he desires (77:17–18; 78:26; 135:7; 148:5–6). • The psalmist interacts with day three of creation (Gen 1:9–13). The Lord is master of water and earth.

title: Psalms 104:6
content: At first, water covered the earth.

title: Psalms 104:7
content: The Lord created dry ground on day three of creation (Gen 1:9–13).

title: Psalms 104:8
content: The earth originates in God’s will.

title: Psalms 104:9
content: The Lord set a firm boundary for the seas to protect the land. God’s sovereignty over sea and land was an argument against the existence of Baal, whom the Canaanites celebrated as victorious over the waters (see Ps 29).

title: Psalms 104:9–10
content: The Lord reigns over all bodies of water, including those on land. He replaced chaotic waters with order and abundance, and the earth became a splendid place for animals and humans, with water refreshing the ground, the birds, and the animals.

title: Psalms 104:11–18
content: The psalmist celebrates animal, plant, and human life, as well as the Lord’s abundant provision for all of it (Gen 1:9–30).

title: Psalms 104:14
content: people to use: People are the managers of the created order, and they receive nourishment from the work of their hands.

title: Psalms 104:15
content: While both can be misused (cp. Prov 21:17), the Lord provides wine and olive oil as gifts to enhance life. Life is sustained by basic food, represented by bread.

title: Psalms 104:17–18
content: The storks migrated from northern Europe and resided in Palestine during the winter. • hyraxes: These animals are about the size of a rabbit and live in rocky places.

title: Psalms 104:19
content: the moon to mark the seasons: Ancient Israel based its calendar on the cycles of the moon. • the sun knows when to set: This is a poetic description from the perspective of normal observation. The sun goes down at a regular time every evening.

title: Psalms 104:19–23
content: The psalmist rejoices in the order of night and day, marking day four of creation (Gen 1:14–19). This cycle gives all creatures an opportunity to live.

title: Psalms 104:20–23
content: Cycles of darkness and dawn mark the days on earth.

title: Psalms 104:24–26
content: The Lord’s works testify to his wisdom. All parts fit together—land and sea, night and day, land creatures and sea creatures. The Lord’s wisdom makes life orderly and wonderful.

title: Psalms 104:25
content: The ocean, . . . teeming with life of every kind (see Gen 1:20–21), exemplifies the Lord’s creative activities.

title: Psalms 104:26
content: ships sailing: Commercial vessels engaged in sea trade were one of the wonders of the ancient Near East (see Isa 2:16; 23:1, 3). • Leviathan: The psalmist says that this feared creature is nothing but the Lord’s pet.

title: Psalms 104:27–30
content: All life depends on the gracious sustenance of the Lord of life and death (cp. Matt 6:11).

title: Psalms 104:29–30
content: When you give them your breath: Life on earth is only possible as the Lord’s gift, symbolized by his breath (Hebrew ruakh, “breath, wind, spirit”). The Lord’s Spirit is the agent of renewal (Isa 32:15–20).

title: Psalms 104:31
content: The Lord reveals his presence in the created order (see 8:1; 19:1–4; 24:7) and takes pleasure in his new creation (see Isa 65:19).

title: Psalms 104:31–35
content: The psalmist moves from describing the known creation to anticipating the new creation, when the Lord will renew the created order into a world without sinners.

title: Psalms 104:32
content: The trembling earth and the smoking mountains represent the Lord’s coming in judgment against sinners and salvation for his faithful people (see 18:7–15).

title: Psalms 104:35
content: The Lord will remove all forms of evil that defile his creation. • The concluding phrase takes us back to 104:1 (see also 103:1–2, 22; 146:1).

title: Psalms 105:1–5
content: The poet begins with the exhortation Give thanks (see also 106:1; 107:1; 118:1; 136:1). The other psalms continue with the refrain “for he is good!” The rest of Ps 105 tells of God’s goodness.

title: Psalms 105:1–45
content: This hymn praises the Lord’s faithfulness to Abraham and his descendants in all their journeys—from Ur to Canaan (105:12), to Egypt (105:17, 23), through the wilderness (105:37, 41), and back to Canaan (105:44). All of this fulfilled the Lord’s promise to Abraham (105:9, 42), which was the basis for Israel’s very existence. Joseph, whose suffering was changed into glory, is a paradigm of encouragement for Israel (105:16–25). • Psalm 105:1–15 (along with 96; 106:1, 47–48) is included in David’s song of praise recorded in 1 Chr 16.

title: Psalms 105:6–11
content: The story of Israel is based on the Lord’s commitment to Abraham. Even when a question arises about the future of God’s covenant with David (Ps 89), God’s covenant with Abraham stands, as does the spiritual bond between God and Israel, Abraham’s descendants.

title: Psalms 105:8
content: The covenant is the Lord’s irrevocable oath to be the Father of Abraham and his descendants (see Gen 12:1–9; 15:1–21).

title: Psalms 105:11
content: God promised the land of Canaan to Abraham’s descendants as their special possession, where they could live as God’s people (105:44–45; Gen 12:7; 15:7–21).

title: Psalms 105:12–15
content: The Lord protected Israel’s patriarchs.

title: Psalms 105:15
content: Abraham was one of the nation’s prophets (Gen 20:7).

title: Psalms 105:16–22
content: These verses tell the story of Joseph (see Gen 37–41).

title: Psalms 105:19
content: tested Joseph’s character: See Gen 39:6–12.

title: Psalms 105:23
content: Egypt (Hebrew mitsrayim) is called the land of Ham.

title: Psalms 105:23–25
content: These verses tell the story of Israel’s affliction in Egypt (see Exod 1:1–14).

title: Psalms 105:26–36
content: The psalmist recounts the story of Moses and the plagues in Egypt (Exod 7:20–12:30).

title: Psalms 105:37
content: not one . . . stumbled: The Lord protected all of his people (cp. 9:3).

title: Psalms 105:37–45
content: The Exodus and the conquest of Canaan fulfilled God’s promise to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob (105:9–10). Unlike Ps 78, the poet recites the Lord’s goodness without commenting on Israel’s history of rebellion (cp. Ps 106).

title: Psalms 105:39
content: The Lord’s presence was as evident to all as a fire in the darkness (Exod 13:22).

title: Psalms 105:42–45
content: The story of redemption is also the story of the Lord’s faithfulness.

title: Psalms 105:44
content: Canaan was a land of pagan nations (see 111:6). The psalmist might also be reflecting on God’s promise to Abraham (Gen 24:60) regarding the lands given to Isaac (Gen 26:3).

title: Psalms 105:45
content: The Lord planned for Israel to testify about him by obeying him; Israel was to be his model people.

title: Psalms 106:1
content: Praise the Lord! This refrain (Hebrew haleluyah) characterizes four small subgroups in the psalms: 104–106, 111–113, 115–117, 146–150.

title: Psalms 106:1–48
content: The Israelite community in exile confessed the Lord’s goodness and justice and their own historic sinfulness. From the humble state of exile, they pleaded for redemption and restoration, asking to be gathered back from all the places the Lord had scattered them in his wrath. The psalm does not end in despair but with the memory of the Lord’s former mercy and the hope that his mercy will be renewed (106:44–48). Israel failed, but the Lord is constant. • Verses 1, 47–48 (along with Pss 96; 105:1–15) are included in David’s song of praise recorded in 1 Chr 16:1–43.

title: Psalms 106:2–3
content: Wise people who practice justice and righteousness receive encouragement to proclaim the Lord’s great acts.

title: Psalms 106:4–5
content: The poet prays individually for the Lord’s favor before leading the community confession that follows.

title: Psalms 106:6
content: The story of Israel’s redemption encompasses their sinful response from the days of the ancestors to the present (106:43). The themes of sin and divine wrath both open and close Book Four (90:1–9; 106:6, 23, 43).

title: Psalms 106:6–13
content: The community joins together to confess their sins and their ancestors’ many acts of unbelief.

title: Psalms 106:9
content: Red Sea: See Exod 14:15–31.

title: Psalms 106:13
content: They wouldn’t wait: God’s impatient people did not trust him to work according to his will (e.g., see Exod 15:24; 16:2–3; 17:1–3; Num 14:26–45; 21:4–9).

title: Psalms 106:15
content: he sent a plague: See Exod 32:35; Num 11:33.

title: Psalms 106:16–18
content: The people became jealous because they presumed to have the same privileges as God’s appointed priests (see Num 16:1–35). • the earth opened up: See Num 16:28–33.

title: Psalms 106:19–23
content: they bowed before an image: The people forgot their Savior and committed the sin of idolatry (see Exod 32:1–6).

title: Psalms 106:22
content: The land of Ham here means Egypt (106:21).

title: Psalms 106:24–25
content: The people disobeyed God’s command when they refused to enter the pleasant land (the Promised Land; see Jer 3:19). • they wouldn’t believe his promise: See Num 13:25–14:12.

title: Psalms 106:26–27
content: God’s judgment when Israel refused to obey was death and exile (Num 14:26–30). The occasion for these severe judgments seems to have been disobeying God’s word (Ps 106:24–25) and provoking the Lord’s wrath (106:28–46).

title: Psalms 106:28
content: the worship of Baal at Peor: See Num 25:3; Deut 4:3.

title: Psalms 106:28–39
content: Israel’s idolatry outside of the land came with them into the land. Their nature did not change; they continued to provoke the Lord to anger by their actions.

title: Psalms 106:30–33
content: Phinehas, who executed a flagrantly apostate Israelite man (Num 25:3–8), is an even better model of a righteous man than Moses, who failed at Meribah (Num 20:11–13).

title: Psalms 106:34
content: Israel continued to disobey the word of the Lord while living in the Promised Land. Rather than destroying the nations, Israel accepted them and their ways (see Judg 2:1–3, 11–15; 3:5–6).

title: Psalms 106:37
content: Pagan gods were demons (see Deut 32:17).

title: Psalms 106:39
content: Idolatry, like adultery, defiles God’s people (see Lev 18:24; Hos 5:3).

title: Psalms 106:40
content: God abhorred Israel’s sin, as he does all sin.

title: Psalms 106:40–46
content: The psalmist returns to the Babylonian exile (106:26–27). The Lord judged Israel severely, but he also restrained his wrath, remembering the covenant he had made with Abraham.

title: Psalms 106:43–44
content: When Israel was finally destroyed, the destruction was not complete. The Lord pitied them, so he left a remnant.

title: Psalms 106:45
content: He remembered . . . and relented: Unlike Israel, the Lord is faithful to his covenant (105:8).

title: Psalms 106:46
content: As harsh as the Exile was, the Lord still protected his people (see 2 Kgs 25:27–29).

title: Psalms 106:47
content: Gather us back: The community prays for restoration from exile (see 102:19–22; 107:3; see also Isa 11:12; 40:11; 43:5; 54:7; 56:8; 66:18).

title: Psalms 106:48
content: This doxology concludes Book Four (cp. 41:13; 89:52). • from everlasting to everlasting! The reference to God’s eternal nature links to the opening of Book Four (90:1–2). • Let all the people say, “Amen!”: The Hebrew word ’amen means “It is true.” The godly accept the Lord’s will in exile and his promise to be their God.

title: Psalms 107:1–43
content: This psalm is a hymn of praise to God the Redeemer. After an introduction exhorting the redeemed to praise God for his goodness (107:1–3), the psalmist brings together four case studies of people whom the Lord redeemed from adversity (107:4–32). He then sums up the Lord’s sovereignty (107:33–42) and concludes with an invitation to discern God’s unfailing love in all areas of life (107:43).

title: Psalms 107:2
content: The redeemed might be all who came out of exile.

title: Psalms 107:3
content: exiles: People came from all nations where the people of Israel and Judah had been scattered.

title: Psalms 107:4–9
content: Those who were lost in the wilderness thank God for his rescue. The wilderness might be a metaphor for leaving the path of wisdom (1:1; Prov 4:10–15).

title: Psalms 107:6
content: The psalmist does not specify the occasion of his trouble and distress. The generic nature of the adversity permits readers in a variety of circumstances to identify with the laments.

title: Psalms 107:7–8
content: God led them like a shepherd (see 23:1). • Verse 8 is a refrain that is repeated in 107:15, 21, 31.

title: Psalms 107:10–16
content: The psalmist calls for thanksgiving and praise from people in despair over the consequences of their rebellion.

title: Psalms 107:11
content: God’s counsel includes his instruction and will.

title: Psalms 107:12
content: Exhausted by their hard labor (Lam 5:13), the people fell. While this might be expected of the wicked (Pss 9:3; 27:2), it was unlike the Israelites’ flight from Egypt (105:37).

title: Psalms 107:17–22
content: Fools who received what they deserved but were rescued from death offer thanksgiving to the Lord.

title: Psalms 107:20
content: The Lord creates (Gen 1:3) and sustains the universe (Heb 1:3) simply by speaking (Ps 147:18); when he speaks, people are also healed (Matt 8:8).

title: Psalms 107:23–32
content: Sailors give thanks to the Lord when he saves them from the chaos and peril of the sea.

title: Psalms 107:25–29
content: The same God who speaks and brings about the sailors’ distress can also calm the storm with just a word (cp. Jon 1:4; Matt 8:26).

title: Psalms 107:32
content: This call for public praise expands the refrains in 107:21–22 and 107:31.

title: Psalms 107:33–35
content: The Lord can choose to make the earth fertile or barren (74:15; Isa 35:6–7).

title: Psalms 107:33–42
content: These two sections (107:33–38, 39–42) expand the theme of the Lord’s sovereignty over things that humans cannot control.

title: Psalms 107:38
content: God’s presence can be seen in the abundance of his people’s families and herds (127:3; 133:3; cp. 109:8).

title: Psalms 107:39
content: People often become impoverished when their rulers practice oppression.

title: Psalms 107:40
content: In his contempt for human rulers, the Lord rectifies their corruption on earth.

title: Psalms 107:41
content: The large families of the poor are evidence of God’s blessing.

title: Psalms 107:42–43
content: Justice prevails in God’s world (1:6), and Israel’s history demonstrates God’s faithful love.

title: Psalms 108:1–13
content: This psalm combines two excerpts from David’s other psalms (cp. 57:5, 7–11; 60:5–12).

title: Psalms 109:1
content: The psalmist sees no evidence that God cares (see 28:1).

title: Psalms 109:1–31
content: The psalmist begins this lament with a general charge against his accusers: They do evil in return for good (109:1–5). At the end of the psalm, he turns to the Lord in prayer, asking for his protection (109:21–25) and vengeance (109:26–31).

title: Psalms 109:4–5
content: The psalmist’s acts of kindness and godliness (see 35:12–14) have only met with stubborn opposition and expressions of hatred.

title: Psalms 109:6–19
content: The NLT translates these verses as the words of the psalmist’s accusers; Hebrew lacks They say, which makes it unclear who is speaking.

title: Psalms 109:8
content: The wicked person apparently held a position of leadership. Peter referred to this psalm in regard to Judas Iscariot (Acts 1:20–26).

title: Psalms 109:8–11
content: Family members of those guilty of capital crimes often died with the perpetrator (Num 16:1–33; Josh 7:1–25) or had their property confiscated (1 Kgs 21:13–16).

title: Psalms 109:13
content: If one’s family name was blotted out, it meant there was no offspring to carry on the family name or remember its history (see Prov 10:7).

title: Psalms 109:14
content: Children inherit the sinful nature of their parents (51:5; Exod 20:5; Eph 2:3). The speaker wants the Lord to punish the perpetrator for the guilt of family members who went before him (cp. Matt 23:35–36).

title: Psalms 109:16
content: The defendant committed capital crimes and did not exercise even basic decency.

title: Psalms 109:18
content: Cursing is the accused person’s whole way of life.

title: Psalms 109:20
content: The psalmist appeals to the principle of retribution (see 94:23).

title: Psalms 109:21
content: The Lord’s reputation is at stake. If the wicked triumph, others could think that the Lord is also wicked and be drawn to that wickedness (1:1).

title: Psalms 109:21–25
content: Vulnerable and miserable, the psalmist appeals to his Lord for help. The accusations have killed his inner spirit and even his physical stamina.

title: Psalms 109:23
content: A shadow at dusk suggests a transitory, empty existence (102:11; 144:4); a single locust could easily be brushed off one’s clothing.

title: Psalms 109:26–31
content: These verses form a prayer for God’s presence and for vindication. The psalmist wants everyone to see that he is vindicated by the Lord, not by any human agent.

title: Psalms 109:28
content: The Lord’s servant demonstrates loyalty and obedience.

title: Psalms 109:29
content: The psalmist had been accused of being clothed with curses (109:18); now he asks that his accusers be clothed with disgrace and humiliation.

title: Psalms 110:1
content: The king of Israel had the great privilege of being the Lord’s adopted son (Ps 2; 1 Chr 22:10), but he fell (Ps 89). This decree restores and heightens his position. • The Lord: Hebrew Yahweh, the name of God (see Exod 3:6–14; 6:2–8; 20:2). • my Lord (Hebrew ’adoni) means “my master” or “my superior.” The psalmist viewed God’s messianic ruler as his superior. The New Testament frequently cites this psalm to validate Jesus’ claim to be the Messiah (Matt 22:44–45; Mark 12:36–37; Luke 20:42–44; Acts 2:34–35; Heb 1:13). • The Lord’s right hand represents his authority, strength, presence, and benefits. The Lord chose the descendant of David and raised him up to be close to him (Ps 80:17). Jesus claimed this position for himself (Matt 26:64; Mark 14:62; 16:19; Luke 22:69), and the apostles announced that Jesus, having ascended to heaven, sits at the right hand of the Father (Acts 2:33; 5:31; 7:55–56; Rom 8:34; Eph 1:20; Col 3:1; Heb 1:3; 8:1; 10:12; 12:2). • Ancient Near Eastern kings were sometimes portrayed as placing their feet on the backs of their conquered enemies as on a footstool (see Heb 10:12–13).

title: Psalms 110:1–7
content: Jesus and the apostles cite this psalm to explain Jesus’ unique ministry and status as the Messiah (Matt 22:43–45; Acts 2:32–36). It reaffirms God’s covenant with David and gives hope for the future (see 2 Sam 7:8–16).

title: Psalms 110:2–3
content: The kingdom will expand and increase, beginning from Jerusalem, until all enemies are conquered.

title: Psalms 110:4
content: The Lord had made an unbreakable oath and covenant, so his apparent rejection of David’s dynasty (89:38) in the Exile had led to a crisis. The placement of Ps 110 in Book Five reaffirms the future of the dynasty: David’s descendant must conform to God’s standard of integrity (Ps 101). His ministry will be transformed as he serves under God’s kingship (Pss 93–100). • You are a priest forever: The role of God’s messianic ruler changes. The priestly kingship of David and his descendants extended to serving as patrons of the Temple. David had the Ark brought to Jerusalem (2 Sam 6:15) and arranged for the Temple service (1 Chr 6:31–48; 15:11–26; 16:4–42; 23:4–32; 25:1). Solomon supervised the Temple construction (1 Kgs 5:1–7:51). Even so, Israel’s kingship was separate from its priesthood. In the messianic kingdom, the king would also minister as priest, as Melchizedek, king of Salem (Gen 14:18), had done. The New Testament develops the ministry of Jesus Christ as a fulfillment of this new order (see Heb 5:6–10; 6:20–7:25).

title: Psalms 110:5–6
content: at your right hand: This position brings help and protection (see 16:7–8; 108:13). • The Lord will strike down rebellious kings. Rebellion against the Lord is a capital offense (Ps 2; Rom 6:23).

title: Psalms 110:5–7
content: The new priestly role of David’s descendant does not rescind his old role as conquering ruler. He must still bring the nations under his rule (110:2–3; see Ps 2).

title: Psalms 110:7
content: God’s messianic ruler obtains victory as a vigorous person, as if he had received nourishment from brooks along the way (110:3).

title: Psalms 111:1–5
content: The godly praise God and delight themselves in his great works. His mighty acts reflect his righteousness, grace, and compassion (see 116:5–7). All who submit themselves to him experience his glory.

title: Psalms 111:1–10
content: This wisdom psalm contains many references to the works of the Lord that reveal his character. God is righteous, gracious, compassionate, faithful, just, trustworthy, upright, holy, and awe-inspiring (111:3, 4, 7, 8, 9). God’s character gives hope in the covenant relationship (111:5). He rescued Israel from Egypt (111:9), gave them the land (111:6), and provides for his people (111:5). However, God demands that the beneficiaries of this relationship also be people of righteousness and integrity.

title: Psalms 111:1–117.2
content: The refrain Praise the Lord! (Hebrew haleluyah) characterizes this group of psalms.

title: Psalms 111:5
content: God takes care of his people’s needs, even providing food. He remembers his covenant with Abraham (see 105:8–11).

title: Psalms 111:6–8
content: Giving Israel the lands of other nations was just and good because the Lord was executing his justice on those he dispossessed and showing grace to the Israelites. However, if the Israelites do not live faithfully and with integrity, they will also be dispossessed. The Lord’s people must reflect his character.

title: Psalms 111:9
content: The people of the Exodus generation went free because of God’s grace.

title: Psalms 111:10
content: True wisdom is the source of life (Prov 3:18; 9:11; Eccl 7:12); it begins with the fear of the Lord (Prov 9:10).

title: Psalms 112:1–5
content: The fear of the Lord leads to a life of wisdom that honors God and blesses the family and community. The godly joyfully imitate God; their obedience is not slavish.

title: Psalms 112:1–10
content: This psalm reiterates the themes of wisdom and the fear of the Lord (Ps 111). The wise have reason to be happy (112:1–5) and vigorous (112:6–10).

title: Psalms 112:2–3
content: successful: All will know the children of godly people (see 127:4) because the godly leave a legacy for their children (see 1:3; cp. Matt 6:20).

title: Psalms 112:4–5
content: The godly imitate God by being generous, compassionate, and righteous (51:1; 111:1–10; 2 Cor 9:9). They lend money to the poor without charging interest (Pss 15:5; 112:9; Exod 22:25).

title: Psalms 112:6
content: The honesty and compassion of the wise keeps them from stumbling (15:5; 37:23–24), ensuring that they will be long remembered (Prov 10:7).

title: Psalms 112:8
content: Because the godly joyfully expect God to prevail and rescue them, they face their foes triumphantly (59:10; 112:4; 118:7).

title: Psalms 112:9
content: Paul quotes this verse in his instructions about generous giving (2 Cor 9:9).

title: Psalms 112:10
content: The wicked . . . grind their teeth in anger out of their bitter envy (35:16; 37:12). The vigor and reputation of the godly cause conflict with those who want them dead. • The wicked will slink away out of fear and shame.

title: Psalms 113:1–3
content: The name of the Lord (Hebrew Yahweh; see Exod 3:15) reveals his being, character, and reputation. He is exalted in time (now and forever) and in space (from east to west).

title: Psalms 113:1–9
content: This hymn of praise exalts the greatness of the Lord’s name and glory. God is greatly exalted and glorious in heaven (113:4); he also stoops down to take care of the lowly and needy on earth (113:5–9).

title: Psalms 113:1–118.29
content: These psalms form what is known as the “Egyptian Hallel” (hallel means “praise”) because Jews use the collection in the celebration of Passover, which was instituted at the beginning of the exodus from Egypt. Psalms 113–114 are recited before the Passover meal and Pss 115–118 afterward.

title: Psalms 113:4
content: The Lord’s glory reaches to the heavens (57:5, 11; 99:2; 108:5; 138:6; Isa 6:1; 57:15) and throughout the world of human relationships.

title: Psalms 113:5–9
content: The incomparable Lord intimately involves himself in caring for people on earth.

title: Psalms 113:6
content: The Lord stoops to the world’s level to be directly involved with his people (see 138:6; Phil 2:6–8).

title: Psalms 113:7–8
content: These phrases are a quotation from Hannah’s prayer of praise (1 Sam 2:8–9a).

title: Psalms 113:9
content: A childless woman was customarily treated with disdain (Gen 16:4); the Lord has the power to make her a happy mother, as he made Sarah (Gen 21:2), Rebekah (Gen 25:21), Rachel (Gen 30:23), and Hannah (1 Sam 1:20). • God’s greatness and goodness provide ample reason to praise him.

title: Psalms 114:1–2
content: At the time of Israel’s exodus from Egypt and their entrance into the Promised Land, Israel was one holy kingdom (Exod 19:5–6). • The separate references to the land of Judah and Israel indicate that the psalm was composed after the kingdom was divided (1 Kgs 12:16–17; cp. 1 Sam 11:8; 1 Kgs 1:35), and probably after the Exile. The land of Judah became God’s sanctuary because the people worshiped God; his Tabernacle and later his Temple were located there.

title: Psalms 114:1–8
content: This lyrical celebration of the Lord’s power in nature recalls Israel’s beginning as a nation at the Exodus (114:1–2) and upon their entry to the Promised Land (114:3–6). It promotes reverence for the God of Jacob (114:7–8).

title: Psalms 114:3–4
content: hurried out of their way! The waters divided for Israel to escape Egypt (77:17–18; Exod 14). • The Jordan River turned away when Israel arrived to cross over (see Josh 3). • skipped like rams: God’s presence caused the mountains to quake (Exod 19:16–20).

title: Psalms 114:8
content: The Lord miraculously provided for his people in hard times after the Exile, just as he had done in the wilderness after the Exodus.

title: Psalms 115:1–3
content: The community confesses their faith that God will rescue them for the glory of his name.

title: Psalms 115:1–18
content: In this hymn of thanksgiving for God’s blessings, the community ascribes all glory to the name of the Lord, who is the true source of hope and blessing. Meanwhile, those who trust in idols are greatly disappointed. The blessing of the Creator of heaven and earth extends to future generations (115:14), and especially to the priesthood (115:12).

title: Psalms 115:2–3
content: Where is their God? People deny God’s presence or power when he does not act as they think he should (cp. 14:1; 42:3, 10). However, God is in the heavens—he has all power, authority, and knowledge. He does as he wishes, not what people think he should do. He works out his plans in accord with his will (Eph 1:11) and acts in his own time and in ways he chooses.

title: Psalms 115:4–11
content: This entire section is repeated in 135:15–20. • Unlike the Lord (95:3–5), idols cannot do anything; they are good for nothing.

title: Psalms 115:8
content: Worshiping idols leads one astray and corrupts those who trust in them (Isa 44:20).

title: Psalms 115:9–11
content: Israel . . . priests . . . you who fear the Lord: The psalmist calls on all those in the God-fearing community to commit their ways to the living God. The threefold address assures them that the Lord is their true helper and shield (cp. 118:2–4).

title: Psalms 115:12–13
content: The groups named in 115:9–11 receive assurance of the Lord’s blessing, regardless of their social status (see 113:8).

title: Psalms 115:14–15
content: The psalmist blesses (107:37–38, 41) all who trust in and fear the Lord. The Creator will care for the families of those who fear him. • who made heaven and earth: This statement speaks of the Lord’s all-encompassing power in creation.

title: Psalms 115:16–18
content: The heavens belong to the Lord:’s: God’s exaltation begins in heaven (113:4), far above the gods of the nations. Of course, the earth also belongs to him (47:9; 95:4). • The dead cannot participate in God’s blessings. The living praise God in thanksgiving for his blessings (79:13).

title: Psalms 116:1
content: I love the Lord: This unique opening expresses affection for and commitment to the Lord (see 18:1; Deut 6:5) on the basis of what the Lord has done.

title: Psalms 116:1–4
content: The psalmist praises the Lord for answering his prayers and rescuing him from death.

title: Psalms 116:1–19
content: This hymn of thanksgiving rejoices in God’s character and in rescue from death (116:1–11). It gives an assurance of God’s protection in life and reminds the godly that the Lord watches over them even at death. The psalmist commits to living as God’s servant and resolves to honor him publicly (116:12–19).

title: Psalms 116:2
content: Because the Lord responds to the cry of his people (107:41; 113:6–8), the psalmist now strongly believes in prayer.

title: Psalms 116:3
content: It isn’t clear if the psalmist’s crisis was a literal near-death experience or if he was using the term figuratively.

title: Psalms 116:4
content: This is the first of three times that the psalmist calls on the Lord’s name (i.e., reputation).

title: Psalms 116:5–7
content: The gracious, righteous, and compassionate Lord (see 111:1–5) rescued and gave rest to the psalmist.

title: Psalms 116:6
content: People with childlike faith readily receive his wisdom and instruction (19:7–11; Matt 18:3–4).

title: Psalms 116:8–11
content: The psalmist’s near-death crisis made him more aware of life and of walking before the Lord. Though he had been in anguish, the Lord was faithful. However, people are all liars.

title: Psalms 116:9
content: I walk in the Lord’s presence: The psalmist already lived with integrity, but since his experience of deep distress, he now enjoys open fellowship with the Lord (see 56:13; cp. Job 42:5).

title: Psalms 116:10
content: I believed in you: Paul quotes this phrase in 2 Cor 4:13.

title: Psalms 116:12–14
content: The Lord’s gracious gifts are so great that the psalmist can do nothing to repay his debt. Keeping his promises publicly demonstrates his gratitude. • All he has done for the psalmist includes answers to prayer, rescue, and life. • The cup of salvation overflows with God’s blessings (23:5), unlike the cup of judgment (75:8). • The psalmist makes promises (“vows,” 116:18) to praise the Lord publicly (116:17–18).

title: Psalms 116:15–19
content: No one lives or dies outside of God’s will. Having been given a second chance at life, the poet readily commits himself to the Lord with renewed acts of public devotion.

title: Psalms 117:1
content: Paul quotes this verse to show that Gentiles would eventually praise the God of Israel (Rom 15:11).

title: Psalms 117:1–2
content: This psalm, the shortest in the Psalter, invites all . . . people of the earth to praise the Lord because of his unfailing love and enduring faithfulness.

title: Psalms 118:1–29
content: With an exultant testimony, the psalmist gives thanks for the Lord’s goodness and encourages others to trust in his faithful love (118:1–4, 29). This poem is the last of the Egyptian Hallel (Pss 113–118).

title: Psalms 118:2–4
content: Israel . . . Aaron’s descendants . . . all who fear the Lord: These three groups represent the whole of the covenant community (cp. 115:9–11; 135:19–20).

title: Psalms 118:5–9
content: The Lord alone is the psalmist’s helper.

title: Psalms 118:6–7
content: The Lord is for me: Cp. Rom 8:31; Heb 13:6. • God’s presence cancels out the need to fear mere people (Ps 56:11). The psalmist joyfully expects God’s rescue (59:10; 112:8).

title: Psalms 118:8–9
content: Trusting in the Lord is better than placing confidence in even the most powerful human leaders (118:6; 146:3).

title: Psalms 118:10–12
content: Strength comes in the name of the Lord, declared by the threefold mention of the attackers, the Lord’s name, and victory. • Even when hostile people blazed . . . like a crackling fire, the Lord caused them to subside like burning thorns (see Isa 9:18; 10:17).

title: Psalms 118:14–18
content: The psalmist celebrates the victory of the Lord’s strong right arm, which kept him from death.

title: Psalms 118:17–21
content: God has restored the psalmist from death to life, so he praises the Lord publicly (cp. 116:6, 12–19).

title: Psalms 118:22
content: The cornerstone (or keystone) of a building or an arch gives the structure its shape and foundation. It is the most important of all the stones. The Lord chooses and places this stone for his sanctuary (Isa 28:16). Jesus referred to himself as this cornerstone (Matt 21:42; Mark 12:10–11; Luke 20:17; see Acts 4:11; Eph 2:20; 1 Pet 2:6–7).

title: Psalms 118:22–24
content: The psalmist sees his own salvation as the beginning of a new day in which the Lord will do great things.

title: Psalms 118:24
content: This is the day the Lord has made: The day of the Lord’s victory has already arrived, although its completion awaits another day (118:25).

title: Psalms 118:25–29
