content: The psalmist concludes with prayer and thanksgiving, anticipating an even greater revelation of God’s victory and rescue.

title: Psalms 118:26
content: The one who comes in the name of the Lord brings the Lord’s complete victory (see 118:10–12). • During Jesus’ triumphant entry into Jerusalem, the crowds called out various blessings, including phrases taken from this verse (Matt 21:9; Mark 11:9; Luke 19:38; John 12:13). Jesus himself quoted this passage as he wept over Jerusalem (Matt 23:39; Luke 13:35).

title: Psalms 119:1–4
content: The wise are happy. They are people of integrity (see 84:11) who follow the path of divine instruction. They obey God’s revelation and search for it with all their hearts (see 27:7; 119:10, 45, 94, 155), and they reject all forms of evil. Cp. 1:1–2.

title: Psalms 119:1–8
content: Aleph (א): God, the author of these instructions, commands that his followers live by them. The psalmist prays to be given the grace to live by that revelation.

title: Psalms 119:1–176
content: This psalm combines elements of wisdom, lament, praise, thanksgiving, and confession. Eight Hebrew words are used frequently, translated as “instructions,” “laws,” “words,” “regulations,” “statutes,” “commands,” “decrees,” “commandments,” and “promises.” Together, these words encourage love for and obedience to God’s instructions, as found in the Scriptures (see 2 Tim 3:14–17). The expression of deep commitment to these instructions unifies the psalm.

title: Psalms 119:4
content: To keep God’s commandments means to guard them by obeying them.

title: Psalms 119:9
content: A young person tends toward foolishness (Prov 22:15) and can easily make mistakes that destroy his life (Prov 7:6–23). Youth is also the best time to develop personal discipline and pursue wisdom (see Ps 34:11; Prov 1:4). • To stay pure means to remain uncorrupted by wickedness and sin and to develop the integrity of life defined in Ps 15.

title: Psalms 119:9–16
content: Beth (ב): The psalmist is determined to pursue purity and encourages the cultivation of wisdom through God’s principles (119:9) and instructions (119:10–16).

title: Psalms 119:10
content: The student asks God the teacher to discipline him so that he will not wander.

title: Psalms 119:14
content: God’s wisdom is far greater than any riches humans seek (119:72, 127; Prov 3:14–15).

title: Psalms 119:15
content: The way of wisdom includes meditating on God’s ways (see 119:1, 3). The wise reflect on the implications of God’s word.

title: Psalms 119:17–18
content: The psalmist seeks to please the Lord with a full and obedient life of praise (118:17; 119:25, 77, 116, 144, 175). Only the Lord can remove his adversaries and enable him to see the wonderful truths found in God’s instructions.

title: Psalms 119:17–24
content: Gimel (ג): Like a foreigner in hostile territory, God’s servant needs God’s guidance.

title: Psalms 119:20–21
content: The arrogant are probably those who mock the psalmist (119:22–23).

title: Psalms 119:23–24
content: Those who meditate on God’s instructions receive wise advice from them.

title: Psalms 119:25–32
content: Daleth (ד): Though the poet feels anguish and sorrow, he entreats the Lord to revive him because he wants to obey the Lord. Suffering and death may result from the Lord’s chastening (118:17–18; 119:67, 71, 75), but his instruction revives the weary soul (see 119:12).

title: Psalms 119:29
content: lying to myself: Self-deception is a fruit of sinful human nature (Jer 17:9); it leads to folly. • Access to God’s word is a privilege, not a right.

title: Psalms 119:33–40
content: He (ה): As a student, the poet asks his teacher, God, to renew life and to transform disgrace into righteousness.

title: Psalms 119:36
content: The love for money can lead to sin (cp. Exod 18:21; 1 Tim 3:1–5; 6:10).

title: Psalms 119:41–43
content: The psalmist asks to be saved from enemies who speak harshly (see 42:10; 44:16; 89:50–51; 102:8).

title: Psalms 119:41–48
content: Waw (ו): The psalmist prays that God’s word would continue to be the source of his love and salvation.

title: Psalms 119:44–46
content: The psalmist is determined to obey the Lord.

title: Psalms 119:47–48
content: The psalmist finds delight in God’s word in spite of pain (119:92, 143).

title: Psalms 119:49–56
content: Zayin (ז): The psalmist asks God to remember his word as the psalmist also remembers God’s word and his name. Remembrance expresses devotion.

title: Psalms 119:52
content: The age-old regulations are the Torah (God’s “instructions” or “law”), a term that refers to the books of Genesis—Deuteronomy.

title: Psalms 119:57–64
content: Heth (ח): The psalmist seeks God’s favor and unfailing love. Although surrounded by evildoers, he remains a loyal servant of the Lord.

title: Psalms 119:61
content: Evil people try to drag him into sin, but the psalmist’s memory of God’s word keeps him standing firm (see 119:16).

title: Psalms 119:64
content: God’s goodness fills the earth; the whole created order provides evidence of his goodness (see Isa 6:3; 11:9).

title: Psalms 119:65–68
content: Good judgment and knowledge come from wisdom (111:10). • The psalmist admits that he used to wander off like a stray sheep (119:176). • you disciplined me: See 119:25–29. • You are good and do only good: God’s character is perfect (97:2; Jas 1:17; 1 Jn 1:5).

title: Psalms 119:65–72
content: Teth (ט): The psalmist describes himself as a penitent sinner who gratefully accepts the Lord’s discipline.

title: Psalms 119:73–76
content: As God’s child, the psalmist asks for divine wisdom.

title: Psalms 119:73–80
content: Yodh (י): In this prayer for comfort and compassion, the psalmist commits himself to his Creator, who has afflicted him. He wants God to pay back his enemies for the wrongs they have done. He also prays to receive the gift of life. He not only prays for himself but also considers the whole community of the godly, asking that God’s answers to prayer would encourage them.

title: Psalms 119:81–88
content: Kaph (כ): The psalmist is worn out from waiting for the Lord, but his hope is in God’s future rescue.

title: Psalms 119:85–88
content: God’s word is trustworthy, in contrast to the deceptions of the enemies who hunt the psalmist down without cause (see 119:78).

title: Psalms 119:89–96
content: Lamedh (ל): The stability of God’s wisdom gives understanding. God’s word provides order and a framework for living, even when under pressure from adversaries.

title: Psalms 119:95
content: The wicked intended to kill the psalmist, but destruction (1:6) was their own fate.

title: Psalms 119:96
content: Even perfection has its limits: Humans cannot fully understand God’s ways (see Eccl 3:11).

title: Psalms 119:97–102
content: make me wiser: God’s word provides wisdom and perspective. God is the true source of wisdom.

title: Psalms 119:97–104
content: Mem (מ): The instruction and wisdom of God through his word are far superior to the best that human teachers can offer.

title: Psalms 119:103–104
content: Wisdom is preferable to even the finest food (19:10; 81:16). • The psalmist had already rejected the delusion offered by the way of folly (see 119:18, 78, 86, 163).

title: Psalms 119:105–106
content: The Lord’s word is a lamp that provides perspective, hope, and guidance in darkness (18:25–29; 119:130). Even more, this light gives life (Prov 6:23).

title: Psalms 119:105–112
content: Nun (נ): The psalmist’s devotion to God’s word comes from within his being (119:112) and guides his external life.

title: Psalms 119:108–112
content: offering of praise: This Hebrew expression is unique in the Old Testament (cp. 50:23). • The psalmist is vulnerable to his opponents because of his commitment to a wise life.

title: Psalms 119:113
content: The godly hate the wicked and their deeds (5:4–6; cp. Ezek 33:11).

title: Psalms 119:113–120
content: Samekh (ס): The psalmist declares his hatred of evil and his love for God and his ways.

title: Psalms 119:121–128
content: Ayin (ע): The servant of the Lord strains to endure the evil around him. He boldly petitions the Lord to rescue him immediately!

title: Psalms 119:125
content: Simply possessing God’s law does not provide any benefits. The psalmist knows that only as the Lord gives discernment will he understand it.

title: Psalms 119:129–136
content: Pe (פ): The psalmist prays earnestly for God to speak to him as he suffers from his adversities.

title: Psalms 119:137–144
content: Tsadhe (צ): God is righteous, and his word is right and just, especially in contrast to the deceptions of the wicked.

title: Psalms 119:139
content: The psalmist’s indignation (cp. 69:9) comes from seeing the wicked disregard God’s word.

title: Psalms 119:141
content: The psalmist is greatly troubled by his oppressors (see 119:143; cp. Isa 53).

title: Psalms 119:145–148
content: I rise and anticipate translate the same Hebrew verb.

title: Psalms 119:145–152
content: Qoph (ק): The psalmist prays to the Lord at night. Even when God seems distant, he is actually close.

title: Psalms 119:150–151
content: Coming to attack me (or draw near) is a Hebrew wordplay on You are near. The wicked stay far from God's instructions, but the psalmist stays close, so he does not need to fear.

title: Psalms 119:153–160
content: Resh (ר): This request for life appears throughout Psalm 119, but it is focused in this stanza.

title: Psalms 119:161–164
content: my heart trembles . . . I rejoice: Fear, trembling, and joy mark the psalmist’s devotion to God. • God’s word is a treasure. • In the Old Testament, seven signifies wholeness.

title: Psalms 119:161–168
content: Shin (ש): The psalmist looks beyond his adversaries to the peace of God. This perspective allows him to praise God throughout the day.

title: Psalms 119:169–176
content: Taw (ת): God’s servant petitions the Lord one final time; he still feels like a lost sheep.

title: Psalms 119:176
content: God, the Great Shepherd, seeks out his lost sheep (23:1; Luke 15:4–6).

title: Psalms 120:1–2
content: The psalmist is surrounded by liars, so he makes his lament to the Lord, the only one who can help him.

title: Psalms 120:1–7
content: This short, individual lament expresses the psalmist’s trust that the Lord will deal with deceptive evildoers. It also laments living as a stranger among hateful liars. The psalmist’s picture of his life in a foreign land might have been a reality as he set out for Jerusalem, or it might depict his feelings and concerns as he begins his pilgrimage. Overwhelmed with injustice, he trusts God and looks forward to arriving in the Lord’s presence.

title: Psalms 120:1–134.3
content: These short, appealing songs were sung during pilgrims’ journeys to Jerusalem for the national festivals three times per year (Deut 16:16). The title of these psalms includes the Hebrew word for stairs, which some take to mean “ascending to Jerusalem.” These psalms (sometimes called the Songs of Ascents) take the reader on a pilgrimage to Jerusalem to praise God for his goodness to Israel throughout history.

title: Psalms 120:3–4
content: The psalmist dialogues with the liars who surround him. He feels reassured that the Lord will judge them. • The Divine Warrior (see 7:12–13; 11:4–6) will throw sharp arrows and glowing coals on the liars.

title: Psalms 120:5
content: Meshech was a Japhethite territory far to the north of Canaan. Kedar was an Ishmaelite territory in Arabia. Violent people lived in both locations. Meshech was the home of a famous slave trade (Ezek 27:13; cp. Exod 21:16) and Kedar of renowned warriors (Isa 21:16–17). These places can be understood as representative of the apostate, violent land where the psalmist suffered.

title: Psalms 120:5–7
content: The psalmist feels the anguish of alienation, isolation, and perpetual conflict.

title: Psalms 120:6–7
content: peace: See 37:11; 122:6–9; 125:5; 128:6.

title: Psalms 121:1
content: The mountains were known for their idolatrous worship (Deut 12:2), and Israel was enticed to the hilltop shrines (Hos 4:13). This verse can be understood as a rhetorical question expecting a negative answer: The gods of the hilltop shrines cannot rescue anyone. Others understand the mountains to be a symbol of the Lord’s strength (Ps 95:4). In that case, the question would be interpreted literally (Where does my help come from?), with the answer given in the next verse

title: Psalms 121:1–8
content: The leader of the group of pilgrims uses word pictures to assure the group of the Lord’s presence during the journey.

title: Psalms 121:4
content: God watches over his own, even and especially when they face many troubles (12:5, 7; 69:29; 91:14; 146:9).

title: Psalms 121:4–6
content: The Creator (121:2) is the guardian of Israel. • God stands beside Israel, supporting and caring for the godly (see 16:7–8). • Both the sun and the moon were regarded as deities in the ancient Near East, but the Creator limits their power. They, too, praise the Lord (148:3).

title: Psalms 122:1
content: The central sanctuary was the house of the Lord. This phrase originally referred to the Tabernacle (Exod 23:19; 34:26).

title: Psalms 122:1–9
content: Jerusalem is here idealized as the city of God, the city of David, and the city of faith. A group of people on a pilgrimage joyfully arrive in the city (122:1–2). The psalmist sings an ode to Jerusalem (122:3–5) and prays for the city’s peace (122:6–9).

title: Psalms 122:2
content: Several psalms celebrate or look forward to being inside the gates of the city (9:14; 87:2; 100:4; 118:19).

title: Psalms 122:3
content: In the time of David and Solomon, Jerusalem was renowned as a place of security (1 Kgs 10:6–7).

title: Psalms 122:3–5
content: Jerusalem is a metaphor for God’s heavenly dwelling. David was the archetype for God’s chosen rulers.

title: Psalms 122:4
content: Each of the people of Israel belonged to one of the tribes, and all of the tribes belonged to the Lord. • To give thanks is to present an offering acceptable to the Lord (50:14, 23; 100:4; 118:19). • as the law requires of Israel: See Exod 23:17; Deut 16:16.

title: Psalms 122:5
content: the thrones where judgment is given: In the eras of David and Solomon (1 Kgs 3:28), Jerusalem was the home of wisdom and justice; it would be so again (Isa 9:7).

title: Psalms 122:6–9
content: Prayers for the peace of Jerusalem are motivated by love of family and God’s sanctuary.

title: Psalms 123:1–4
content: This lament on the psalmist’s lowly position expresses vivid trust in the Lord (123:1–2). The psalmist prays for God’s favor on the community, as the reality of evil surrounds them (123:3–4). The poet looks beyond Jerusalem (Ps 122) to God’s throne in heaven.

title: Psalms 124:1–2
content: The negative rhetorical questions emphasize the positive idea that the Lord was indeed on their side.

title: Psalms 124:1–8
content: This thanksgiving song describes what might happen if the Lord were not present with his people.

title: Psalms 124:4–5
content: the raging waters of their fury: The enemies could have overwhelmed the Israelites and wiped them out if the Lord had not been with his people (cp. 69:15; Jer 46:8).

title: Psalms 124:6–8
content: The enemies of God’s people, like lions or bears who tear their prey with their teeth (see 57:4; Prov 28:15), had their mouths shut by the Lord (Dan 6:22).

title: Psalms 125:1–5
content: The psalmist expresses the community’s confidence in the Lord’s protection (125:1–2) and prays for peace (125:3–5).

title: Psalms 125:2
content: surrounds: God guards and protects like a wall of fire (Zech 2:5).

title: Psalms 125:3
content: The godly might be tempted through peer pressure and cultural domination.

title: Psalms 125:4–5
content: People who reject the straight path of the upright are fools (Prov 2:12–15). God pours out his goodness on the godly (see Ps 122:6–9).

title: Psalms 126:1–3
content: The Lord brought about Israel’s restoration from exile, just as he had brought Israel out of Egypt (114:1). The restoration transformed the weeping of the Lord’s people into laughter and showed the Lord’s character to the nations (9:11; 64:9; Isa 12:4).

title: Psalms 126:1–6
content: This hymn celebrates Israel’s return from exile (126:1–3). The psalmist prays for full restoration (126:4–6).

title: Psalms 126:4–6
content: The prophets had spoken of the restoration as a time when the wilderness would change into the Garden of Eden (Isa 51:3; Ezek 47); the reality fell far short of paradise. Here the restoration community prays for full redemption (see Hag 2:19). • as streams renew the desert: The seasonal rains filled the dry river beds (wadis), and the land turned green again. The prayer looks for a similar transformation of Israel’s fortunes, a fulfillment of the imagery of the “Second Exodus” in Isaiah (see “The Promise of a Second Exodus” Theme Note). • The harvest represents God’s full restoration.

resource.label: The Promise of a Second Exodus

title: Psalms 127:1–2
content: Unless: These conditional sentences emphasize the positive idea that the Lord will protect the city (cp. 124:1–2). • Human effort is futile unless the Lord blesses it (see 44:3). • from early morning until late at night: This depicts an aggressive and competitive lifestyle. • God’s loved ones enjoy a quiet night’s sleep (3:5; 4:8).

title: Psalms 127:1–5
content: Blessing and protection come from God. Without his presence, there is no success (127:1–2). This is particularly true for children, who are God’s gift (127:3–5).

title: Psalms 127:3–5
content: Children are one of God’s blessings. The words translated “children” (Hebrew banim) and “builders” (bonim, 127:1) form a wordplay. Having children builds a family.

title: Psalms 127:4–5
content: like arrows: God uses children to protect the reputation of his people against the wicked (cp. 120:4; 7:12–13).

title: Psalms 128:1–2
content: Enjoying the fruit of one’s labor means gaining benefit from whatever work one does.

title: Psalms 128:1–6
content: The godly, who fear the Lord, will know true happiness (128:1–2). The Lord is with them (see 127:1–2), building their home life (128:3–4) and blessing them across the generations (128:5–6).

title: Psalms 128:3
content: Like vigorous young olive trees, children are saplings filled with potential. Olive oil symbolizes God’s blessing (104:15; Num 18:12; Jer 31:12; Hag 2:19).

title: Psalms 128:4–6
content: God will continually bless all who fear him (133:3) from his dwelling in Zion (20:2; 50:2; 110:2), no matter where they live. • grandchildren: God’s blessings extend from generation to generation for the faithful (79:12–13; 89:1; 100:4–5; 103:17–19).

title: Psalms 129:1–2
content: Israel’s earliest youth as a nation was during its sojourn in Egypt.

title: Psalms 129:1–8
content: The psalmist briefly reviews Israel’s history of trouble (129:1–2) and redemption (129:3–4). He concludes with curses against the enemies and blessings on the godly (129:5–6).

title: Psalms 129:3–4
content: the Lord is good: He rescued Israel from Egypt, from many enemy attacks, and from the Babylonian exile.

title: Psalms 129:6–8
content: Grass on a rooftop had shallow roots and would scorch easily. A crop was ignored by the harvester when the yield was low. The enemies who had sown hurt among God’s people would gain little.

title: Psalms 130:1–3
content: A cry from the depths is from a place of deep distress (cp. 69:2, 14; Isa 51:10; Ezek 27:34). Out of the frailty of his being, the psalmist prays for divine favor.

title: Psalms 130:1–8
content: Beginning with himself as a representative of the community, the psalmist cries for God’s mercy (130:1–3) out of deep distress. He places his hope in the Lord (130:4–6), knowing that the Lord will rescue when and as he chooses. Based on this confidence, the psalmist invites Israel to wait for the Lord (130:7–8).

title: Psalms 130:3
content: The psalmist knows that his sins make him guilty and deserving of God’s judgment.

title: Psalms 130:4–6
content: The good news comes in God’s readiness to forgive sinners. His grace encourages people to fear him and hope in him.

title: Psalms 130:5
content: God’s word imparts hope (119:42–43, 49; 147:11).

title: Psalms 130:7–8
content: Israel is invited to hope in the Lord (9:18; 27:14; 131:3) because the Lord pays the costly price for redemption and covers whatever sin separates humans from him (see also 111:9; Exod 6:6–8; 2 Sam 7:23–24; Isa 43:1–4; Titus 2:14; Heb 9:12; 1 Pet 1:18).

title: Psalms 131:1
content: The heart represents the whole being (see 27:8). • God hates arrogance, which is a foolish way of life (Prov 6:16–19). • The psalmist does not trouble himself with matters that properly belong to the Lord.

title: Psalms 131:1–3
content: Out of his contentment in the Lord, the psalmist invites Israel to seek their rest in God (131:3).

title: Psalms 131:2
content: The psalmist calmed and quieted himself, surrendering his ambitions and taming his ego (Gal 2:20). • like a weaned child: The psalmist sees himself as a contented child.

title: Psalms 132:1–18
content: This psalm celebrates the Lord’s faithfulness to David. When David wanted to bring the Ark into Jerusalem (132:1–5), the Lord granted the request and made Jerusalem his earthly home (132:6–10). The choice of Jerusalem marked God’s election of David’s line (132:11–13), of Zion (132:14–17), and of the priesthood (132:9, 16).

title: Psalms 132:6
content: Ephrathah is Bethlehem (Gen 35:19; 48:7). • Jaar is the singular form of the plural “Jearim.” The Ark was at Kiriath-jearim for twenty years in Samuel’s time (1 Sam 7:1–2).

title: Psalms 132:6–10
content: These verses form a recollection of David’s moving the Ark of the Covenant to Jerusalem (2 Sam 6:1–15) and of the Lord’s oath to David (2 Sam 7:4–16).

title: Psalms 132:8–10
content: These verses are a quotation from Solomon’s prayer at the dedication of the Temple (2 Chr 6:41–42).

title: Psalms 132:9
content: The priests were to exhibit righteousness in their lives (132:16; Mal 2:6).

title: Psalms 132:11–12
content: The Lord swore an oath to David (2 Sam 7:4–16): God’s promise is unconditional, but the covenant is not (If . . . then). Those who break God’s covenant can expect the discipline of God’s judgment (see Ps 89:30–37).

title: Psalms 132:13–17
content: The psalmist recounts the selection of Jerusalem and of the priests.

title: Psalms 132:17
content: anointed one: The ruler God chose and established (see Pss 1–8) would never cease to provide light for the Lord’s people. This light would burn continually (see 1 Kgs 11:36; 2 Kgs 8:19; cp. John 8:12; Rev 21:23–24).

title: Psalms 132:18
content: The adversaries will be humiliated, in contrast to the glorious king (132:9, 16).

title: Psalms 133:1
content: Brothers are related by blood, by profession, or by commitment.

title: Psalms 133:1–2
content: The psalmist tells of the joy of consecrated relationships.

title: Psalms 133:1–3
content: In this wisdom psalm (see Ps 1), peaceful and harmonious relationships manifest the presence of God.

title: Psalms 133:2
content: The anointing oil was the oil used to ordain and consecrate Aaron for service in his office (see Exod 29:7). • head . . . beard . . . border of his robe: The oil consecrated Aaron completely.

title: Psalms 133:3
content: The dew represents the richness of divine blessings; in Jerusalem, it comes from moist winds from the Mediterranean Sea. Mount Hermon, which is capped with snow, is a place of abundant moisture. • A blessing is God’s life-giving power, a guarantee of his provision and protection (5:12; 41:2), secured by his presence (21:6; 67:1). Even the other nations will ultimately be blessed (Pss 67; 72:17). Zion is the focal point of God’s blessing (134:3; 147:13). • God gives life everlasting to human beings.

title: Psalms 134:1–2
content: Those who serve at night were the priests and Levites (see also 135:2).

title: Psalms 134:1–3
content: In the last of the pilgrims’ songs (Pss 120–134), the travelers call the Temple workers to praise the Lord. In return, they will receive a much-anticipated blessing.

title: Psalms 135:1–21
content: God, the Creator and the Lord of history, “made heaven and earth” (134:3). He deserves praise because, unlike idols, he redeems his people.

title: Psalms 135:4
content: The synonyms Jacob and Israel include all twelve tribes. The Lord cherishes his chosen people. They are his treasure out of all the kingdoms of the world (Exod 19:5–6).

title: Psalms 135:5
content: The Lord is superior to any real or imagined supernatural being (see 95:3–5; 115:4–8).

title: Psalms 135:6
content: God is sovereign over the whole created order—he does whatever pleases him him. • The phrase heaven and earth refers to all of creation.

title: Psalms 135:7
content: The psalmist tells of God’s sovereignty over the weather (Pss 29; 77:17–18; 78:26; 104:4; 147:8–9; 148:5–6).

title: Psalms 135:8–11
content: In the tenth and culminating plague against Egypt, God destroyed the firstborn of each family. • The miraculous signs and wonders are the ten plagues (see Exod 7–11; Deut 4:34; Neh 9:10).

title: Psalms 135:8–12
content: The Lord was sovereign over the Exodus and the conquest of the Promised Land.

title: Psalms 135:13–18
content: The Lord’s name and character stand in contrast to idols.

title: Psalms 135:15–18
content: Idols corrupt the thinking because they are merely things made by humans; they cannot speak, see, hear, or breathe (Isa 41:22–24; 44:9, 18; Rom 1:21–23).

title: Psalms 135:15–20
content: This entire section is repeated in 115:4–11.

title: Psalms 135:19–21
content: The groups named here comprised the covenant community (see 115:9–11).

title: Psalms 136:1–3
content: The psalmist invites the community to praise the Lord, who is good and full of love, the true Lord of humanity. Verse 1 alludes to the poetic expression in 2 Chr 5:13.

title: Psalms 136:1–26
content: This is the last of the Great Hallel psalms (Pss 120–136). It distinctively repeats the refrain His faithful love endures forever in every verse. The hymn is framed by a call to praise (136:1–3, 26). It proclaims the Lord as the Creator of all and the Redeemer of Israel, both in the distant (136:10–22) and in the recent past (136:23–24).

title: Psalms 136:10–22
content: The psalmist recounts the early history of Israel’s redemption.

title: Psalms 136:23–24
content: The psalmist relates the recent history of Israel’s redemption, although the circumstances are not specified.

title: Psalms 136:25
content: The Lord provides for all of his creatures.

title: Psalms 136:26
content: The phrase God of heaven is an exilic and postexilic designation for the Lord; it is found in Ezra (Ezra 1:2; 5:11, 12; 6:9, 10; 7:12; etc.), Nehemiah (Neh 1:5; 2:4, 20; etc.), and Daniel (Dan 2:18, 19, 37, 44).

title: Psalms 137:1–9
content: In response to the pain of exile (137:1–4), the psalmist resolves to remember Jerusalem even though the memories cause him pain (137:4–6). He also writes an astounding imprecation, or prayer for vengeance (137:7–9).

title: Psalms 137:2–4
content: Because the music of Jerusalem was tied to the joys of life in the Promised Land, the Exile removed any occasion for singing joyous songs. The Babylonians wanted the Judeans to sing and dance for them, but the exiles’ grief made doing so either distasteful or impossible. The songs celebrating the Lord speak of his power and goodness, but his people were filled with doubts and questions. They hung their harps in trees, perhaps signifying the death of their joy under God’s curse (Deut 21:23).

title: Psalms 137:5–6
content: The psalmist pledges his loyalty to Jerusalem, the city at the center of God’s reign and the location of fellowship with him.

title: Psalms 137:7–9
content: The poet witnessed the betrayal of God’s people from Judah by the Edomites, so he curses Edom. The long rivalry between Edom and Judah came to a head during Judah’s last days, when the Edomites handed the Judeans over to the Babylonians (Obad 1:10–11) and rejoiced in Jerusalem’s fall. • This prayer for vengeance is shocking.

title: Psalms 138:1–3
content: The Lord receives praise before the gods of the nations.

title: Psalms 138:1–8
content: In this wisdom psalm, the Lord is presented as the God of gods. He rescued his people and has a perfect plan for them as individuals. The nations will join Israel in glorifying God.

title: Psalms 138:1–145.21
content: In this final collection of psalms of David, praise and wisdom psalms (Pss 138–139, 145) form a frame around five poems of lament (Pss 140–144).

title: Psalms 138:4–5
content: As the Lord’s glory fills the earth, the world’s population must willingly submit to him. Every king (cp. Ps 2) will join the community of praise as they hear the Lord’s ways of truth and love.

title: Psalms 138:6
content: God’s holiness and excellence are great, beyond the scope of humanity (see 99:2; 113:4; Isa 6:1; 57:15).

title: Psalms 138:6–8
content: The exalted God takes care of the humble (138:6), especially his servant the psalmist (138:7–8).

title: Psalms 138:8
content: The psalmist expresses confidence in the Lord’s plans, which are perfect, and prays for God’s continued involvement. The psalmist sees himself as part of God’s plans (see 9:10; 139:14).

title: Psalms 139:1–6
content: The Lord knows the psalmist well; God has examined him thoroughly, in an inescapable examination that is painful at times (Job 7:17–19).

title: Psalms 139:1–24
content: In this wisdom psalm, the psalmist opens every aspect of his being, character, behavior, and speech to God’s examination. As hard as life is, he wants to ensure his own growth in wisdom so that he does not come under God’s judgment of the wicked (141:5; 142:3; 143:8, 10; 144:3–4). Further, the poet recognizes that he cannot escape from the Lord. His sense of stress disappears when he considers the Lord’s loving care for him, even before birth (139:13–18). He then invites the Lord to continue examining him as he walks in the path of wisdom (139:23–24).

title: Psalms 139:2
content: The phrase sit down or stand up refers to daily activities (cp. Deut 6:6–9).

title: Psalms 139:3–6
content: The Lord’s omniscience and omnipotence provide comfort to the godly, but they imprison the hearts of the wicked (2:3).

title: Psalms 139:6
content: The Lord’s wonderful understanding lies beyond the psalmist’s ability to comprehend (see Judg 13:18).

title: Psalms 139:7–12
content: The psalmist expresses his awe at the Lord’s omnipresence.

title: Psalms 139:8
content: down to the grave: God has total access to his entire creation—even the most hard-to-reach places.

title: Psalms 139:9
content: ride the wings of the morning: This poetic expression describes traveling eastward, as far as the sunrise, if that were possible. • the farthest oceans: This expression takes the traveler in the opposite direction, far to the west.

title: Psalms 139:13
content: The delicate, inner parts of the body include a person’s very being. • Even when hidden in his mother’s womb, the psalmist was guided by the Lord.

title: Psalms 139:17
content: How precious are your thoughts about me: God’s investigation reveals loving care. Fellowship with the Lord provides riches beyond description.

title: Psalms 139:19–24
content: The psalmist’s sense of awe leads him to consider the wicked and to reflect on himself. The Lord, as the examiner of all people, judges the wicked for their destructive acts and speech; thus, the psalmist prays that he will not be among them.

title: Psalms 139:21
content: I hate: Rejection of evil is a mark of wisdom (see 1:1; 5:4–6).

title: Psalms 139:23–24
content: The psalmist’s prayer against the wicked leads him also to reflect on himself; he does not presume that he is righteous. This prayer has been repeated by believers over the centuries.

title: Psalms 139:24
content: The path of wisdom leads to everlasting life (see 1:6; Prov 4:18; 6:23).

title: Psalms 140:1–3
content: The psalmist prays for the Lord to rescue him from wicked people.

title: Psalms 140:1–13
content: In this individual lament, the psalmist artistically sketches God’s enemies with all their evil intents. He prays for the Lord’s protection and rescue with confidence in God’s strength and justice. He foresees the evil as being judged by fire (140:9–11) and himself as being vindicated and dwelling in the Lord’s presence (140:13).

title: Psalms 140:3
content: sting like a snake . . . a viper: These creatures depict the wicked as very corrupt people (see Prov 23:32; Isa 14:29; Rom 3:13).

title: Psalms 140:4–5
content: The psalmist asks for divine protection (see Ps 121), praying that the Lord will keep him safe from the many schemes of the wicked.

title: Psalms 140:7
content: The expression Sovereign Lord comes from combining the name Yahweh with the title Adonai (Master). See also 68:20; 69:6; 71:16; 73:28; 109:21; 141:8.

title: Psalms 140:9–11
content: The psalmist prays for God’s judgment on the wicked.

title: Psalms 140:10
content: The psalmist wants fire to descend on his enemies, and he wants them thrown into pits so they can never attack again. The language foreshadows the New Testament teaching on hell (Matt 5:22, 29–30; 10:28; 18:9; Mark 9:43–47; Luke 12:5; Jas 3:6; 2 Pet 2:4).

title: Psalms 141:1–2
content: The psalmist prays urgently for rescue. He does not have at hand either incense or an evening offering (Exod 29:38–39), but his prayers and devotion are the reality that those elements represent (cp. Isa 1:13; Rev 5:8). • Upraised hands are a posture of prayer (Pss 28:2; 88:9; 143:6; Exod 9:29; 1 Tim 2:8).

title: Psalms 141:1–10
content: The psalmist prays for rescue and wisdom, and he envisions the end of evil. The principle of retribution (141:10) unifies the psalm.

title: Psalms 141:3–5
content: Wisdom sometimes requires protection from oneself. One could say or think things that lead to the evil path (Prov 13:3; 21:23). • Wisdom opens itself to correction from godly people (see Prov 3:11; 9:8; 15:31; 19:25).

title: Psalms 142:1–3
content: Though overwhelmed by his persecutors (142:6), the psalmist looks to the Lord for wisdom.

title: Psalms 142:1–7
content: regarding his experience in the cave: Cp. Ps 57:title.

title: Psalms 142:7
content: His experience of confinement and duress is like being in prison (see 107:10).

title: Psalms 142:3–4
content: The psalmist reaches a point of despair (see 77:3), and the Lord cares for him in his distress. The psalmist commits himself to the Lord’s wisdom (see Ps 139) but laments his entrapment by the wicked (5:9–10; 140:5; 141:9; 142:3).

title: Psalms 142:5
content: Though he is alone, the psalmist’s trust remains in the Lord, who is his life (see 9:9; 16:5; 27:13).

title: Psalms 142:6–7
content: Though overwhelmed by loneliness and trouble, the psalmist focuses on the Lord’s goodness and protection. He knows that the Lord alone is his Redeemer, so he offers his praise.

title: Psalms 142
content: The psalmist faces severe persecution, so he cries to the Lord, and the Lord will rescue him.

title: Psalms 143:1–2
content: The psalmist prays for God’s love and mercy.

title: Psalms 143:1–12
content: In this lament, the psalmist feels overwhelmed by constant harassment from his foes, so he turns to the Lord’s love, righteousness, and faithfulness. He remembers God’s acts in the past and yearns for the renewal of the Lord’s love. He opens himself to God’s wisdom because he knows that instruction will lead to life.

title: Psalms 143:2
content: All people are guilty before God (Rom 3:20–24).

title: Psalms 143:3–4
content: I am losing all hope: The psalmist confesses his desperation as his life slips away under oppressive and ruthless foes.

title: Psalms 143:5–6
content: Remembering God’s acts from the past reassures the psalmist of God’s faithfulness (42:4; 63:6; 77:3, 6; 119:55).

title: Psalms 143:6
content: The psalmist’s thirst is a deep longing for God’s redemption (see 42:1–2).

title: Psalms 143:7
content: The psalmist experiences depression. He feels that he is dying from anguish (31:10; 119:87), exhausted (39:10; 71:9; 119:81), fainting with longing (84:2), and overwhelmed by the weariness of life (90:7, 9).

title: Psalms 143:7–10
content: The psalmist petitions the Lord for a renewal of his love.

title: Psalms 143:8–10
content: The psalmist prays for wisdom (see 5:8; 25:4–6; 138; 143:10). • your gracious Spirit: The Spirit brings God’s goodness (see 23:6).

title: Psalms 143:11
content: To preserve means in this case to restore from despair (80:19; 85:6; 138:7).

title: Psalms 143:12
content: A prayer for vindication and renewal of life concludes the psalm.

title: Psalms 144:1–2
content: The psalmist’s descriptive names for the Lord reveal his deep love for him.

title: Psalms 144:1–15
content: This lament begins with an exclamation of love for the Lord. The community then reflects on the transitory nature of life (144:3–4). The psalmist prays for divine intervention and anticipates victory (144:5–11). A new song (144:9–10) and a prayer for rescue (144:11) open up the theme of the Lord’s blessing through his provisions and protection (144:12–15).

title: Psalms 144:3–4
content: what are human beings? The same question in 8:4–6 elicits the answer that humans are mere mortals but are also glorious rulers. The psalmist depicts humans as having a transitory, empty existence (see 90:3, 7–10; 102:11; 109:23; 146:4).

title: Psalms 144:5–8
content: The psalmist prays for God’s intervention against his enemies (cp. 18:7–19).

title: Psalms 144:12
content: The psalmist compares sons and daughters to plants and pillars, which are images of strength and beauty.

title: Psalms 144:12–15
content: This prayer for the Lord’s blessing brings the laments of Pss 140–144 to a close. It offers a vision of God’s provision and protection (see Ps 127), not only for the psalmist, but for his descendants and those of all the godly.

title: Psalms 144:13–14
content: no enemy . . . no cries of alarm: These images depict peace and security.

title: Psalms 145:1–3
content: The psalmist praises God, the Great King who reigns over all other rulers (see 47:2).

title: Psalms 145:1–21
content: This hymn of praise is the last in this collection of the psalms of David (Pss 138–145). Praise continues in the last five psalms (Pss 146–150). This psalm celebrates the Lord as King of all (145:1–3, 10–13). God’s actions reveal his royal qualities (145:4–7). He cares for all creatures (145:14–17) and for those who fear him (145:18–20).

title: Psalms 145:4–7
content: This litany praises God’s character and mighty deeds. Each generation will continue to testify to God’s power (22:30).

title: Psalms 145:8–9
content: God consistently demonstrates his character toward all his creation (see 136:25).

title: Psalms 145:10–13
content: These verses form a description of the Lord’s kingdom.

title: Psalms 145:14–20
content: The Lord cares for his creatures.

title: Psalms 145:20
content: The Lord cares for those who love him and fear him. God-fearers love the Lord and find refuge in him (5:11); they seek him as their only true Savior (40:16; 70:4). They will experience a grand future (69:36), as well as God’s peace (119:165).

title: Psalms 146:1
content: This verse is reminiscent of 103:1, 2, 22; 104:1, 35.

title: Psalms 146:1–10
content: The call to praise (146:1–2) leads into a warning against folly and false confidence (146:3–4). The psalm concludes with a blessing for all who place their hope in the Lord (146:5–7).

title: Psalms 146:1–150.6
content: The Psalter ends with five hallelujah psalms, so named because each begins and ends with Praise the Lord! (Hebrew haleluyah).

title: Psalms 146:8–9
content: The fourfold repetition of the name of the Lord emphasizes that only he heals, unburdens, loves, and protects.

title: Psalms 147:1
content: This verse is a call to worship.

title: Psalms 147:1–20
content: The psalmist calls for the Lord to be praised for restoring and blessing Zion, caring for the poor, displaying his power over nature, and revealing himself to his people.

title: Psalms 147:2–6
content: The psalmist recalls the restoration of Jerusalem and the Lord’s afflicted exiles.

title: Psalms 147:4–5
content: The Lord created the heavens. • He counts the stars: God’s people can feel secure in knowing that the Lord attends to every detail of his creation; he knows all that belongs to him.

title: Psalms 147:6
content: God measures out his justice on the poor and on the wicked (55:22; 140:12; 145:14; 146:7).

title: Psalms 147:7–11
content: Human achievements fail to impress the God who commands nature; rather, he takes pleasure in those who fear him.

title: Psalms 147:8
content: God holds sovereign power over the weather (77:17–18; 78:26; 104:4; 148:5–6).

title: Psalms 147:10–11
content: human might: Any physical or intellectual achievement is a gift from the Lord, just like the strength of a horse. These gifts are a reason to praise the Lord, not to boast (Jer 9:23–24).

title: Psalms 147:13
content: The bars of the city gates symbolize defenses against enemies. • God blessed his people by empowering them with safety, prosperity, peace, and provisions (see 133:3).

title: Psalms 147:15–18
content: Simply by speaking his command, the Lord can change the season from unbearable winter to refreshing spring (see 147:8; 148:5–6).

title: Psalms 147:19–20
content: words . . . decrees . . . regulations: The Lord gave powerful words to Israel so that they might obey him (105:45).

title: Psalms 148:1
content: During Jesus’ triumphant entry into Jerusalem, the crowds called out various blessings, including a phrase taken from this verse (Matt 21:9; Mark 11:10; Luke 19:38).

title: Psalms 148:1–14
content: This psalm calls for the whole created order to praise the Lord because he has honored his faithful people.

title: Psalms 148:6
content: The created order is stable because of the Lord’s word (see 33:9).

title: Psalms 148:8
content: In the ancient Near East, people viewed different gods as having control over separate aspects of nature. The Lord, however, reigns sovereign over all natural phenomena; all the parts of creation are his servants, bringing praise to him through their obedience (77:17–18; 104:4; 135:7; 147:8, 15–18; Num 11:31).

title: Psalms 148:11–12
content: The psalmist calls all humans to offer praise to God, regardless of status, age, or gender.

title: Psalms 148:13–14
content: Universal praise of the Lord is fitting because he is glorious, and he has blessed his people (see 147:13; Isa 46:13; Eph 3:10). • His faithful ones are his trusting and devoted servants (Ps 86:2).

title: Psalms 149:1–9
content: This hymn of praise celebrates the Lord’s victory. He is the Maker of Israel (149:1–2) and the victorious King who shares his glory with his faithful ones (149:3–9).

title: Psalms 149:4
content: God’s people, whom the world ignores and despises, will be vindicated (Matt 19:30). The humble will experience victory over their oppressors and persecutors (see Isa 61:3).

title: Psalms 149:6–9
content: Vengeance is the Lord’s business (see 2:3; 94:1; 102:20; 142:7; 146:7).

title: Psalms 150:1
content: The phrase mighty heaven alludes to Gen 1 and to God’s glorious work in filling the emptiness.

title: Psalms 150:1–6
content: Everything that breathes is commanded to praise the Lord as he deserves. The whole Psalter describes the greatness of the Lord, so this psalm is a fitting conclusion.

title: Psalms 150:3–5
content: The psalmist calls all people to praise God with instruments and dancing. flutes: These wind instruments are not mentioned as being used in Temple worship. • clanging cymbals: Temple musicians clapped two bronze bowls together as percussion instruments.

title: Psalms 150:6
content: Praise the Lord: This refrain is a fitting conclusion to the entire book of Psalms.
